DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Helicopters Pursuing Contras, Cattle
DOC.TEXT: In helicopters and on foot, Sandinista forces are pursuing Contra rebels turned cattle rustlers, state radio said. Several clashes were reported. Radio Catarran in Juigalpa, capital of south-central Chontales province, said the army aims to recover more than 700 cattle some of the U.S.-backed guerrillas allegedly stole from farm cooperatives and state enterprises. ``Air force helicopters have taken part in the pursuit,'' the radio said Tuesday, denying the Soviet-made helicopters fired on civilian targets. Capt. Francisco Enrique Lorente, chief of the army's 52nd Brigade based in Santo Tomas, said operations are taking place in Muhan, La Gateada and Quimichapa, the radio reported. It quoted Lorente as saying Contra commanders Cafe Negro (Black Coffee), Alacran (Scorpion), and Muneco (Doll) led cattle-rustling raids that began Friday. No casualties were reported on either side, and the radio said some cattle were recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho Becomes 47th State Honoring Civil Rights Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, ```This historic ...,' to UPDATE with comment by Coretta Scott King.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Cecil Andrus on Tuesday signed into law a compromise bill making Idaho the nation's 47th state with an official holiday honoring civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. The law establishes Martin Luther King Jr.-Idaho Human Rights day on the third Monday in January, corresponding with the federal holiday first observed in 1986. Idaho's action leaves Arizona, Montana and New Hampshire the only holdouts not recognizing the federal holiday for King, who was assassinated on April 4, 1968, at the age of 39. ``This historic legislation firmly demonstrates that Idahoans have that broader concern for all humanity,'' Andrus said at a Statehouse ceremony. ``We stand against racism and for brotherhood.'' King's widow, Coretta Scott King, issued a statement from Atlanta commending Andrus and the Idaho Legislature. ``Governor Andrus has provided courageous leadeship in securing enactment of the holiday bill, as well as some of the strongest anti-bias legislation in the nation,'' Mrs. King said. Idaho's 10th state holiday was approved by the Legislature last month after lengthy, sometimes bitter debate. Opponents focused on the cost of another paid day off for state employees, which some put as high as $2.6 million, and whether King should be singled out for the honor. Supporters cited the impact of King's nonviolent philosophy and his symbolic importance. They also said the action was needed to help eliminate Idaho's stigma as a haven for racists such as the Panhandle-based Aryan Nations. Critics dismissed that problem as exaggerated and the fault of irresponsible media coverage. It took the addition of ``Idaho Human Rights Day'' to win over enough lawmakers for passage of the bill in the session's closing hours. Idaho's black population is estimated at 3,200, or just over three-tenths of 1 percent of the state's approximately 1 million people. New Hampshire legislators have consistently voted down holiday proposals since 1979. After losing in 1989, supporters said they would try again in 1991, the next time legislative rules allow it. Lawmakers in Montana, with an even smaller black population than Idaho, made Jan. 15 a ``day of observance'' in 1987 and created Heritage Day, a floating holiday to be designated by the governor. The Legislature in Arizona, the most populous state without an official King holiday, approved a paid holiday for state employees last year. But opponents petitioned to prevent the law from taking effect unless it is approved in a November referendum. Besides states without a King Day, North Dakota's holiday is unpaid, Louisiana's is by proclamation rather than legislation and is Jan. 19, Maryland's is on Jan. 15 whether or not that is a weekday, and some states give employees other holiday options to substitute. The legislative victory for Idaho supporters of a King holiday was overshadowed somewhat by its timing. While the bill was being adopted, Idaho also was embroiled in a national controversy over legislation that would have created the nation's most restrictive anti-abortion law. Andrus vetoed that measure only minutes after the Legislature adjourned for the year March 30, then waited more than a week to make the King holiday bill law to ensure it would have center stage to itself.

DOC.HEAD: Northernmost U.S. Immigration Agent Greets Visitors in Nome
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Charles ``Chick'' Trainor has what he thinks is the ideal job for an Alaskan in the age of glasnost. Since February, when he became the nation's northernmost Immigration and Naturalization Service officer, Trainor has enjoyed what he sees as his dual role of federal agent and one-man welcome wagon for Soviets coming to Alaska. ``My intention out there at the airport is to let them know we're happy to have them here. None of this `Let me see your papers,''' Trainor said. With cultural, educational and scientific exchanges between Alaska and the Soviet Far East burgeoning in the last year, Nome has become a principal contact point for citizens of both countries. Whenever a plane load of Soviet Young Pioneers (roughly equivalent to Boy Scouts), artists, educators or others visit Nome, it's Trainor's job to examine their papers and stamp their passports. He also occasionally goes to nearby Wales on the western tip of Seward Peninsula, or to Barrow, about 550 miles to the north on the Arctic Ocean, Although Trainor works for the INS, his duties also include those of a customs inspector. He must watch for the illegal importation of whale ivory, animal furs, and Soviet reindeer or any other meat products possibly carrying diseases. The 45-year-old former Marine has a background different from that of most federal agents. Since coming to Alaska in 1966, he has owned a saloon, scratched for gold, driven a truck, run a local housing agency and worked on the trans-Alaska pipeline. He also has been a guard at a local mental hospital. Flights between Nome and the Soviet Far East are strictly charter, so Trainor drives over to the Nome Airport only when summoned. Most of the calls come from Jim Rowe, whose Bering Air Service has pioneered flights between northwest Alaska and the Soviet Far East. Soviets who visit Nome, a community of 3,600 with boom-town roots dating to turn-of-the-century gold-rush days, arrive wide-eyed and often gawk at the stacks of consumer goods in local stores, Trainor said. ``They think we stock the shelves just to impress them,'' he said. Many return home carrying computers, stereos and other items hard to find in the Soviet Union _ especially in the Far East. Some stores in Nome accept rubles as a goodwill gesture, although the Soviet currency is virtually worthless on the world market. Trainor thinks U.S.-Soviet exchanges will help break down barriers to international understanding. ``I see no reason why we should be fighting them,'' he said. ``We don't even know them.'' One barrier between Trainor and visiting Soviets is created, however, by the INS uniform he wears. ``They are extremely suspicious of me because I'm a police official, and I guess over there they don't hobnob with police officials,'' said Trainor, who's studying Russian to help break down the barriers. Whatever happens with superpower relations between Moscow and Washington, Trainor and others in this coastal community think people-to-people contact between Nome and the Soviet Far East will have some lasting effects. ``They've had a taste of it now,'' Trainor said. ``They like this town.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes, Sinks So Deep It Can't Be Found
DOC.TEXT: A small plane plunged nose-first into a freshly plowed field during heavy rain Tuesday, sinking so deep in mud and water that neither the wreckage nor its occupants could be found, authorities said. ``It hit and didn't bounce, jump or anything,'' Dr. Wesley Dyer, the Rapides Parish coroner, said after walking from the muddy field where the wreckage was found. ``I think a thunderhead twisted it up and spit out the pieces.'' The crash happened sometime Tuesday afternoon and the plane could seat four people, but authorities still hadn't found any bodies by Tuesday night because the plane was so deeply submerged in the water-filled hole. Small pieces of the plane were visible over about a 100-yard area in the field, located between U.S. 71 and a rural road just northwest of this small, central Louisiana community. Firemen, city police and parish sheriff's deputies were still trying Tuesday night to drain the hole containing the plane so the wreckage could be pulled out. Authorities said it probably would be morning before they would learn whether anyone had been killed. Dyer said a small piece of wing with a serial number on it was found in the field and the number was given to the Federal Aviation Administration for tracing.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan's King Pledges No Retreat From Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Pledging ``there will be no turning back'' from parliamentary democracy, King Hussein is entrusting a committee with drafting guidelines for legalizing political parties outlawed 33 years ago. Hussein gathered the 60 members of the National Charter committee on Tuesday and pleaded on television for a pact that will guarantee tolerance for conflicting viewpoints. ``The new phase with we are about to begin will pave the way for the resumption of political pluralism, which is another cornerstone of democracy,'' the 54-year-old king said. ``The constitutional parliamentary life is our common choice, and the path from which there will be no turning back.'' His speech had historic importance for this country of 3.1 million people. In November, Hussein oversaw Jordan's first national election since 1967, one of the freest ever held in the Arab world. He said the charter would form ``a broad and flexible framework for national action'' and would regulate ``the state's various activities in politics, economy, security, social affairs and culture.'' He cautioned that without good will and agreement on basic concepts, ``democracy turns into anarchy'' and develops ``fangs and talons that tear at the fabric of national unity and destroy the achievements and gains of the state.'' Hussein, who has ruled since 1953, is relinquishing many powers but retains firm control and is personally popular. The king said his July 1988 decision to renounce claims to the Israeli-occupied West Bank in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization led to last November's parliamentary election. The West Bank, captured in the 1967 Middle East war, held half the seats in Jordan's old Parliament. It is not represented in the new body. Hussein said four days of widespread rioting over economic problems and government policies one year ago led him to seek the National Charter. He said the riots showed that elections alone ``would be an insufficient remedy'' because Jordanians held ``varying convictions on some of the fundamental tenets and precepts upon which the kingdom is founded.'' The king banned political parties in 1957 following an unsuccessful leftist coup attempt. A non-party Parliament continued intermittently until 1974. After a 10-year hiatus, it was revived in 1984 despite the lack of elections since 1967. ``Anyone who thinks that I was comfortable with the situation which prevailed in the absence of an elected Parliament, or that I was happy bearing most of the burden (of government), is mistaken,'' said Hussein. He said the parties of the 1950s, when pan-Arab forces tried to spread their influence across national borders, ``were governed by the positions and dictates of their leaders from abroad.'' He accused them of seeking ``power at the expense of democracy'' and of violating ``another tenet of political pluralism, which is to refrain from violence.'' The king repeated that ``Jordan's commitment to help the Palestinian people and their just cause is a historic and fateful part of its national commitment. ``Jordan will continue to exert all available resources to support the struggle of the Palestinian people under its national leadership, represented by the Palestine Liberation Organization.'' Roughly half of Jordan's people come from Palestinian families who fled or were driven from their homes by Israel's creation or its capture of the West Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Setting Summit Date `Catalyst' for Arms Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf: ``Bush said,'' with two grafs to get Bush back in Washington
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday there's an ``awful lot to be done'' before next month's superpower summit. He added that he doesn't want to suggest that complete agreement is possible in advance on a new arms control treaty. Bush, on a brief visit to Canada, also issued a fresh warning to Mikhail Gorbachev to refrain from using force in the breakaway republic of Lithuania. But he coupled his words with praise for the Soviet president's commitment to ``peaceful change and the evolution of democracy'' in Europe and the Soviet Union. Bush said the presence of Soviet tanks in Lithuania make it ``even more important to have good-faith negotiations'' over the fate of the republic. ``I would just appeal to all sides and anyone with any influence to encourage dialogue and discussion,'' he said. Bush and Gorbachev are scheduled to meet in the United States beginning May 30. Bush also said he didn't know enough about the release of three European hostages in Beirut earlier in the day to say whether Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi deserved any of the credit for their release. ``If indeed a person deserves credit for facilitating the release of people held against their will ... I would say fine, give the person credit,'' he said. As for Gadhafi, Bush said, ``we've got some major differences with Libya that continue to exist, but look, who am I to argue in this case if someone can help free one hostage? ... give that person credit.'' Bush spoke first with reporters aboard Air Force One en route from Washington. He and Brian Mulroney, the Canadian prime minister, fielded reporters' questions after their private meeting on the upcoming summit and other topics, and before attending a baseball game between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Texas Rangers in Toronto's domed stadium. Bush flew back to Washington later in the evening. Before the game, Bush said he was looking forward to throwing out the first ball. ``I'm going to go with a slider this time,'' he said. ``I've had such good luck in the last couple of years. The catcher let me down one time when he couldn't get into the dirt and grab it properly.'' For his part, the Canadian leader said he looked forward to negotiations with the United States on an acid rain treaty, with the talks to begin after Congress approves clean air legislation. Both leaders said they were hoping Gorbachev would avoid the use of force in Lithuania, and Bush renewed his earlier statements that the future of superpower relations could be affected by what the Soviets do in their attempt to deal with the secession crisis at home. He said the United States hopes ``they will conduct themselves in a way that can move the dramatic progress that's taken place in the last year or so even further forward.'' Asked whether he was basing his foreign policy on the fate of a single man, Bush said that wasn't the case. He then added, ``In this case Mr. Gorbachev, the president, has a record of encouraging or certainly acquiescing in the peaceful evolution'' in Eastern Europe. ``He has demonstrated that he is committed to peaceful change and the evolution of democracy.'' Mulroney said he agreed with Bush that Gorbachev represents a new kind of Soviet leader _ ``more attractive and more realistic and ... appears to be much more in keeping with some if not all of the values that we in the West defend.'' He said the Soviet leader had displayed ``reasonableness that we had not come to know in earlier Soviet leaders.'' Earlier, on his plane, Bush said there was an ``awful lot to be done'' on arms control in advance of his meeting with Gorbachev, and said, ``I can't predict how much will be done by the time the summit rolls around.'' He said it was a good thing to have a date set and ``obviously this will serve as a bit of a catalyst or goal for getting things done.'' He said he didn't want to ``suggest we're going to have all the details worked out by the time of the summit.'' ``You deal with what's on the table,'' Bush said. The superpowers are negotiating agreements on long-range nuclear weapons, chemical arms and troop and tank levels in Europe. Bush said combining the baseball game between the Toronto Blue Jays and the Texas Rangers with the Mulroney meeting ``just seemed like a wonderful way to do it.'' The president's son, George Walker Bush, is part owner of the Rangers. The meeting with Mulroney is the first in a series of talks Bush plans this month with Western leaders before the summit in Washington. Bush will fly to Bermuda on Friday to meet with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and will hold talks with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla., on April 19. The president enjoys a strong friendship with Mulroney. The prime minister and his family were guests last year at the Bush seaside vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. Canadian Ambassador Derek H. Burney said Monday that Canada was in a ``unique position these days in Washington'' in terms of ``access and influence.'' ``The fact that we are able to get attention to Canadian concerns when we want to ... speaks well for continued economic growth in Canada, as well as providing us with an opportunity of influence in helping address some of the more pressing international issues,'' Burney said.

DOC.HEAD: Sculptor Creates Dinosaurs From Junk Auto Parts
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Sculptor Jim Gary looks at the rusting oil pan from a junked automobile and he sees the gaping jaw of a dinosaur. Under his welding torch, the metallic bones and joints of extinct automotive behemoths from Detroit are reincarnated as Gary's artistic vision of the prehistoric giants that crawled from the ooze to roam our planet millions of years ago. Gary, a self-taught sculptor from Farmingdale, N.J., has built more than 200 of his ``20th century dinosaurs'' from the brake shoes, universal joints, leaf springs, drive shafts, hoods, front ends and other parts of scrapped cars and trucks. Some of his larger creatures, he says, required more than 500 parts from as many as a dozen automobiles and took a year to complete. He prefers the parts from older cars, dating back to 1960, because they have more character. One of his biggest dinosaurs, the 57-foot-long Diplodocus, contains more than $5,000 worth of junk parts. The plates along the arched back of the evil-looking Stegosaurus were a challenge. Gary finally took them from the inner walls of a wrecked garbage compactor. Eighteen of Gary's skeletal dinosaur sculptures in rich yellows, greens, purples and blues or natural rust, plus four brightly colored dragon flies, are making their Washington debut Thursday at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History. The works will be on display through Aug. 10 as part of a new museum show titled ``Dinamation's Dinosaurs Alive and in Color,'' which features a collection of computer-controlled robotic dinosaurs that roar and squeal, rip meat from carcasses, tend their offspring and crane their necks toward spectators. The main show, now touring the United States, was created by Dinamation International Corp. of California and will be on view at the museum through Sept. 3 for an admission fee of $4 for adults and $2 for children. Gary's exhibit will be free. His dinosaurs have toured museums in the United States, Japan and Australia since 1979. They have been pictured in school textbooks, magazines and an encyclopedia, and made an appearance in the George Lucas movie, ``Howard the Duck.'' Gary learned about cars as a kid growing up in Colts Neck, N.J., where he picked up enough junkyard parts to build and license two homemade jalopies. Years later, as a sculptor searching for unusual art supplies, he returned to his old childhood haunts. ``When I saw those heaps of junked cars,'' he said, ``it reminded me of an elephant graveyard. Just as elephants went to the graveyard to die, those old cars went to the junkyard to die.'' Gary saw a parallel between old cars and dinosaurs, the chrome-finned gas guzzlers and the prehistoric plant eaters. Both died out and were replaced by smaller, more fuel-efficient species. ``The car really is an animal. It has its own metabolism and needs fuel, air and water to exist,'' he said. ``To survive it had to change, just like the dinosaurs. The evolution of the two is obvious.'' Gary envisions the junkyard as a burial ground for the discarded artifacts of 20th century technology, where future scientists might study the remains of scrapped cars just as paleontologists examine fossils for clues about how dinosaurs lived and died. ``It's not my intention to suggest that the auto industry is going the way of the dinosaur,'' Gary said hastily. ``I'm just doing my work as a sculptor.''

DOC.HEAD: Union Officials: Greyhound Suit is Attempt to Keep Talks Stalled
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Union officials accused by Greyhound officials of organizing strike violence contend a $30 million civil suit filed by the company is merely an excuse not to return to the bargaining table. ``We have consistently asked this company to present its evidence. We know that there is no evidence. They've simply pointed the finger of blame at employees and used the issue as a smoke screen'' for not resuming negotiations, union spokesman Nick Nichols said Monday after Greyhound filed suit in U.S. District Court in Jacksonville, Fla. The suit claimed that unlawful actions by the Amalgamated Transit Union and 20 union officers have cost the company at least $10 million. It accused the union of violating provisions of the federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, which allows triple damages to be assessed. Nichols noted that no government agency has filed criminal charges against union officers. ``Anyone can hire a lawyer and submit some documents to the court,'' he said. The strike, called on March 2, has been marked by shootings, bomb threats and other incidents. The company has said it won't resume negotiations until a week goes by without an act of violence. Greyhound Vice President Anthony P. Lannie, who announced the suit in Washington, maintained that several specific offenses showed a pattern of racketeering activity, including extortion, attempted murder, obstruction of justice, interference with interstate commerce and arson. He charged that, through violent activities, union officials were attempting to ``win an inflated financial settlement they could never achieve through lawful, collective bargaining. There is a word for that _ extortion.'' Union officers allegedly assigned rank-and-file members violent tasks and then paid them from the union's strike defense fund, the suit contended. ``That's false and ridiculous,'' said Fred Ingram, president of ATU Local 1493 in Charlotte, N.C., and one of two local presidents the company has asked the court to replace with a receiver. ``We have never ordered anybody to do anything. I don't know where that's coming from.'' Strikers are paid $50 a week in strike benefits for manning picket lines, he said. Ingram contended that the company filed the lawsuit to divert attention from its refusal to resume contract negotiations. ``Their whole plan from the beginning has been to get rid of the union,'' he said. Last month, a replacement driver in Fayetteville, N.C., swore an assault charge against Ingram following a picket line altercation. Besides Ingram, the suit seeks to have Rafael Rivera, president of Local 1600 in Atlanta, removed from office. About 6,300 Greyhound drivers and 3,000 maintenance and other workers walked out over wages and job security. Greyhound, the nation's only nationwide bus system, has been operating on a reduced schedule with replacement drivers it hired and union members who crossed the picket line.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Attacks Rival's Office With Backhoe
DOC.TEXT: Police protection didn't prevent an attack on an underworld's office by a rival in a backhoe who destroyed a police car, a guard house and a garage before 10 officers shot out the vehicle's tires, officials said. It was the second time this year that a member of Japan's largest underworld organization, the Yamaguchi-gumi group, used such a heavy construction vehicle against the office of the rival Takenaka-gumi, a local police official said. Two police officers and one mob member were injured in Sunday's attack in Okayama, 345 miles west of Toyko. Police said the backhoe, driven by Toshiyuki Okamoto, 24, dragged a patrol car 33 feet and smashed into the police guard house when officers tried to stop the attack. Okamoto damaged the office building's gate and garage and several cars by repeatedly ramming into the building, police said. Authorities often station police officers outside gang offices when violence is expected to protect the neighborhood and hopefully prevent confrontations. One policeman was stabbed when he stopped one of several people who came out of the Takenaka-gumi office and tried to attack Okamoto, who was protected by the backhoe's bullet-proof cab, the official said. Okamoto and the man who stabbed the officer were both arrested. The Takenaka-gumi broke with the Yamaguchi-gumi last year in protest over the appointment of Yoshinori Watanabe as the new gang boss. Watanabe's predecessor, Masahisa Takenaka, was killed in a leadership dispute in 1985. The Takenaka-gumi now is led by Masahisa Takenaka's younger brother, Masashi. Police say the Yamaguchi-gumi has about 21,000 members nationwide. The Takenaka-gumi is widely believed to have been reduced to about 20 members. Police estimate Japan has 90,000 mob members, nearly half associated with the three largest gangs _ the Yamaguchi-gumi and the Tokyo-based Inagawa-kai and Sumiyoshi Rengo. Members often wear badges identifying them as gang members, although they do not admit to criminal activity. Police say the gangs are involved in extortion, illicit gambling, the drug and sex trades, and money laundering. Some also have interests in the construction, real estate and entertainment businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Some Lawmakers Back Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Some lawmakers are readying legislation to halt all U.S. aid to Iraq as tensions mount over a series of incidents, including a threat by President Saddam Hussein to use chemical weapons against Israel. ``We should be ashamed'' of the U.S. trading relationship with Iraq, said Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif. Berman has drafted proposed sanctions that would end all U.S. assistance to Iraq, including agricultural credits and investment guarantees under the Export-Import Bank. Several others in Congress, including Sens. William Cohen, R-Maine, and John McCain, R-Ariz., said they support some kind of sanctions against the Baghdad government. ``I think we ought to take action,'' Cohen said recently, adding it was ``not an acceptable situation'' for the United States to be doing business with a country seeking to add nuclear weapons to an arsenal that already includes chemical weapons. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he will push for legislation to impose sanctions against any nation that uses chemical weapons illegally. But not everyone in Congress favors immediate sanctions. Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said it would be premature to do anything without first talking with Hussein. Specter, who visited Iraq in January with Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., urged Hussein to ``exercise restraint.'' ``We believe discussions and negotiations can go far to resolve current tensions,'' Specter and Shelby said in a letter to Hussein. The outrage among some in Congress comes amid growing tension over Iraq's actions. Hussein has been criticized for threatening to use chemical weapons against Israel and for executing an Iranian-born British journalist accused of spying. Last month, U.S. and British intelligence agents broke up an Iraqi smuggling ring allegedly trying to obtain nuclear triggers for atomic weapons. Iraq denied the charge. On Monday, Iraq expelled an American diplomat in retaliation for the expulsion of an Iraqi diplomat posted at the United Nations. The State Department said the Iraqi was suspected of being involved in a plot to kill two political opponents. Margaret Tutwiler, the department spokeswoman, said Iraq's decision to expel the American was ``totally inappropriate.'' The sour climate prompted the Commerce Department to cancel the Iraqi leg of a trade mission scheduled to visit Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Egypt in May. ``We thought it was inappropriate to take a group of U.S. companies to Iraq at this time,'' said Elizabeth Dugan, a Commerce Department spokeswoman. Nine aerospace companies signed up to travel to the Mideast on a mission to ``help U.S. companies enhance their market position overseas and gain market exposure,'' the department said. ``Iraq has ambitious plans for upgrading its civil aviation system, including new airports, air traffic control and related equipment,'' the statement said. Berman has criticized the Bush and Reagan administrations for allegedly having a ``soft spot'' for Iraq. Ms. Tutwiler said U.S. relations with Iraq have been ``complex and sometimes disturbing'' since the restoration of diplomatic ties in 1985. Berman said Iraq has received about $1 billion a year in agricultural credits from the United States since 1984. The United States imported about $1.5 billion worth of goods, mainly oil, from Iraq in 1988, the Commerce Department said. It exported about $1.1 billion in goods to Iraq, mostly agriculture products.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Seeks Boost in Long Distance Market With Telecom Merger
DOC.TEXT: Telecommunications industry analysts say MCI's merger with Telecom USA Inc. will give the nation's second-largest long-distance company a chance for greater inroads into a market still dominated by American Telephone & Telegraph Co. That could mean good news for consumers, they say, and even AT&T is saying it hopes to benefit from the tougher competition. MCI Communications Corp. and Telecom USA, the fourth largest company in the long distance market, said Monday that MCI would acquire all outstanding shares of Telecom USA's stock for $42 a share, for a total price of $1.25 billion. The transaction is subject to approval by Telecom's stockholders. The Federal Communications Commission also would have to grant approval and the Justice Department would review whether the deal would violate antitrust laws. ``It's a strategically important move,'' Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's president and chief operating officer, said in an interview. ``It immediately brings us additional market share of about 1{ percent and against AT&T, as dominant a competitor as they are, that efficiency is very important.'' Industry analysts agreed the acquisition should give MCI a strong boost, despite the cost, because of Telecom's active moves in advanced technology. ``This shows the industry is consolidating at a very fast pace. AT&T is a very aggressive competitor and you have to move rapidly to grow. This gives MCI a further boost,'' said Charles Nichols, a telecommunications industry analyst for Prudential-Bache securities. Nichols and other analysts played down the stock market reaction to the Monday's announcement, which sent Telecom USA soaring $16.25 to $38.12{ a share trading on the New York Stock Exchange. MCI dipped $1.12{ to $35.75 a share on the over-the-counter market. ``We think this puts MCI and Telecom in a favorable position,'' said Cathy Clarke, senior analyst for The Yankee Group, a Boston-based consulting and marketing firm. ``MCI is growing and this will increase their potential'' to gain more of the market and provide more services, she said. The cost ``will have no effect on our ability to fund growth,'' said Roberts. ``We're in a very cash-strong position. You're going to see that debt paid off very quickly, within a couple of years.'' MCI revenues increased more than 20 percent in 1989 to $6.5 billion, while Telecom had revenues of $713 million in sales last year. Atlanta-based Telecom was formed in 1988 with the merger of Southernet of Atlanta and Teleconnect of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and serves customers primarily in the Southeast and Midwest. AT&T holds 64 percent of the long distance market, down from about 90 percent before the court-ordered breakup of the old Bell system in 1984. MCI has 12 percent and US Sprint is third with 9 percent, according to the most recent FCC figures. MCI will gain the digital network and the fiber optic systems Telecom has in place. ``They're going to gain a lot of network miles,'' said The Yankee Group's Clarke. ``In this type of merger, we expect to see cost savings, improved quality of service, improvements for customers such as one-stop shopping. So, overall, this should be good news for consumers,'' she said. Even AT&T said it was a good move. The former monopoly is trying to convince the FCC that there is enough competition in the market to lift some regulations aimed solely at AT&T. ``This development ... suggests two vigorous companies are combining forces to provide even more competition,'' said AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen. ``We wake up every day to a real knockdown, drag-out fight in the marketplace.'' Paul Thibeau, spokesman for No. 3 Sprint, suggested there may be more mergers and acquisitions in the industry in the struggle to chip away at AT&T. The MCI move ``should come as no surprise to those who follow the telecommunications industry,'' he said. ``We continue to explore similar opportunities.'' ``MCI will continue to focus on strategic acquisitions that make sense,'' said Roberts.

DOC.HEAD: G7 Countries Giving Weak Support to Japan's Effort to Boost Yen
DOC.TEXT: Japan isn't getting a lot of support from the United States and other major economic powers in its effort to check the steep decline of the yen, many economists say. After a weekend meeting of financial ministers in Paris, the Group of Seven industrial nations warned that the yen's recent decline has ``undesirable consequences.'' The group, consisting of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada and Italy, pledged to ``keep these developments under review'' and reaffirmed its commitment to ``cooperation in exchange markets.'' However, on Monday, the central banks of the group followed the statement with only weak and uncoordinated intervention, traders said. Central banks intervene by buying yen in an attempt to push up its price. Also, there was no indication that the United States and West Germany were inclined to cut their interest rates to bolster the yen. ``They're basically leaving Japan twisting in the wind,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based consultant. ``There was just enough intervention so the Japanese wouldn't have egg all over their face.'' Economists said although the Group of Seven's statement was slightly stronger in tone than expected, it will not halt the yen's slide unless Japan does more to shore up its economy. Turmoil in the Japanese stock market and political instability have helped push the yen down 11 percent in value compared with the dollar this year. It hit a three-year low of 160 yen to the dollar early last week before recovering somewhat before the meeting. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.02 yen to 156.45 yen Monday. But later in New York, the dollar traded at 158.335 yen, up from Friday's 157.70 yen. ``The market is just not really sure of the G-7's resolve. ... They're going to have to come in collectively and so far they haven't. The intervention has seemed more of a gesture than a real movement,'' said Kevin Lawrie, a currency trader in New York with the Bank of Boston. In order to stabilize its currency long term, Japan will have to further increase its interest rates, said economist David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. An increase in Japanese rates relative to U.S. rates makes the yen a more attractive investment and raises its value. The Bank of Japan raised its discount rate from 4.25 percent to 5.25 percent on March 20, but it was not enough to stem the yen's slide. Since a March 23 meeting in Los Angeles between Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Japan had been asking for interest rate cuts in the United States and West Germany. But other countries are not inclined to help the Japanese at the expense of their own economic objectives, analysts said. The West Germans fear that lower rates will increase inflationary pressures in their country, where the economy already is being stimulated by the prospect for investment in Eastern Europe and monetary union with East Germany. In the United States, the Federal Reserve has been reluctant to cut rates until clearer evidence emerges that inflation is moderating. ``For the Fed to lower interest rates in the current inflation environment is not in the cards,'' said economist Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. In contrast with the Fed, the Bush administration favors lower U.S. interest rates, both to stimulate economic growth and to help the U.S. trade deficit, economists said. A weak yen pushes up the trade deficit by making Japanese goods less expensive in the United States and raising the price of U.S. goods in Japan. The Group of Seven officials will get a chance to re-evaluate their stance at their next meeting in early May in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Fishy Stories Brighten Tabloids And Titillate The Masses
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Extra, extra, read all about it: Woman gives birth to fish! If that's too tame, how about randy spooks impregnating maidens? Or perhaps a ``routine'' appearance by the Virgin Mary? Such reports are a staple of Manila's lively tabloids, among the most widely read of the city's more than 20 dailies. In a country where the truth is often bizarre enough, English and Tagalog language tabloids dish out fantasy and flamboyance for those who find the broadsheet dailies too tame. The latest titillation was the saga of ``Goldfish Flores Pascua,'' a six-inch-long mudfish supposedly ``born'' to Lilian Pascua, 22, of Paniqui in Tarlac province. Several Manila tabloids reported that Mrs. Pascua gave birth to the fish March 31 and named it ``Goldfish.'' Tabloids splashed pictures of ``Goldfish,'' swimming in a water basin, and its ``parents'' on their front pages. For several days, tabloids regaled their readers with details of the couple's plans to baptize the fish on Palm Sunday, despite healthy skepticism by local officials. ``I think a fish should not be baptized and registered because it doesn't even have the resemblance of a man,'' said Paniqui Mayor Cesar Cuchapin. The baptism controversy was resolved when tabloids reported last week that ``Goldfish's'' short but celebrated life had come to an end. It was eaten by the family dog. With ``Goldfish'' history, the tabloid Ang Pilipino Ngayon, or Filipino Today, reported today that an 8-year-old boy had given birth by caesarian section in a hospital in Pampanga province. The baby, a boy, was still-born, the tabloid reported. Not to be scooped, Manila radio station DZXL telephoned the hospital and spoke with an official, who confirmed that something resembling a fetus had been extracted from the boy. ``How could he give birth when he is only 8 years old,'' the reporter asked, apparently more curious over age than the sex peculiarity. The official was at a loss for a response. Many of the far-fetched reports play on traditions of mysticism and superstition which run deep in this predominately Roman Catholic country. ``Goldfish'' attracted almost as much attention as a teen-aged girl in Laguna province, who the tabloids reported two years ago became pregnant by the spirit of a 19th century cleric. Apparitions by the Virgin Mary are frequently reported, although the church hierarchy tends to give them little credence. The most recent was reported last year, when the Virgin supposedly appeared in a coconut grove southeast of Manila. Last month, the former governor of Cagayan province, Rudolfo Aquinaldo, eluded troops seeking to arrest him for trying to overthrow the government and fled into the mountains with armed followers. One tabloid quoted Cagayan residents as saying Aguinaldo was protected by an amulet which ``gives him the characteristics of a dog,'' not always a blessing in an area where puppies are prized as food. But the tabloid explained that with the amulet, Aquinaldo ``can smell his enemies coming.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Seeks Stricter Regulation of Cosmetics Industry
DOC.TEXT: Makers of cosmetics and toiletries say there is no need to increase regulation of their industry because their voluntary efforts already are ensuring the safety of their products. But Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., says a General Accounting Office report to Congress shows that this self-regulation approach isn't working and may be allowing unsafe products on the market. The report by the investigating arm of Congress found that most manufacturers of personal care products _ which include everything from toothpaste to bubble bath _ are not signing up for voluntary federal oversight. The Food and Drug Administration has no authority to require these manufacturers to let the agency know they exist, to provide safety-testing data on their products or reports on adverse reactions. Without at least a registration requirement, ``anyone could make cosmetics in their bathtub and not have to tell the FDA their location or any information about the product. That's absurd,'' said Wyden, who requested the report. Of the 2,000 to 2,500 companies that FDA estimates are making cosmetics products, 778 were registered with the agency as of July 1989 _ about 31 to 39 percent. The Cosmetics, Toiletry and Fragrance Association estimates there are at most 2,000 manufacturers and that 60 percent of them are registered. ``There isn't a serious safety problem. ... If there was ... the agency would know about it and the public would know about it,'' said Michael Petrina, the group's vice president for legislative relations. The association, the main trade organization for the cosmetics industry, has been encouraging manufacturers to register voluntarily with the FDA, he said. It also has been collecting and reviewing safety data on chemicals used in cosmetics, Petrina said, noting that registration grew by 94 companies from 1988 to 1989. ``The FDA has plenty of information now to make any judgments to deal with any safety concerns,'' he said. ``We don't think the FDA needs any more authority to regulate. ... We don't think it makes any sense to divert their scarce resources to an industry that has a demonstrated safety record.'' Petrina noted that government regulations do require that ingredients of personal-care products be listed on the labels of retail products sold to consumers. Noncommercial products sold for professional use in business establishments, such as beauty salons, are exempt from that requirement. Wyden said the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, on the books since 1938, should be rewritten to require cosmetics manufacturers to register with the FDA and provide data on safety tests and injury reports. He said he expects to introduce such legislation later this year. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said: ``The agency is doing what it can to regulate the industry under the authority Congress gave it.'' Asked if the FDA needs more authority, Nesbit said, ``It's Congress' responsibility to write the laws.''

DOC.HEAD: He's Never Discouraged People From Calling him a Mob Lawyer
DOC.TEXT: The gold lettering on the plate-glass window reads simply: Law Office. Inside works Rhode Island's busiest criminal lawyer _ a man who has built a career by representing reputed organized crime figures. ``I've never discouraged people from referring to me as a mob lawyer,'' John F. ``Jack'' Cicilline said between drags on his cigarette. ``I suppose to some people it's a sinister connotation, but it's done me well. Someone has to represent these people.'' But Cicilline does more than defend people such as reputed mob boss Raymond J. ``Junior'' Patriarca _ he befriends them. Pictures of Patriarca and his late father, legendary organized crime leader Raymond L.S. Patriarca, hang in Cicilline's office. On the opposite wall is a framed copy of a 1983 indictment against Cicilline _ charges he eventually beat. Cicilline rents his office from Patriarca in the city's Italian section _ not far from where he grew up. His father wanted him to become a lawyer. Although he originally planned on entering the foreign service, he's glad he followed his father's advice. ``I love doing this work,'' he said. Cicilline put himself through law school, commuting 60 miles to Boston's Suffolk University while working days to support the wife with whom he'd eloped as a teen-ager. The balding 51-year-old sees himself as on the front line defending civil rights. He said his small firm, which includes two of his five children, takes ``more than our fair share'' of cases from poor people. ``I see myself as one of the last survivors of the battle against the system taking over,'' he said. Two of Cicilline's clients were arrested last month in an FBI sweep. Patriarca and Matthew Guglielmetti Jr. are charged with racketeering. Partriarca, 45, has been identified in testimony before the U.S. Senate as head of the New England Cosa Nostra. Guglielmetti, Cicilline's golf partner, is named in last month's indictment as a lieutenant in charge of the Patriarca family's Connecticut operation. That doesn't faze Cicilline, who said his ``commonality'' with some of his clients has forged friendships that have survived even though ``a lot of them are in jail.'' ``I've never heard anyone say his reputation has been impaired or sullied in any way because of the company he keeps,'' said Presiding Superior Court Judge Anthony A. Giannini. ``Jack is a very sensitive, warm guy,'' said Dick Casparian, chief public defender. But when asked about Cicilline's personal relationship with some clients, Casparian said he had never developed such a friendship in 16 years as a criminal lawyer. Cicilline said he knows nothing about organized crime. As to the guilt or innocence of his clients and friends, Cicilline said: ``I've heard what's said about a lot of my clients. I don't know if it's true and it doesn't bother me even if it is true.'' Cicilline said he got involved in representing reputed mobsters as a young lawyer trying to build a practice. ``You've got to take little risks,'' said Cicilline. ``Risking my reputation is a risk I was willing to take. ``I can't say I didn't enjoy seeing my name in the paper with people who were expected to be seen with the best lawyer money could buy.'' That strategy, with a healthy dose of talent, made Cicilline into the state's busiest criminal lawyer. He takes on about 25 percent of the criminal cases that don't go to the public defender's office, according to Giannini. That doesn't include the many cases he handles in federal court. Although Cicilline has the respect of his colleagues, many refuse to talk about his private life. A half-dozen law enforcement officials also refused to comment on Cicilline. In 1980, the FBI bugged Cicilline's office. In 1983, an informant wore a wire during a meeting with the lawyer and mobster Frank L. ``Bobo'' Marrapese Jr. After a mistrial and a hung jury, Cicilline cleared himself of charges he conspired to persuade a witness to lie. ``He's aware of the tightrope that he chooses to walk,'' one police officer said, demanding anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Forum Lays Emphasis On Tradition, For Gradual Reform
DOC.TEXT: A historian has emerged as Hungary's most powerful political figure after leading to electoral victory a conservative party that appeals to the Hungarian pride long stifled under the Communists. Jozsef Antall, 58, dominates the Hungarian Democratic Forum, which has been vilified by critics as nationalistic and anti-Semitic. He and other senior party officials deny such charges. They say the party's emphasis on traditional Hungarian values, including a strong sense of the Hungarian nation that extends to minorities outside the country's frontiers, has been misunderstood. Nevertheless, the Forum may be courting trouble with its militant championing of Hungarian minority rights in neighboring countries. With victory assured after Sunday's second round of parliamentary elections, Antall told a cheering crowd on Monday that his government will be the spokesman of 15 million Hungarians. He was referring not only to Hungary's 11 million people, but to those in neighboring countries _ mainly Romania _ who became foreign citizens after the 1920 Trianon peace treaty. Last month, Romania was the site of the most violent anti-Hungarian riots in recent memory. Its leaders are already worried about Hungarian interference and may not be keen on the idea of more intense scrutiny of the fate of Hungarians within its borders. Yugoslavia, the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, also home to Hungarian minorities, could object as well. Once in office, the Forum may have no choice but to change its priorities and deal with specter of economic collapse. A foreign debt of more than $20 billion, growing unemployment and double-digit inflation are some of the most worrisome legacies of centralized economic planning that must be dealt with as Hungary's new leaders embrace free market reforms. From its inception in September 1987, at the outset of the democratization process that led to the elections, the center-right Democratic Forum incorporated three major trends _ a strong national consciousness, Christian democracy and economic liberalism. In the elections, the Forum captured 165 of the 386 parliamentary seats at stake and is expected to forge a governing coalition with the Smallholders Party and Christian Democrats that would control nearly 60 percent of the legislature. As little as a year ago, Jozsef Antall was a virtual unknown. A man of patrician bearing, Antall was born April 8, 1932, a scion of the landed gentry. His father was a widely respected leader of the Independent Smallholders' Party, and the Democratic Forum embraces many of the pre-war Smallholder ideas. The young Antall studied law, economics and history and was teaching high school when the anti-Stalinist revolt broke out in 1956 only to be crushed by Soviet tanks. Active on the side of the revolutionaries, he took part in the brief revival of the the Smallholders' Party. In a January magazine interview, he called the revolution a ``pivotal event'' in his life. After the revolution, he was arrested and barred from teaching. He later gained employment as a librarian and in 1964 joined the Semmelweis Medical History Museum, to be made its director 10 years later. Although invited, Antall did not attend the founding meeting of the Democratic Forum because he was outside the country. But he became intensely involved soon after the party's creation, refusing leadership posts with both the revived Smallholders and the Christian Democrats. He was elected Forum leader in October. Antall the politician seeks to project the image of a thoughtful, benign, wise surrogate father. The Forum's main campaign slogan was ``Calm Force.'' Even his political rivals gave him top marks for his performance in the talks last year between a coalition of leading opposition groups and the then-ruling Communist party. But other leaders have marred the image of the party, some of whom have vilified the liberal League of Free Democrats _ the party with the highest percentage of former anti-Communist dissidents _ as latter-day Bolsheviks. Forum deputy chairman Istvan Csurka even used radio time to make comments deemed anti-Semitic by his critics. The party emphatically disavows any anti-Jewish sentiments. It attributes much of the anti-Semitism in Hungary to the knowledge that many of the country's discredited former Communist leaders were Jewish.

DOC.HEAD: Another Season of Indian Spearfishing, Protest Starts in Wisconsin
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The ice is breaking on northern Wisconsin lakes, signaling the start of another tense spring when protesters head to boat landings to confront Indians who use spears to catch spawning fish. The first boats of Chippewa Indian spearfishers are expected to venture onto off-reservation waters tonight to exercise a right guaranteed by 19th century federal treaties. Despite pleas for peace, this spring's spearfishing season is expected to renew confrontations between the Chippewa and sport anglers, who claim spearfishing is an unfair, outdated practice that thins game fish populations. Observers are unsure whether tensions will escalate from a year ago, when more than 200 protesters were arrested and the state and local sheriff's departments spent nearly $2 million to patrol the lakes. Nick Hockings of the Wa-Swa-Gon Treaty Association, a group on the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa reservation that organizes spearfishing outings, thinks the crowds of anti-spearfishing protesters could be smaller, ``weeded out to your racists.'' As many as 1,000 members of the American Indian Movement planned to travel from Minnesota to northern Wisconsin lakes to support the Chippewa. Courts have ruled the Chippewa are entitled to take up to 100 percent of the safe harvest _ the number of fish that can be taken without harming future reproduction _ from each northern Wisconsin lake. But the Chippewa have agreed to limit their catch this year to 54 percent of the safe harvest, or about 41,410 walleyed pike on 178 lakes. The season usually lasts about three weeks. In 1989, 271 spearfishers caught 16,054 walleye. In comparison, Wisconsin's sport anglers take more than 10 times as many fish _ about 600,000 last year, according to the state Department of Natural Resources. The St. Croix Chippewa band plans to start the spearfishing season tonight in northwestern Wisconsin's Polk County, sending about 20 fishermen out, Tribal Vice Chairman Ed Bearheart said. The most active spearfishing band _ the Lac du Flambeau _ is planning its first excursion perhaps Saturday. Groups opposed to Indian spearfishing _ Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin and Protect Americans' Rights and Resources _ have said they would not begin anti-spearfishing protests before Sunday. Dean Crist, a spokesman for Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, said Monday that unless the Lac du Flambeau band agrees to spear only 10 percent of its allowable catch, his group will urge large-scale demonstrations at the lakes. ``It is no different than a soldier going to war,'' Crist said. ``Nobody in their right mind would like to stand out on a landing all night but it is the only thing that works.'' Putting protesters in boats to patrol the lakes where the Indians spearfished caused waves last year that made it difficult to see walleye, preventing tens of thousands of fish from being caught, he said. The spearfishing dispute is rooted in treaties the Chippewa signed when the tribe ceded millions of acres of northern Wisconsin to the U.S. government in the 1800s. Since 1983, federal courts have said the Chippewa retained the right to hunt, spearfish, cut timber and gather foods on off-reservation land in the ceded territory. The rulings are being appealed, but state officials, including Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, said it could take nearly a decade for lawsuits to move through the courts. Unlike their ancestors who used torches, modern-day spearfishers wear hats with battery-operated lights. A walleye, sluggish in the cold, shallow water, is stunned when it sees the light. Using iron spears, the Indians stab the fish from boats. Each spearfishing season has seen a gradual increase of tension and confrontations, but state officials predicted 1990 might bring a downturn. ``I think this will be a more peaceful season than in the past,'' said George Meyer, chief of enforcement for the state Department of Natural Resources. ``While I don't believe tribal spearfishermen will be lonely on boat landings, I believe there will be reduced tensions and levels of anti-treaty rights demonstrations. ... Many people understand the issue cannot be resolved at boat landings.''

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Faces Long Odds on Peace Dividend Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward Kennedy faces an uphill battle in his goal of turning the entire ``peace dividend'' over to domestic programs instead of the deficit, the House Democratic leader says. Kennedy, in a speech at Georgetown University on Monday, said billions of dollars cut from the defense budget should go not to reducing the federal deficit but to long-neglected programs such as education and health care. ``It is time to insist on what the American people and virtually everyone in Congress already know,'' Kennedy said. ``There really is a peace dividend and we must not throw it away.'' But House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Congress will almost certainly want to put some of the money saved by cuts in the defense budget toward deficit reduction and some toward reviving domestic programs. ``The likelihood is that we'll do both,'' Gephardt said in a telephone interview. ``They're both high priorities. Each is a part of rebuilding economic strength.'' Gephardt agreed with Kennedy that the peace dividend should be much larger than the Bush administration has proposed. According to Kennedy, as much as $170 billion in five years should be placed in a ``National Needs Trust Fund'' and spent only on ``critical'' domestic programs such as Head Start for preschool children; national health insurance for the roughly 37 million Americans with no coverage; and aid to communities and people dislocated by military plant closures. Kennedy chided his Democratic colleagues for letting President Bush control the national agenda and warned that unless the party became more active in its opposition, the party would retain its secondary status. ``There has been a kind of unnatural quiet coming from our party, a sense of yielding ground to the president, of kowtowing to his veto threats, of confining our own Democratic efforts to merely marginal improvements in Republican proposals, of almost conceding a second term to President Bush _ or hoping against hope that he stumbles somewhere along the way,'' Kennedy said. Hard-line Republican views on defense spending helped bring about the easing of U.S.-Soviet tensions and the spread of democracy in Eastern Europe, Kennedy conceded. But he said the turn of world events created an opportunity tailor-made for the Democratic Party. ``Seldom have a period and a party been so well matched,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Ninja Turtles' Counts $18.8 Million at Box Office
DOC.TEXT: Moviegoers shelled out $18.8 million at the nation's movie theaters to see ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' making the film No. 1 at the box office again. According to figures released Monday by Exhibitor Relations Co., ``Ninja Turtles'' has made more than $50 million after just two weeks. It's already the biggest money-maker yet for New Line Cinema. In second and showing few signs of fading was the comedy ``Pretty Woman,'' starring Richard Gere and Julia Roberts. The movie collected $11.3 million, and the Walt Disney Co. said the film is on a pace to equal the studio's 1987 hit ``Three Men and a Baby.'' In third was the new comedy ``Ernest Goes to Jail,'' featuring Jim Varney in the latest sequel about the annoying dimwit title character. The movie had ticket sales of $6.1 million, the best opening yet in the Ernest trilogy. The new adventure ``The First Power'' opened well, too, making $5.7 million in its first weekend of release. It was followed in fifth by ``The Hunt for Red October,'' which netted $5 million. ``I Love You to Death,'' a comedy about adultery and murder for hire, landed in sixth with a gate of $4 million. In seventh was the best-picture Oscar winner, ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' grossing $3.2 million. The latest effort from bizarre director John Waters, ``Cry Baby,'' opened in eighth place, collecting $3 million. It was followed in ninth by the Dana Carvey comedy ``Opportunity Knocks'' with ticket sales of $2.1 million. Rounding out the Top 10 was ``Joe Versus the Volcano'' on receipts of $1.5 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $18.8 million, 2,226 screens, $8,452 per screen, $51 million, two weeks. 2. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $11.3 million, 1,707 screens, $6,602 per screen, $44.3 million, three weeks. 3. ``Ernest Goes to Jail,'' Disney, $6.1 million, 1,943 screens, $3,162 per screen, $6.1 million, one week. 4. ``The First Power,'' Orion, $5.7 million, 1,332 screens, $4,263 per screen, $5.7 million, one week. 5. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $5 million, 1,765 screens, $2,846 per screen, $83.6 million, six weeks. 6. ``I Love You to Death,'' Tri-Star, $4 million, 1,072 screens, $3,745 per screen, $4 million, one week. 7. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $3.2 million, 1,528 screens, $2,101 per screen, $86.9 million, 17 weeks. 8. ``Cry Baby,'' Universal, $3 million, 1,229 screens, $2,445 per screen, $3 million, one week. 9. ``Opportunity Knocks,'' Universal., $2.1 million, 1,275 screens, $1,645 per screen, $6.4 million, two weeks. 10. ``Joe Versus the Volcano,'' Warner Bros., $1.5 million, 1,085 screens, $1,360 per screen, $33 million, five weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Who is Running Eastern Europe?
With PM-Hungary-Forum
DOC.TEXT: A brief glance at who is running the countries in Eastern Europe:

ALBANIA: Thew last bastion of Stalinist rule in what used to be Communist Eastern Europe has rejected the democratic reforms that have swept the region. The Communist leadership, which broke with Moscow in the 1960s, has made clear it has no intention of relinquishing its leading role or staging free elections. Chairman (nominal head of state): Ramiz Alia, Communist. Premier: Adil Carcani, Communist. Cabinet includes 24 members, all believed to be Communists.

BULGARIA: The Balkan country of 9 million plans to hold its first multiparty elections since World War II on June 10 and June 17 under terms worked out between the ruling Communists _ renamed the Socialists this month _ and opposition parties and groups. President: Petar Mladenov, unaffiliated, officially no longer with the Socialist party. Premier: Andrei Lukanov, now Socialist. Parliament has some 400 members, 75 percent of whom are former Communists turned Socialists. Parliament is in a state of dissolution pending the June elections.

CZECHOSLOVAKIA: Multiparty elections are scheduled for June 8-9 for the 350-member Parliament. On Dec. 29, the current Parliament elected former dissident playwright Vaclav Havel president to replace Communist hard-liner Gustav Husak, who resigned in the wake of the November ``velvet'' revolution. Also in December, Parliament elected Alexander Dubcek, the disgraced leader of the 1968 Prague Spring reforms that were crushed by Soviet troops, speaker of Parliament. Premier: Marian Calfa, former Communist who resigned from the party and is currently unaffiliated. Cabinet: Twenty-three members, including 3 Communists. Parliament has 350 members, less than half of them Communists.

EAST GERMANY: The first free elections in East Germany's 41 years were held March 18. An alliance of conservative parties favoring quick reunification with West Germany won 48 percent of the vote for 193 seats in the 400-seat Parliament and began negotiating to form a coalition. Christian Democrat leader Lothar de Maiziere was charged by Parliament to form a new government. He is building a broad coalition with the Social Democrats, which will enable him to must the two-thirds majority needed to make the constitutional changes required for unification. A Cabinet is expected to be presented for approval when Parliament meets on Thursday.

HUNGARY: Hungarians voting in the country's first free elections in 43 years _ on March 25 and in runoffs on Sunday _ gave the greatest support to the conservative Democratic Forum, headed by Jozsef Antall. His party won 165 seats, according to unofficial results, and was likely to form a center-right coalition with like-minded parties. Antall said he expects the coalition talks to take up to a month. The caretaker government is comprised of Socialists _ reformed Communists who formed the new party in line with their support of democracy. Premier: Miklos Nemeth, who also secured a seat in the new Parliament. Interim President: Matyas Szueroes.

POLAND: The once-banned Solidarity Free Trade Union won overwhelmingly over the Communist party in partially democratic elections last June that were agreed upon at historic negotiations between the trade union and Communist leadership. In September, Solidarity formed the first government in Eastern Europe not dominated by Communists, under Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a Solidarity activist and journalist. Following the trend begun in Hungary, the old Communist Party dissolved itself in Jaunary and a new Social Democracy Party was formed. The 23-member Cabinet includes 12 Solidarity members, the others are former members of the now-dissolved Communist party or of the Peasant Party and the Democratic Party. President: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, a now unaffiliated former Communist elected by Parliament in July for a six-year term. His is a more ceremonial post than Mazowiecki's. Fully free Senate elections and partially free Sejm (lower house) elections were held in June and next elections are not due until 1993, although they could be moved up when the constitution is rewritten this year. The Senate has 99 senators from Solidarity and one independent. Since the Communist Party was dissolved, in the 460-seat Sejm the former Communists have either joined other parties or are unaffiliated.

ROMANIA: Free, multiparty elections have been scheduled by the interim revolutionary government for May 20. They will be the first since 1937. The elections will be for a 387-member Parliament. Romania's former ruling Communist party dissolved after the December revolution that toppled and executed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu after a summary trial. Premier: Petre Roman, a former Communist and now member of the ruling National Salvation Front. Interim President: Ion Iliescu, a former Communist. Cabinet includes 30 members, none Communist.

YUGOSLAVIA: The first multiparty elections in non-aligned Yugoslavia's 45-year Communist history took place in the republic of Slovenia on Sunday. Slovenia will get its first freely elected president in a runoff between a reformed Communist _ Milan Kucan _ and a secessionist and former political prisoner _ Joze Pucnik, first-round election results show. The two will face each other in a runoff election on April 22. The reformist federal government of Premier Ante Markovic, a Communist, has put forward a bill that will legalize a multiparty system in the country but there is resistance from the hard-line Communists who run Serbia, the largest of the country's six republics. President: Janez Drnovsek, Communist.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim Ryan White Remembered as Teacher, Student
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Arcadia, Fla., in last graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The flag flew at half-staff outside of a high school where AIDS victim Ryan White was remembered as a model student, and those who once fought to keep him out of school mourned his absence. Students and administrators at Hamilton Heights High School wore orange ribbons, mementoes of school pride, and began the day with a 10-minute convocation in memory of White, who found friendship and acceptance here after a long legal battle to attend public school. ``I've said many times, as a teen-ager his age I probably would have stayed home instead of coming to school every day,'' Principal Steve Dillon said during an inpromptu news conference. ``He very much wanted to be at school. He was very much a fighter. ``And I think every one of our lives is going to be a lot better for knowing Ryan and participating in his last three years.'' White, a junior, attended classes as recently as two weeks before his death Sunday, 10 days after he was admitted to an Indianapolis hospital with an AIDS-related respiratory infection. He was diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome 5{ years ago, having contracted the disease from blood products to treat his hemophilia. The teen-ager attracted national attention during his successful fight to attend school in his hometown of Kokomo and emerged as an international spokesman for children suffering from AIDS. He is credited with furthering understanding of the disease, its devastating effects and the rights of its sufferers. After White won his court battle to attend school in Kokomo, he and his family still felt uncomfortable there and moved to Cicero, about 20 miles away, in 1987. His death elicited sympathy in his former hometown. ``It's a terrible thing. I'd hoped from the beginning he could have been the first to whip it,'' said Dan Carter, who was board president at Western School Corp. when Ryan was banned from classes there. ``He was a real educator for all of us and he showed a lot of class,'' said Kokomo Mayor Robert Sargent. His contribution to AIDS awareness was remembered Monday night with a candlelight vigil in downtown Indianapolis attended by about 50 people. ``He was brave, he brought people's awareness alive,'' said Kevin Johnson, an AIDS organization volunteer who attended the vigil and whose best friend has the disease. ``I think Ryan made a big difference.'' A funeral was planned for Wednesday. Dillon said he expected half of his school's 550 students and several staff members would attend the funeral. Some of White's closest friends sought consolation Monday from school counselors, Dillon said. ``I'm very pleased with the student body today. They're handling it very well. We wanted to make sure they felt good about themselves,'' Dillon said. He said the White's classmates should be proud that he ``could attend school and have friends and go to dances and go to the ballgames and not worry about any problems. He was very much a part of our school body.'' White's death was particularly hard to take for three young Florida brothers suffering from AIDS who also fought to attend school, their mother said. Louise Ray said her hemophiliac sons Ricky, 13, Robert, 12, and Randy, 10, had met White, and his death reminded them of the gravity of their own illnesses. ``It's a senseless death, in a way,'' she said. ``The boys are going to miss him, and at this age it's hard for them to understand why a young person has to die.'' The brothers won a federal court order to attend school in Arcadia, Fla., in 1987, but fire destroyed their home soon afterward and the family fled to Sarasota, where they enrolled in school without incident.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Cards to the White family can be sent to P.O. Box 40, Noblesville, Ind. 46060.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Jet, Plane Collide; Two Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The collision ...' to CORRECT Cessna involved to single-engine plane, sted twin-engine. Pick up 4th graf, `The two ...'
DOC.TEXT: A commuter jet that had just taken off collided with a smaller plane Monday evening, killing the two people aboard the smaller aircraft, authorities said. The pilot of the Atlantic Southeast Airlines jet, a Brazilian-made Embraer, returned safely to Gadsden Municipal Airport with his four passengers. The collision occurred around 6 p.m. shortly after the jet left the northeastern Alabama airport for Atlanta, said Arlene Salac, a Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman in Atlanta. The jet and the single-engine Cessna 182 collided at an altitude of 2,100 feet and about three miles southwest of the airport. The two Civil Air Patrol pilots aboard the Cessna were killed, said airport manager Fred Anderton. There were no injuries aboard the commuter jet, whose tail was damaged in the crash. ``It looks like the ASA was flying out of Gadsden and was only up to 2,100 feet when this little Cessna ... must have came in out of the blue,'' Ms. Salac said. ``It sounded like a cannon shot when it hit,'' said Bob Cote of Counce, Tenn., a passenger in the commuter jet. ``They never saw the small plane.'' On Nov. 5, four people died when two planes collided about 300 feet above the Gadsden airport, which does not have a control tower. Gadsden is about 50 miles northeast of Birmingham.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,624.68, down 773.25 points, or 2.54 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Compares Lithuania To Lincoln's Battle Against Secession
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet official is comparing Moscow's opposition to Lithuanian independence to Abraham Lincoln's fight to prevent the South from seceding. Yuri A. Reshteov, head of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's department for international humanitarian cooperation and human rights, told a news conference he visited Washington's Lincoln Memorial on Sunday. The Civil War president, ``in his second inaugural address in 1865, said that he is fighting against the forces which are seeking to dissolve the Union. Abraham Lincoln saved the American Union,'' Reshteov said Monday. ``We have been together with Lithuania, with Estonia and with Latvia for many, many years,'' he said. ``I still hope that what unites us is much stronger than what is capable of leading to dissolution of our union.'' Reshteov said Lithuania's fate should be decided by a popular vote, rather than by the March 11 declaration by the parliament in Vilnius rejecting the 1940 Soviet annexation. Stasys Lozoraitis Jr., charge d'affaires of the Lithuanian legation in Washington, responded at a separate news conference that since the Western Powers have never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania ``the international law that should be applied is that the Soviets should withdraw.'' A majority of Lithuanians favor independence, Lozoraitis said, but a referendum would be ``a trap'' for neighboring Estonia and Latvia, where sizable minorities oppose independence.
DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Auto Parts Firm to Pay $1.5 Million OSHA Fine
DOC.TEXT: A Philadelphia auto parts manufacturer has agreed to pay a $1.5 million fine for violating government noise standards on the job, the Labor Department says. The settlement between the Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the Budd Co., announced Monday, also requires the firm to improve record-keeping and protect employees from excessive noise. Last December, OSHA proposed Budd Co. be fined $3.3 million for more than 840 alleged violations at its Philadelphia plant, including failure to tell some workers that tests showed their hearing was deteriorating. Government regulatory agencies frequently reduce proposed fines after negotiating with alleged violators. Budd, which makes doors, lift gates and other body stampings for motor vehicles, has about 2,400 people working at the plant. The Troy, Mich.-based company is a subsidiary of the West Germany's Thyssen Industries and has plants in Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Tennessee. Under the settlement, the company will monitor noise and test employees to identify all workers exposed above a certain noise level. The workers will be notified of the results and trained to use hearing protectors, the Labor Department said. In addition, the company has agreed to reduce noise at its Philadelphia plant through engineering controls and repair and maintenance of equipment.
DOC.HEAD: Petroleum Industry Adopts Environmental Goals
DOC.TEXT: The trade association representing the nation's major oil companies has adopted a set of ``guiding environmental principles,'' but an environmentalist says they sound like hollow promises. The American Petroleum Institute's board of directors, which includes all of the nation's major petroleum companies, adopted the environmental principles Friday in Dallas. The principles, unveiled Monday, include pledges that the industry would promote the safe use, transportation and disposal of raw materials; address problems created by the handling and disposal of hazardous substances from oil operations; and operate plants and facilities in a way that protects the environment and the safety and health of employees and the public. ``The commitments are so vague as to be practically meaningless,'' said Bob Adler, senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said Monday. ``It sounds like hollow promises, especially coming from an industry that has violated not only government regulations but its own promises time and time again.'' Adler said the industry appears to be seeking to replace ``badly needed'' enforceable government regulations with more unenforceable industry promises.

DOC.HEAD: John Henry Faulk, Humorist and First Amendment Champion, Dead at 76
DOC.TEXT: Humorist-folklorist John Henry Faulk, who faced blacklisting head-on with a lawsuit in the 1950s and became a champion of civil rights, has died after a long bout with cancer. He was 76. The Austin-born author and lecturer, whose objections effectively ended blacklisting in the entertainment industry, died Monday at his Austin home, said his niece, Anne McAffee. Faulk was a popular CBS radio and television personality when, in 1957, he mounted a six-year legal battle in a New York court against an organization that tried to brand him a subversive. He recounted the struggle in a best-selling book, ``Fear on Trial.'' The book was made into a made-for-TV movie that was broadcast on CBS in 1975. Faulk often said he never expected the First Amendment to become pivotal in his life. ``I never had the slightest inkling that I would ever be embattled in invoking its protections,'' he said. ``It's the main nerve center of our entire self-governing democratic society.'' Faulk studied and taught at the University of Texas before joining the merchant marine during World War II. He also worked for the American Red Cross in the Middle East. Despite eye trouble, he was able to join the Army in 1944. While on Christmas leave in 1945, Faulk was approached by executives from CBS, who had heard him perform and were impressed with his character sketches and interpretations of folk humor. The network signed him in 1946 to do a weekly, one-hour radio show. He worked for CBS until 1957, when he was fired after AWARE Inc., a group that blacklisted entertainment personalities, accused him the year before of having subversive associations. Faulk sued AWARE in 1956, charging the group had libeled him and destroyed his career. He won the lawsuit and was awarded $3.5 million, but the judgment was later reduced to $725,000 on appeal. The 1962 trial brought an end to blacklisting.
