DOC.TEXT: Questions involving property taxes and the environment are on Bay Area ballots today along with a transsexual mayoral contender who wants pink lifeboats for residents and a candidate who faces an arson trial. Terri Pohrman, a 37-year-old ex-female impersonator who had a sex-change operation in 1970, is running for mayor of Yountville, a conservative Napa Valley town about 40 miles northeast of San Francisco. ``Miss Terri,'' as Pohrman is known, campaigned hard among 1,200 residents of the California Veterans' Home, where they love her exuberant performances in high heels and sequined cocktail dresses with plunging necklines. Pohrman, a former boutique operator, promises to bring more levity to the leadership at City Hall. Now working as a traveling saleswoman, Pohrman has pledged to buy Yountville's 3,200 residents pink lifeboats to protect them from floods, such as one that left dozens homeless three years ago when the Napa River overflowed. Pohrman says sexuality should not influence her race against Mayor Pro-tem Carlee Leftwich and former Councilman Aaron Mosley. They agree, but maintain that their city government experience gives them an edge. San Leandro Mayor David Karp is running against John Vaccaro, who operates a warehouse surplus supply company and faces retrial in Santa Barbara on arson charges six days after the election. The case involves a 1986 fire that authorities have charged was an insurance-fraud scheme. A 1987 trial ended with a jury deadlocked 11-1 for conviction of Vaccaro and a co-defendant. In Hayward, voters will decide whether to allow a 1,927-home development on scenic Walpert Ridge above California State University at Hayward. Environmentalists have lobbied against the Hayward 1990 project, complaining it will increase traffic congestion and pollution. Supporters argue the development will help improve the city's image as a place where people live, not just a jungle of freeways and thoroughfares. Voters in Marin County, Newark, Antioch and Los Gatos will be asked to raise between $1.7 million and $16 million for their local public schools through property tax hikes dubbed ``Measure A'' on all the various local ballots.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seize 25 Pounds of Heroin in West German Tour Bus
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested a West German tour bus driver today after seizing 25.9 pounds of heroin hidden in the air conditioning system of his bus, authorities said. The seizure resulted from an anti-drug operation carried out in cooperation with Dutch and West German police, said a Civil Guard spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Authorities did not identify the 47-year-old driver. The Civil Guard spokesman said an international heroin trafficking ring based in West Germany and Holland has been using tour buses to smuggle drugs into Spain, particularly during holidays such as Easter. In another development, Civil Guard customs officers at Madrid's Barajas Airport reported seizing 11.4 pounds of heroin Saturday, which was found hidden under a panel in the suitcase of a Swiss man who had arrived on a flight from Zurich. The man's identity was not made public.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Dampen Pre-Passover Ritual
DOC.TEXT: When a group of Hasidic Jews set fire to bread in a Passover eve ritual on a Brooklyn street, firefighters rode up and doused the flames. The Satmar sect Hasidim, prayer books in hand, protested, but to no avail. John Mulligan, a fire department spokesman, said the firefighters were right to hose down the burning loaves. ``Generally our custom is to permit small fires _ but when they become dangerous we must put them out,'' the New York Post quoted Mulligan as saying. Observant Jews burn bread before Passover to symbolize that their homes are free of prohibited food during the the eight-day holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Texas; Tornadoes in Kansas, Oklahoma
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with thunderstorms in Texas, tornadoes in Oklahoma; picks up 5th graf, `The high ...
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms lashed north Texas today with hail and high winds, while snow fell in central North Dakota and Montana and rain dampened parts of the Midwest. Tornadoes churned across portions of Kansas and Oklahoma on Monday and early today, and the National Weather Service issued a tornado watch for much of north-central Texas. Rain fell in Missouri, Michigan and Ohio. Bismarck, N.D., and Great Falls, Mont., received snow. On Monday, parts of Wyoming, Kansas, Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas were hit by rainstorms. Rain also fell in northern Missouri, Iowa, southern Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, southern Michigan, southern Florida and central Vermont. In Kansas, a tornado touched down near Sedgwick, and hail more than 2 inches in diameter fell east of Halstead. In Oklahoma, a tornado cut a swath from Lone Grove to Ardmore late Monday and early today, damaging about 10 houses, five mobile homes and landing a barn in the middle of a city street. At least five people were reported injured. In Texas, hail near golfball size was reported in Gainesville about 1:25 a.m., with winds up to 60 mph tearing roofs from several homes and breaking windows, the weather service said. High winds also destroyed a greenhouse and some equipment at a department store, said Gainesville authorities. One-inch hail fell at Agnes, six miles west of Springtown, at 3:40 a.m. The high temperature Monday in the Lower 48 states was 93 degrees at Palm Springs and Thermal, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Hostage Release Gives Spark of Hope To British Hostages' Families
With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Friends and relatives of Britons held in Lebanon welcomed today's release in Beirut of a French woman, her Belgian boyfriend and their daughter, but doubted it meant their loved ones will soon be freed. Four Britons are believed held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon _ journalist John McCarthy, retired pilot Jack Mann, and Terry Waite, the envoy of the archbishop of Canterbury. Missing teacher Brian Keenan has Irish and British citizenship. ``The release of hostages of any nationality by any group is always very welcome news,'' said a spokesman for Archbishop Robert Runcie. ``But the captors in this case are quite different to those holding the British hostages in Lebanon, so their release brings little direct comfort to the families of the British hostages beyond the hope that it might loosen up the situation of hostages in Lebanon generally.'' The three hostages set free today had been held by Abu Nidal's radical Palestinian group Fatah-Revolutionary Council. The Britons are believed to be held by Islamic Jihad, an umbrella organization for pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems in Lebanon. John Waite, cousin of Terry Waite, said: ``It's great, and we are delighted that these three have been freed. It's wonderful and we send them our love. It's also a great boost that somebody has been released.'' He said that because the Britons were held by a different group, ``I don't think it means we are going to see the release of any of our loved ones as a result of this.'' ``But I hope that it shows things are cooling down a little and that people are realizing that hostages have got to be released because they get nobody anywhere,'' he said. Chris Pearson, president of the group Friends of John McCarthy, said: ``Given the nature of their kidnapping _ that they were taken by the Abu Nidal group _ it probably has little effect on the British hostages in Beirut. ``I don't think it means the Western hostages in Beirut are any nearer release. But if the suggestion is that there is a more hopeful mood in the Lebanon then we would be a little bit encouraged.'' Waite was captured while negotiating the release of hostages with Islamic Jihad in January 1987. McCarthy, a journalist with London-based Worldwide Television News, and Keenan were seized in April 1986. Mann was taken hostage last May.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Declare Commitment To Free-Market Style Economic Reforms
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today welcomed a new international accord committing it to free-market oriented economic reforms, but pressed the West to loosen its restrictions on high-technology exports. Stepan Sitarian, a deputy premier, praised a document that was endorsed Monday by the Soviet Union and 34 other nations attending a major economic conference in the West German capital. ``Many of the decisions and recommendations contained in the Bonn document are in line with our philosophy of perestroika and have a direct bearing on the economic renewal in the Soviet Union,'' Sitarian said as the 35-nation Conference on Economic Cooperation in Europe winded down. On Monday, the 35 nations participating at the Bonn conference _ all the European countries except Albania plus the United States and Canada _ informally endorsed a document committing them to back private property, free enterprise and multiparty democracy. Such a move would have been unthinkable only months ago, but it was made possible by the wave of democratic and economic reforms sweeping across Eastern Europe. Sitarian also pressed for East-West talks on loosening up the so-called COCOM restrictions on sales of Western technology to the East bloc. ``COCOM should no longer remain a sacred cow,'' he said. ``We propose that East-West consultations begin on rules to govern the transfer of dual-purpose technology,'' said Sitarian, referring to technology that can be used for both military and civilian purposes. COCOM stands for the 17-nation Coordinating Committee For Multilateral Export Controls. The COCOM nations are working on proposals for loosening restrictions on technology sales to reforming Eastern European countries. However, the United States has indicated it will take a tougher stand on technology sales to the Soviet Union. Sitarian said Moscow considered the Bonn meeting ``a major milestone'' in the process of intensified East-West cooperation that began with the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in 1975. He said ``we seek to integrate ourselves into the world economy in a dynamic fashion and on a large scale'' and added the Soviets want an ``open type of economy.'' He also said changes at home and abroad ``bring us closer to a key objective, namely the convertibility of the ruble,'' but he did not elaborate. Economic experts from the 35 nations have been meeting in Bonn since March 19 to examine ways of improving East-West cooperation and helping with the reconstruction of Eastern Europe. The Bonn conference ends on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Fires Editors for Off-Duty Anti-Abortion Activity
DOC.TEXT: Two editors active in anti-abortion groups were fired for violating a small daily newspaper's policy against employees serving as officers of politically active groups that receive news coverage. ``That's two out of a staff of four reporters, that's half my staff,'' The Fairfield Ledger's Editor Jan Nierling said today. The two were fired Monday after refusing to resign their positions as secretary and president of the recently formed Southeast Iowa Pro-lifers, Nierling said. ``We take our role as a newspaper very seriously and we believe that their activities jeopardize our credibility as impartial observers,'' said Ms. Nierling. She said News Editor John Kennedy and People Page Editor Terri Lambertsen both were given the opportunity to resign their positions in the anti-abortion group, but refused. Kennedy was secretary and Lambertsen was president. ``They said you can think it over tonight and either get out of the group or quit your job,'' said Kennedy, an eight-year employee of the newspaper. ``I said I didn't need to think about it, and they fired me.'' Ms. Lambertsen said she was warned March 30 to give up her anti-abortion activities or risk losing her job. The newspaper didn't know about Kennedy's involvement until Monday, Ms. Nierling said. The independently owned paper was established in 1849 in this southeast Iowa city of about 10,000. It has a daily circulation of about 5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Legality of FBI Purchase of AIM Leader's Photos
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has upheld the legality of an FBI agent's getting a photo shop to sell him copies of snapshots taken by American Indian Movement leader Vernon Bellecourt. A three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals refused Monday to overturn a lower federal court's ruling that dismissed the suit. C. Peter Erlinder, Bellecourt's attorney, said he plans to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to review the case, or request that the entire court in the 8th Circuit rehear it. The appeals panel ruled that Bellecourt had given up his right to privacy when he dropped his film off at a shop in Minneapolis that had a processing machine located next to a glass wall. The transparent wall allowed anyone to observe the photos briefly as they were being printed at the F-Stop One Hour Photo Store. A clerk at the store agreed to sell a duplicate set of pictures to an FBI agent who had been trailing Bellecourt. The clerk later told the Indian leader about the duplicate photos, and Bellecourt sued the FBI. The appeals panel ruled that Bellecourt's use of the F-Stop for photo processing exposed his photographs to the public sufficiently to defeat his claim to Fourth Amendment privacy protection. ``With this ruling it appears there are a lot of places that people go to in their everyday lives that now are potential government information pickup points,'' Erlinder said. Bellecourt has charged that the FBI's action was harassment aimed at him because of his involvement in Central American politics. The photos, Bellecourt said, included pictures taken when he attended the First Congress of Indian Organizations in Panama City, Panama, in March 1989. Bellecourt said he feared that the FBI or CIA would circulate pictures of congress participants who could later become targets of death squads in Central America. Bellecourt said he will appeal the decision. He said he believes the ruling is a threat to everyone's privacy, and may open the way for federal agents to seize written material, such as copies being made at a photocopying shop. ``I think it's very dangerous, and must be seen as an erosion of our Fourth Amendment rights,'' he said. The judges on the appeals panel were John R. Gibson, George G. Fagg and Pasco M. Bowman.

DOC.HEAD: Police Canine Officers' Lawsuit Puts Bite in Back-Pay Complaint
DOC.TEXT: City police dogs may land in kennels because of a lawsuit by officers who claim providing free after-hours care for their four-legged co-workers is a dog's life. ``We're looking at other ways to cut costs,'' police spokeswoman Tina Vicini said Monday. ``There's nothing definite yet.'' About 70 officers are suing the city for more than $1 million in back pay they claim they are owed for three years under the Fair Labor Standards Act for taking care of dogs in their department. ``Federal laws are passed for everybody, and the city of Chicago is not immune,'' said John Dineen, president of the Fraternal Order of Police, which filed the lawsuit in U.S. District Court. Since the police dog unit started 29 years ago, the city has saved money by having the canine officers take their partners home after a day's work. The city provides small backyard kennels and pays for dog food and the use of police station wagons. But the city does not pay the officers for the time they spend taking care of the dogs. ``I have to walk Rocky, give him baths, brush him and a lot more,'' said Patrol Officer Walter Tamberlin. ``It comes to about an hour and a half beyond my regular shifts. We even take care of them after they've retired.'' The city maintains the officers have the perquisite of having a pet without the costs. ``The vet bills are paid. Plus they have a watch dog on the premises. Now, they want to get paid for feeding the dog,'' Miss Vicini said. A similar lawsuit in Detroit was settled by awarding officers 45 minutes of overtime a day, totaling about $4,000 a year, said a Detroit police spokesman. Stephen Feinberg, an attorney for the Chicago officers, said the city's policy clearly violates the dictates of the Fair Labor Standards Act, which has applied to municipal employees since 1986. ``They are providing a service for the city,'' said Feinberg. ``The city would not be able to kennel the dogs for free.'' Miss Vicini would not comment about how much the city saves by having the dogs stay with their handlers.

DOC.HEAD: Plan to Destroy 150,000 Pigs to Combat Swine Plague In Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Angry farmers blocked highways in four towns for a second day today to stop officials from destroying 150,000 pigs to combat an outbreak of swine plague. The farmers complain that the preventive killing of healthy pigs will bankrupt them. Officials said the government was considering suspending enforcement of the order in the four towns to prevent the removal of the pigs. Over the weekend, the government ordered all pigs destroyed within a half-mile radius around farms that have been hit by the contagious disease since March 15. It promised to refund farmers the full price of the destroyed pigs but the offer was termed insufficient by farmers who say the cost to restart from scratch is much higher. The measure affects some 200 pig farms in the provinces of West and East Flanders, in Belgium's Dutch-speaking northern half. The government's action has sparked farmer protests from the beginning. The mayors of farming towns have barred the transportation of pigs to slaughterhouses, arguing it ``disturbed the public peace.'' The Belgian measure affects 150,000 pigs. The European Community has offered to refund farmers for the voluntary killing of another 380,000 animals in areas beyond those of the Belgian program. If fully carried out, the EC eradication program, due to start on Thursday, will cost an estimated $16.9 million. The swine plague started in mid-January and is still running out of control, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Plane Collides With Cessna, Two Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits thruout to CORRECT type of plane to turbo-prop sted jet, UPDATE with identities of dead; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A commuter plane with seven people aboard landed safely at Gadsden Municipal Airport after a collision with a smaller plane that killed two other people, authorities said. The Atlantic Southeast Airlines plane was en route to Atlanta when the crash with a single-engine Cessna 172 Skyhawk occurred Monday at an altitude of 2,100 feet, said Arlene Salac, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta. The smaller plane, with two Civil Air Patrol pilots aboard, plunged into a field after the collision, which occurred about three miles southwest of Gadsden. Both pilots died. They were identified as Thomas Frondorf, 59, of Ashville, and Marvin Charles Moffett, 46, of Southside. The tail section of the larger craft, a Brazilian-made Embraer turbo-prop, was damaged in the collision, but it landed safely, said Fred Anderton Jr., manager of the airport in this city about 50 miles northeast of Birmingham. ``I don't know how he ever got it down. Part of the tail was torn off,'' Anderton said. ``The pilot, to control an aircraft with that amount of control surface torn from the aircraft, did a remarkable job.'' The turbo-prop had three crew members and four passengers. Bob Cote of Counce, Tenn., who was one of the passengers, said he heard a loud bang. ``It sounded like a cannon shot when it hit,'' he said. Witness Vernon Stephenson of Gadsden said the Cessna was flying west into the sun when it collided with the ASA plane, which was traveling east. ``It went straight down, spinning,'' Stephenson said. Sam Watts, vice president of customer services for ASA, said the names of commuter line's crew members were being withheld during an investigation of the collision. On Nov. 5, four people died when two planes collided about 300 feet above the intersecting runways at the Gadsden airport, which does not have a control tower.

DOC.HEAD: Report Urges Radical Action to Avoid Near Standstill of Air Travel
DOC.TEXT: Growing congestion could bring air travel in Western Europe to a ``near standstill'' within the next 10 years unless air space management is radically reorganized, a report released today warned. The congestion has already caused serious problems, said the report, which was prepared for the International Air Transport Association, or IATA. One out of every four flights was delayed by more than 15 minutes last year, costing the industry about $5 billion for additional fuel and other expenses, it said. With European air traffic expected to double to 500 million passengers by the year 2000 and to triple by 2010, present capacity of the transport system ``will be unable to cope with increases in air travel past 1995,'' it said. The report, which has been sent to all governments concerned, is based on a one-year study conducted by IATA and compiled by SRI International, the U.S. based consulting firm. ``Of the three major airport areas _ London, Frankfurt, and Paris _ only Paris has excess capacity,'' it said. ``No solution is seen for Frankfurt's capacity shortfall. Passenger growth at the three London area airports will exceed terminal capacity by the mid-1990's, and aircraft movement will exceed runway capacity by the year 2004.'' Without enhancement, 16 West European airports `` will be unable to accommodate air traffic demand in the year 2000, according to a summary of runway capacities included in the report. In the order of seriousness, those airports include Madrid, Frankfurt, London-Gatwick, London-Heathrow, Barcelona, Milan-Linate, Duesseldorf, Dublin, Stockholm, Athens, Palma de Mallorca, Geneva, Manchester, Marseille, Copenhagen and Hamburg. The report said by implementing potential improvements most airports could meet the demand forecast. But it stressed that this would require overcoming ``political, environmental and financial obstacles.'' IATA Director General Guenter Eser, who presented the report, agreed at a news conference that fighting environmental concerns will be an uphill battle. Commenting on the airspace situation, the report said one of the most serious problems is the increasing complexity of an air traffic control system that has to cope with a steadily increasing number of aircraft. It also pointed to the fast growing numer of airway intersections and called for the creation of new routes to minimize such crossing traffic. The necessary drastic restructuring should include sectors reserved up top now for military use, the report stressed. ``A radical reorganization of the way in which West European airspace is urgent and essential if the region's air transport system is not to be brought to a near standstill in the late 1990's because of congestion,'' it summed up. It called for an early international conference of all governments, airlines and international aviation organizations, including IATA, which groups 190 airlines, including all of the world's major carriers. Such a conference, the report said, should ``discuss ways and means of tackling the problem before it is too late.'' Eser said the recent political changes in Eastern Europe and the resulting improved East-West relations would make the carriers gain ``a lot'' of additiona airspace. He noted that almost the entire area along the border between East and West Germany is closed to commercial traffic. Norman Jackson, head of IATA's technical division, said that in contacts with military air control authorities during the past 18 months ``we have seen quite an effort on their part ... to help us. We have had access to military air space to which we had no access before.''

DOC.HEAD: Landsbergis Appeals To Gorbachev, Who Softens Language
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Landsbergis plea, Gorbachev comment. Pickup 8th graf `Gorbachev has...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM and CONFORM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis today appealed to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev not to carry out threatened political and economic measures against his independence-minded Baltic republic. Gorbachev seemed to soften his stance today, saying he would impose direct presidential rule in Lithuania only as an extreme measure and that a political solution was still being sought. The statements came on the eve of the one-month anniversary of Lithuania's declaration of independence and one day after Gorbachev and his Presidential Council warned of unspecified ``political and economic'' measures if the declaration was not rescinded. Lithuania said last week it would not repeal the March 11 declaration as a condition for negotiations with the Kremlin, which so far has taken limited steps to maintain control over the republic. Landsbergis sent a telegram today to Gorbachev, addressing him as ``esteemed president.'' ``We are very concerned that ultra-rightist imperial forces are compelling you to take a wrong step: to continue the wrongs of the 1940s in the Baltics,'' the telegram continued. ``Do not further this, please; in the name of peace, justice and concord on Earth, do not do this.'' Lithuania was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with the other Baltic republics: Estonia and Latvia, which have declared their intention to seek independence but are proceeding more cautiously than Lithuania. At a meeting today with delegates to a conference of young Communists, Gorbachev described the Lithuanian parliament's March 11 action as an ``adventure'' but also said he did not regard the situation as irreversible, the official Tass news agency reported. While he did not rule out the possibility of introducing presidential rule in the republic, he said he would do so only as an extreme measure if the situation develops into civil conflict, Tass reported. He also said Moscow was trying to find a political solution to the problem. Gorbachev has ordered Lithuanians to surrender their firearms and warned the republic not to form border patrols. Soviet troops have arrested some Lithuanians who deserted the Red Army and they have also occupied several public buildings in the republic. After a meeting last week between Lithuanian representatives and a major Gorbachev adviser, Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev, however, both sides made conciliatory statements. But on Sunday, Lithuanians prevented hundreds of Soviet soldiers from entering a plant that prints pro-independence newspapers. Pro-Moscow Communists had ordered the plant closed. The republic also told its young men who will be called up in the Soviet draft this spring that it is up to them whether they want to serve. In Moscow, lawmakers opposing Lithuania's independence drive asked Gorbachev to dissolve the Lithuanian legislature and reiterated its demand for direct presidential rule over the republic. In Estonia on Monday, leaders said they send draft responses to Gorbachev's criticism of their bid for independence to legislative committees for debate, a local journalist said on condition of anonymity. Estonia has said Soviet rule in the republic constitutes occupation of an independent country. The Baltic stte voted to re-establish independence after a still-undefined transition period. Gorbachev has demanded Estonia back down. And in Latvia, the new Communist Party chief, Alfreds Rubiks, asked members not to follow Lithuanians and Estonians by establishing an independent party. At a party congress over the weekend, most delegates voted to keep party ties with Moscow. The minority wants an independent Communist Party and moved to establish it this month. Anatolijs Gorbunovs, president of Latvia's Parliament said Monday that he is certain Latvian legislators will vote to secede from the Soviet Union when they meet next month.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Flock to Launch of Discovery and Space Telescope
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with launch scrubbed. Picks up 4th graf, `It's a ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``Do you remember what it was like when you were 5 years old and it was Christmas Eve?'' asked astronomer Phillippe Crane Jr., explaining why he was so excited to be at Kennedy Space Center. Today was the day when the Hubble Space Telescope was to ride into space aboard space shuttle Discovery. And Crane of the European Southern Observatory in Munich, Germany, was one of hundreds of astronomers who wanted to be here for the big event. They were left disappointed, however, when the launch was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff because of a problem with an Auxiliary Power Unit. Once the telescope goes into orbit, it is expected to revolutionize astronomy. ``It's a mixture of all the emotions _ excitement, nervousness, belief and disbelief,'' Princeton professor Edward L. Groth III said Monday. Both astronomers, who have been involved with the Hubble project since 1977, study galaxies. ``How did galaxies form? How did we all get here?'' Groth asked. ``There are many competing theories, but no solid observations. Hubble will put another piece in the puzzle. ``When you get the answer to a question you've been asking, you push back the frontier,'' he said. ``It is going to be very exciting for us all.'' Although astronomers expect unexpected discoveries by Hubble, Crane said, ``I don't think it is going to be as dramatic as Voyager.'' Astronomers were astonished by Voyagers' pictures of Saturn, Neptune, Jupiter and Uranus. The telescope, named for the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than ground-based observatories. ``This is one of those incredible milestones. This is something that literally hundreds of astronomers have been working on, and hundreds are waiting for the chance to work on it,'' said NASA scientist Stephen P. Maran. The Hubble is receiving considerable attention from amateurs, too. ``The only thing that compares in public interest that I have seen in 30 years as an astronomer is Halley's comet,'' Maran said.

DOC.HEAD: Duluth Police Officer Fatally Injured in Motel Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A police officer died today, 10 hours after he and a partner were shot through a motel wall while chasing a suspect in a barroom shooting, authorities said. Detective Sgt. Gary D. Wilson was the first Duluth police officer to die in the line of duty since 1966. Wilson, 34, died of a gunshot wound to the head this morning at St. Luke's Hospital, said Police Chief Eli Miletich. The 11-year veteran also had been shot in the shoulder. Sgt. John Hartley, 44, who was shot in the arm and chest in the Monday night incident, underwent surgery and was in stable condition at a Duluth hospital, Miletich said. Miletich said the suspect, a 47-year-old man from Altoona, Pa., who had been in Duluth only a few weeks working as a welder, was being held in the St. Louis County Jail pending arraignment. He was treated at a hospital earlier for a gunshot wound to the leg. Miletich said Wilson and Hartley were shot while investigating a shooting that had occurred at a bar earlier in the evening. The patron wounded at the Midway Bar, 34-year-old Mark Chumich of Duluth, was hospitalized in stable condition with a chest wound from a small-caliber handgun. The Duluth News-Tribune reported that the suspect had been laid off from his job at Industrial Welders & Machinists only days earlier and had become upset over jovial comments by a bar patron.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Talks On Cabinet Jobs, Including Economics Ministry
DOC.TEXT: Parties working to form East Germany's first non-Communist government haggled today over unfilled Cabinet positions including economic minister, a key role in how fast the country shifts to capitalism. The dominant conservative alliance favors quickly scrapping the Communist system and unifying with West Germany as soon as possible, while the Social Democrats want more-gradual privatization and cuts in subsidies. ``We made a good bit of headway,'' Prime Minister-designate Lothar de Maiziere told reporters after this morning's negotiating session. The Christian Democratic leader said there were still some issues to be ironed out but stressed he will present a complete Cabinet list to Parliament at its next session Thursday. On Monday the talks produced a 24-member Cabinet list that would give 14 seats to de Maiziere's three-party alliance, the leftist Social Democrats would get seven posts and a smaller liberal alliance three. But only 11 of the seats actually were filled on Monday. Among those not named was the economics minister, who is to be a Christian Democrat. The division of Cabinet seats came after five days of talks with the Social Democrats, who finished second to the Christian Democrats in East Germany's first free elections on March 18. The proposed Cabinet brings together the major political parties and includes a well-known peace activist as defense minister and a Lutheran pastor as foreign minister. Hans-Wilhem Ebeling, the designated minister for economic cooperation from the German Social Union _ a party in de Maiziere's alliance _ said negotiators had another night or two of work ahead before the list was complete. The Christian and Social Democrats still must harmonize their differing views on unification with West Germany _ the top priority of the new government. At stake for East Germans is how much of the socialist welfare state will remain once the two countries merge. Accustomed to generous food and housing subsidies, East Germans are unsettled by the probable loss of many state benefits as their country makes the transition to a market-oriented economy. The tough job of hammering out agreement on union of the East and West German currencies falls to the finance minister. Social Democrat Walter Romberg, nominated for the job, pledged Monday to fight for a 1-to-1 conversion of East German marks to West German marks. A West German central bank proposal last month that most exchanges be made at a 2-to-1 conversion drew angry protests in East Germany. Agreement on the Cabinet is a major hurdle that could finally put in place a democratic government to replace the Communist caretaker administration that has been running the country since last October's pro-democracy revolt. Social Democrat leader Markus Meckel was nominated to the important post of foreign minister, while Rainer Eppelmann, who leads the Democratic Awakening party that is part of de Maiziere's alliance, was named defense minister. Although de Maiziere's alliance won the most seats in the 400-member Parliament, it is seeking a coalition with the Social Democrats to ensure the two-thirds majority needed to enact constitutional changes to allow quick unification with West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Wounded in Bombings of Two Police Stations
DOC.TEXT: A militant Moslem group claimed responsibility for bombing attacks on two police stations in the capital today that wounded at least nine policemen. The United News of India news agency said the blasts were caused by timed explosive devices. It said one of the bombs was planted in a toilet and the other in a trash bin. Officials at the capital's police headquarters, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the bombs went off at two police stations about two miles apart in the western suburbs of New Delhi. Responsibility for the explosions was claimed by a previously unknown Moslem militant group, which is backing the fight for the secession of the predominantly Moslem northern Kashmir territory from Hindu-majority India. In Srinigar, the largest town in the Kashmir territory, newspaper offices and reporters received telephone calls from a man who claimed the bombings were the work of the ``Mujahedeen Kashmir,'' or Warriors of Kashmir. The caller, who spoke in the Kashmiri language, said he was an ``area commander'' of the group but did not give any more details. Srinagar has been the focal point for the Moslem secessionist movement in Kashmir. At least 256 people have been killed in Kashmir since the government cracked down on the insurgency on Jan. 20. More than a dozen militant groups are believed to operate in the region, but government sources said they had not previously known of the Mujahedeen Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Train Derails, Killing 1 And Injuring 41
DOC.TEXT: An intercity train derailed in southern Sweden today, killing one passenger and injuring 41, police said. All five cars and the engine went off the tracks outside Skoldinge, 60 miles southwest of Stockholm. The train was traveling from Vasteras to Mjolby, 120 miles to the southwest. The speed limit in the area was 25 mph because of rail work, but authorities were unsure why it derailed, duty officer Sixten Golden said. The accident blocked both tracks on the major western railway from Stockholm to Goteborg, causing severe delays of city trains. The identity of the dead passenger was not immediately available. Most of the injuries were minor, Golden said.

DOC.HEAD: Refinery Fire Closes Freeway, Schools; Neighbors Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through an oil and chemical company today, sending a huge plume of smoke toward downtown Milwaukee that closed businesses, schools and a busy freeway. No injuries were reported. Glendale Fire Chief Norman Wichman said the fire at Harrison Oil Inc. began near some cardboard boxes in a stock area shortly after 4 a.m. and spread rapidly to a part of the building where tanks of oil, kerosene and pesticides were stored. Firefighters were unable to control the flames, which at midmorning spread from the plant to an area of brush and railroad tracks. ``We've abandoned the building and are concentrating entirely on containing the fire in the area surrounding,'' said Wichman. ``We don't have enough firefighters or water power to keep the fire down.'' Plant Manager Gil Dombek said the building held 50,000 to 100,000 gallons of outboard motor oil and 2,000 to 3,000 gallons of kerosene. About 30,000 gallons of the oil burned, he said. He said 150 gallons of a cattle insecticide were believed to have burned and could have produced toxic fumes. ``But beyond that, really, there shouldn't be that much toxic in there,'' Dombek said. Wichman said toxic fumes were not a major concern at the fire scene. But police evacuated a large neighborhood south of the fire where the black smoke was spreading. ``We've been advised should the fumes descend to the ground, they're extremely toxic, and we've been told by the Fire Department to evacuate any area nearby where the smoke may travel,'' Milwaukee Police Sgt. Thomas Doehling said. The plant is bounded on the south by a residential section of Milwaukee, on the west by Interstate 43 and on the north and east by industrial areas. Three blocks of homes were evacuated. Officials also closed a high school and the Koss Corp., a large manufacturer of stereo headphones. Other smaller businesses closed voluntarily. Dombek said most of Harrison Oil's business involved packaging bulk oil into plastic containers and cans and selling it to outboard motor users. He said it also sold some farm insecticides and kerosene. He identified the burning pesticide as Ddvpvapona. Vapona is a brand-name insecticide with an active ingredient known as DDVP, a spokeswoman for the National Pesticide Telecommunications Network in Lubbock, Texas, said. She said Vapona may give off hydrogen chloride gas when burned. Hydrogen chloride gas is corrosive, has a suffocating pungent odor and may cause irritation to the throat, but lower concentrations are not harmful, according to the spokeswoman, who would not give her name.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says Son Told Him of Mansion Incident
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Mickelson told an interviewer he learned of a Nov. 28 incident at the governor's mansion from his son. The governor had kept mum for months about the incident, listed on a Nov. 30 Pierre police log as a rape. In an interview broadcast Monday night on television station KELO, Mickelson was asked how he first learned that something had happened Nov. 28. ``My son told me,'' Mickelson said. ``Before it came through on the police report?'' interviewer Steve Hemmingsen asked. ``Yes,'' the governor replied. However, Mickelson said through his press aide today that he misunderstood Hemmingsen's question when the interview was tapedin principle announced last Friday by Chicago-based UAL. The formalization of the buyout pact sets into motion the process for United's three employee unions to approve wage cuts and other contract concessions designed to save $2 billion over five years as a contribution toward the buyout. Under the agreement reached Friday, UAL's 71,000 employees will buy 100 percent of the company by exchanging for each share of UAL stock $155 in cash, $35 in UAL notes and one share in Covia Corp. valued at $11. Covia is the UAL subsidiary that owns United's 50 percent interest in the Apollo computerized reservations system. The deal, valued at $201 a share, could take up to eight months to complete. The agreement gives the employees four months to secure financing and another four months to complete the deal. UAL's stock was down 25 cents at $160.75 in early trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Born Aboard Czechoslovak Plane
DOC.TEXT: A West German woman gave birth to a baby on board a Czechoslovak airliner, with assistance from a Malaysian doctor on the flight, the state news agency CTK said Tuesday. The birth occurred shortly before midnight Monday during a flight to Frankfurt from Jakarta, Indonesia, CTK said. It identified the mother as Ilona Purwant, 35, and said her newborn daughter was in good condition. A doctor, traveling with the Malaysian soccer team to Bratislava, was called upon to assist during delivery, CTK said. The baby girl, who does not have a name yet, was the first baby to be born aboard a Czechoslovak airliner, CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze at Mental Hospital Kills Patient
DOC.TEXT: A fire possibly set by a patient swept through a dormitory at a mental hospital, killing one patient and severely injuring another, authorities said Tuesday. The blaze broke out Monday night in one of the 40 buildings at the hospital in this eastern city, which accommodates a total of about 1,000 patients. The building that caught fire housed 28 patients, three of whom were treated for smoke inhalation. A 49-year-old patient died, and a 29-year-old suffered extensive burns. Investigators said it appeared the fire was started by a patient.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Test Required For New Maids
DOC.TEXT: All new foreign housemaids must take a test for AIDS before going to work in Singapore, the Labor Ministry said Tuesday. Work permits will not be issued to maids who are found to be infected with the AIDS virus. The test does not apply to other foreign workers or maids already employed here. About 190,000 foreigners work in Singapore. Some 40,000 are maids. Ten people have died from acquired immune deficiency syndrome and at least 34 others have the virus that causes the disease. AIDS damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Sandalwood Smugglers Kill 4 Policemen, Wound 5
DOC.TEXT: Sandalwood smugglers in southern India shot and killed four policemen and wounded five others who were investigating reports that a gang was pilfering the fragrant trees, United News of India reported Tuesday. The victims were members of an eight-man police party investigating reports of smugglers in the Hogenakkal forest on the border of Tamil Nadu and Karnataka states, about 180 miles west of Madras, the news agency said. The policemen were attacked Monday night. Sandalwood oil is used for incense at Hindu shrines and for commercial purposes, such as scented soaps. Shavings of wood are fashioned into fragrant garlands and draped around the statues of gods and goddesses, and pieces of the wood are used in funeral pyres. There are bans limiting the number of trees that can be cut, resulting in a thriving smuggling trade.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Get Away With $2.9 Million in Train Robbery
DOC.TEXT: Three assailants shot their way into a car on a mail train, killing a postal employee and escaping with $2.9 million in Austria's biggest mail train robbery, police said Tuesday. The attack took place late Monday aboard a regional train en route from St. Poelten to Vienna, a distance of about 40 miles. According to witnesses, one of four postal employees on the train was shot to death. The others were handcuffed and gagged, with empty mail bags pulled over their heads. The robbers slashed open mail bags containing some 35 million schillings, or $2.9 million, in cash, police said. They fled when the train stopped in a suburb before Vienna. It was unclear when or how they boarded the train.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Police Find Cocaine Under Sink
DOC.TEXT: Police discovered 22.4 pounds of cocaine that had apparently sat under a kitchen sink for more than a year while the family that lived in the apartment was in jail. National police said Tuesday the seizure was the biggest drug haul ever in Santa Cruz de Tenerife, in the Canary Islands off northwest Africa. It was valued at $4.65 million. The cocaine was found recently in a specially sealed compartment below a kitchen sink, police said. The family that owned the apartment used its wood-export and video rental businesses as fronts for selling drugs. The three family members _ a 62-year-old Spaniard, his 47-year-old Colombian wife, and their 20-year-old son _ were arrested in December 1988 and convicted of possession of 4.4 pounds of cocaine. They are serving nine-year prison sentences. Police said a follow-up investigation into the family businesses indicated they had stashed more cocaine in their apartment, which prompted another search.

DOC.HEAD: Reopening of U.S. Cultural Center Postponed Amid Anti-U.S. Protests
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials have indefinitely postponed the reopening of a U.S. cultural center in the southern city of Kwangju at the request of the South Korean government, news reports said Tuesday. U.S. officials had said the Kwangju facility would reopen at a new location Friday, nearly a year after a wave of firebomb attacks forced it to close. Radicals have attacked the center about 30 times since a civil uprising in the city in 1980. City residents accused the United States of allowing South Korean troops under U.S. command to suppress the uprising, in which officials say 200 people died. ``The Korean government has reportedly expressed views that it was undesirable to reopen the center a month before the 10th anniversary of the Kwangju protests on May 18,'' the South Korean news agency Yonhap said. It quoted an official at the center as saying U.S. officials in Seoul had decided to postpone the reopening. Radical student leaders Tuesday announced a campaign aimed at permanently closing the cultural center. About 500 students fought police with firebombs while trying to march off a campus in Kwangju and vowing to drive out ``U.S. imperialists,'' Yonhap said. In Seoul, about 200 students armed with hundreds of firebombs battled police at Sogang University, shouting anti-U.S. and anti-government slogans. The students demanded U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg be expelled. Six students armed with homemade bombs and clubs attacked Gregg's residence in October. Gregg escaped unhurt. Meanwhile, in Itaewon, an entertainment district near the U.S. military headquarters in Seoul, four Korean citizens were injured in clashes Tuesday with two U.S. soldiers. No details were immediately available, but sporadic clashes have erupted in the area between U.S. soldiers and Koreans in recent years. U.S. authorities said two U.S. military policemen and a civilian American employee were injured Sunday in a dispute with Koreans. South Korean police said six Koreans were injured. Police said the Sunday incident occurred when the American employee injured two Korean pedestrians with his car. Police claimed the U.S. soldiers, brandishing truncheons, came to help the American, drawing dozens of onlookers and leading to a group fight.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela To Lead ANC Delegation In Groundbreaking Talks With Government
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela will lead an 11-member African National Congress delegation in groundbreaking talks next month with the government on ending white-minority rule, the organization said Tuesday. Following the May 2-4 talks, Mandela will embark on a series of foreign trips to at least nine countries, including the United States, the Soviet Union and several African and European nations, the ANC said. Next month's discussions are designed to clear the way for formal negotiations on a new constitution that will give the 28-million black majority a share of power in the country. ``It is vital that this meeting achieve the necessary results in terms of removing the obstacles that continue to stand in the way of negotiations,'' the ANC said in a statement from its exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. The ANC has said those obstacles include lifting the state of emergency, allowing exiles to return to South Africa, and releasing anti-apartheid activists convicted of politically motivated crimes. The government, which had previously announced the dates for the talks, has made clear that several black opposition groups in addition to the ANC will be invited to take part in the formal negotiations on a new constitution. The ANC, founded in 1912, has never held formal negotiations with the white-minority government, although Mandela has met with President F.W. de Klerk and his predecessor, P.W. Botha. The talks originally were set for April 11, but the ANC called off that meeting to protest a March 26 police shooting that left at least 11 protesters dead in Sebokeng, a township south of Johannesburg. The ANC delegation will include leaders from inside the country, such as Walter Sisulu and Ahmed Kathrada. They were released last year after more than 26 years in prison. Exile leaders named to take part in the talks include ANC Secretary-General Alfred Nzo; the commander of the ANC's military wing, Joe Modise; and the director of international affairs, Thabo Mbeki. The ANC did not release the exact dates of Mandela's trips. However, they will begin after the discussions with the government and last until early July. In addition to the United States and the Soviet Union, Mandela is scheduled to visit France, West Germany, Canada, Egypt, Angola, Nigeria and Algeria. De Klerk released Mandela in February after the black nationalist leader spent 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Mandela was named deputy president of the ANC after his release. Also in February, de Klerk legalized the ANC and more than 60 other black opposition groups as part of his effort to launch negotiations. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups want a one-person, one-vote democracy. De Klerk has opposed this, saying it will replace white domination with black domination. De Klerk envisions a mechanism that would allow whites to maintain veto power on major policy decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Border Patrol Seizes 1{ Tons of Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents on patrol along the U.S.-Mexican border followed a trail of footprints to a trailer where they arrested three men and confiscated 1{ tons of cocaine, authorities said. The seizure occurred Monday near Naco, about 100 miles southeast of Tucson, Border Patrol spokeswoman Jacqui Parker said. Four Border Patrol officers followed footprints to a car and trailer about a quarter-mile north of the border and seven miles west of the crossing at Naco, Chief Patrol Agent Ronald J. Dowdy said. When the officers saw people carrying bags across the border and loading them into the trailer, they staked out the trailer for two hours before moving in for the arrests, according to Gerald B. Murphy, who is in charge of the Drug Enforcement Adminstration's Tucson operations. ``It's very common for them to stash the drugs somewhere on this side of the border _ in a pickup or a camper, or just burying it _ and come back to pick it up later,'' Dowdy said. The agents confiscated 3,192 pounds of cocaine, officials said. Ms. Parker said investigators did not know where the cocaine came from or for whom the men were working. The case was turned over to DEA officials who said an investigation was continuing, Ms. Parker said. She said two of the arrested men were carrying assault rifles, while the third had a 9mm semiautomatic pistol. The suspects were identified as Richard J. Dadd of Sierra Vista, Ariz., and two Mexicans, Javier Gonzales Herrera and Jorge Escalante Gamez, of Cananea, Sonora. A fourth person, described only as a juvenile, was arrested later on charges related to the seizure and released. The seizure was one of several in southern Arizona in the past week. Other busts netted more than 470 pounds of cocaine and about 4,500 pounds of marijuana and led to arrests of three U.S. citizens, seven Mexicans and one Yugoslavian.

DOC.HEAD: Mattox, Richards Pledge to Support Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, `In Dallas...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE turnout; PICKS UP 7th graf, `Gov. Bill...'.
DOC.TEXT: Voters cast ballots today in a runoff election for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination after a bruising campaign of name-calling and charges of drug use. But in their final campaign stops, Attorney General Jim Mattox and state Treasurer Ann Richards on Monday talked about party unity. ``We are all going to be unified in November, and we are going to seize the governor's mansion back,'' Ms. Richards said in San Antonio on Monday. Mattox told backers in Dallas that he would consider including Ms. Richards in his administration. ``I think that there's a place for all of us within this Democratic Party, each of our talents,'' he said. Morning voter turnout was heavy at some southern Texas precincts and light to moderate in a few larger counties that lacked hot local races, Mark Toohey of the secretary of state's office said. State election officials predicted a turnout Tuesday of 1 million to 1.1 million voters for both parties. ``Statewide, we had 2.3 million voting in the primary March 13,'' said Toohey. ``Usually the dropoff or fall off the primary to the runoff is 50 percent or more and the figures now are tracking that.'' The winner of the runoff between Mattox and Ms. Richards will face Republican oilman-rancher Clayton Williams in the general election. Williams won the GOP nomination outright last month, capturing more than 61 percent of the vote. Gov. Bill Clements, a Republican, is retiring. The bitter Democratic campaign raged over the last month after Mattox, 46, and Ms. Richards, 56, bested a seven-person primary field. Mattox has accused Ms. Richards of using illegal drugs. ``I'm saying that she used cocaine at the age of 46 and marijuana, and she used other drugs,'' he said, while refusing to offer evidence. Ms. Richards underwent treatment for alcoholism in 1980 and said she has not had a ``mood-altering chemical'' since. She denied seeking treatment for cocaine use, adding, ``Mr. Mattox is telling lies in this campaign.'' But much of Monday's campaigning _ whirlwind tours of the state by both candidates _ lacked the nastiness that permeated both campaigns in recent days. Ms. Richards in Midland called for improvements in education, criticizing Clements for failing to provide leadership to change the current system for financing public schools. The system was declared unconstitutional by the Texas Supreme Court. Mattox, meanwhile, told members of Dallas' Progressive Voters League that a state lottery is the only way to raise needed state revenue without an additional tax increase.

DOC.HEAD: Up To 500 Dead In Famine-Hit Northern Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: As many as 500 people starved to death last month in northwestern Afghanistan because of famine caused by war, weather, and locusts, Western diplomats said Tuesday. Humanitarian aid workers based in the border city of Peshawar, Pakistan, began issuing famine warnings late last year. One agricultural expert, Tom Morrison, said the situation is so bad it might not be possible to save those who remain in the stricken areas of Herat, Badghis, and Faryab provinces. The infestation of locusts and other pests is ``very, very severe indeed,'' said Morrison, director of Agrisystems nordic AB Sweden, a Swedish agricultural research firm. ``It is so serious that I think the only way to cure it is for everyone to leave and starve it out,'' he said. A Western diplomat who refused to be identified quoted refugee sources as saying as many as 500 people may have died of hunger in Faryab province and that hundreds of families have fled because of a shortage of food. About 3.5 million Afghans have gone to Pakistan to escape the civil war since 1979, when Soviet soldiers intervened in Afghanistan to help the government fight Moslem insurgents. Another 2 million fled to Iran. Aid workers expect most people in search of food will go to Iran, because Pakistan is several weeks walks away from the northern provinces. The famine has been blamed on several things: _The 11-year-old civil war. Farmers either joined the U.S.-backed rebel fighters or were conscripted into the army. _Pesticide spraying, which has been suspended because most of the countryside is controlled by rebel fighters. According to Morrison's firm, the government has 800 tons of pesticides but has released only 300 tons. _Inadequately prepared humanitarian aid groups. _Late spring frost. _Government, which has used nomad tribesman to buy up grain from the Upper Herat Valley and horde it in Kabul. In addition, hundreds of thousands of tons of donated grain have either been siphoned by the government for distribution in Kabul, or taken by rebel fighters. A big problem is that aid workers will not venture into the isolated towns where residents are starving, said Bruce Wannell, a British national and researcher who is employed by a variety of groups on a contract basis. He said a $1.2 billion U.N. relief program to aid Afghans can boast only ``paper successes.'' ``They have no people on the ground who know the area, who have real linguistic skilles,'' he said. ``They take blind assurances that everything is working well and being distributed. But even the people in the cities are going hungry.'' A U.N. worker who asked not to be identified agreed, saying the United Nations is incapable of dealing with the ``rawness'' of Afghanistan, ``where there are no organizations to implement its programs.'' Wannell, who speaks the local Persian language, returned to Pakistan in early March after several months interviewing peasants, farmers, Moslem rebel fighters and pro-government militia. The people hit hardest by the famine are in villages surrounded by jagged rocks and accessible only by horse or mule, said Wannell. Aid groups are reluctant to venture into areas where they cannot drive, he said. ``A farmer in a small village in Herat recalled an afternoon in the spring of 1972 when he had to bury 70 people who had died of hunger, and he said things are worse now,'' said Wannell.

DOC.HEAD: Men Close the Population Gap With Women
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Men are catching up, at least in numbers. The Census Bureau said Tuesday that the number of men grew faster than the number of women in the '80s, something that hasn't happened since the first decade of this century. Death rates for men declined more rapidly than for women, extending male lifespans and allowing their population to increase more rapidly than women, the new study disclosed. Cancer deaths increased among women while dropping for men, pointing to increased smoking by women beginning in the 1960s as a likely factor in the change, a Census expert said. ``The male population outgrew the female population in every age group under age 85,'' Frederick W. Hollmann of the Census Bureau reported. From 1980 to 1989 the number of men in the nation increased by 10,557,000, while the female population grew 10,448,000, the Bureau reported. Even so, women continue to outnumber men in America, 127 million to 121 million, the report showed. The last decade in which the number of men increased faster than women was 1900-1910, the Census Bureau noted. The balance of population is determined not only by the number of people born but by the number of years they remain alive, explained Hollmann in a telephone interview. More male babies are born than females, he pointed out, but ``generally a sort of equilibrium is reached since males don't live as long as females.'' The higher death rate for men means that although they outnumber women at birth, women surpass men in total numbers later on. One consequence of males increasing faster than females in the 1980s was that in 1989 there were more men than women at each age group below 34. In 1980 men had been more numerous only through age 26, Hollmann reported. Hollmann said a major contributor to the males outpacing females in the 1980s was the change in death rates. ``Male life expectency has continued to improve gradually during the decade. Female life expectency has improved very little since 1982.'' Life expectency for men increased from 70.9 in 1982 to 71.5 years in 1987, an improvement of six-tenths of a year, he noted. During the same time period life expectency for women went up only one-tenth of a year, from 78.2 to 78.3. The reason seems to be changing patterns of disease as more and more women took up smoking and moved into traditionally male-dominated jobs and lifestyles, Hollmann commented. ``You could suggest that a lot of women took up smoking back in the 1960s, so the difference between men and women in smoking behavior tended to converge somewhat, said Hollmann. ``If behavior (between the sexes) is converging, then you have to expect mortality rates to converge also.'' ``There is a time lag between the time someone takes up smoking and the time they come to highest risk of death,'' he said, accounting for the change in comparative death rates in the 1980s. Between 1982 and 1986, for example, the cancer death rate for males declined from 164.8 deaths per 100,000 men to 163.6. For women the rate increased from 109.5 to 111.4. For heart disease, the death rate for men declined from 264.4 per 100,000 to 238.2. Women had a smaller decline, from 132.5 to 124.6. And deaths from cerebrovascular disease fell from 39.2 to 33.5 per 100,000 men from 1982 to 1986, while for women the drop was from 33.2 to 29.0, also a smaller decline than for men. The Census study used mortality data from the National Center for Health Statistics, a division of the Department of Health and Human Services. While the study did not include a breakdown by sex for immigration, Hollmann said that was also a contributing factor to the increase in males. Refugees coming into the country tended to include more males than females during the 1980s, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Dwarfs' Giant Statues Unveiled
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Some residents were happy, others grumpy about Dopey's rise to the top at the new Walt Disney Co. headquarters. Disney officials on Monday unveiled giant statues of the Seven Dwarfs, made to look as if they are holding up the roof of the five-story building. Happy, Grumpy, Sleepy, Sneezy, Dopey, Bashful and Doc each stand 19 feet tall. They'd been kept under wraps for more than three months. Within hours, tourists began stopping to take pictures of the dwarfs, who starred with Snow White in the 1937 animated classic. ``We have Stone Mountain but these are cuter,'' said Diane Ward, 28, a Georgia native who stopped to look with her 12-year-old nephew as they made their way to visit the NBC Studios. Some gazers were a bit puzzled. ``How can you call it a dwarf if it's 20 feet tall?'' asked Randy Garhan, 41, as he sat in the Pago Pago Club across the street. Disney employees were enthusiastic. ``What other company could do that?'' said Glen Means, 42, who works in the molding shop. ``I think it's outstanding.'' Others were less animated by it all. ``The Seven Dwarfs seem to be the only ones amused about this architectural nightmare,'' said Michael Scandiffio, a board member of the Burbank Rancho Homeowners Association. ``The building is too massive, it's an overbearing presence on surrounding neighbors.''

The new ABC series, ``H.E.L.P.,'' which has gotten no help from its ratings, will be taken off the air after April 14 and replaced with a new Los Angeles police series, ABC said Tuesday. ABC said that ``H.E.L.P.,'' about a New York emergency unit of police and firefighters, will return to the schedule later this year. It premiered on March 3. Its Saturday night successor is ``Sunset Beat,'' which ABC says is about undercover Los Angeles policemen disguised as motorcyclists ``in the seemingly safe, yet dangerous and seductive city that includes Hollywood.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The state and federal governments were on the verge of putting the Tooth Fairy out of business, until Michigan's dentists came to the rescue. The problem was the Environmental Protection Agency had listed extracted teeth as medical waste to be pulverized and sterilized, not stuck under a pillow so the Tooth Fairy could replace it with money. But the Michigan Dental Association and dentists successfully argued that teeth should be excluded from the state's own hazardous medical waste list, and the EPA went along. A Plainwell dentist, Dr. Robert Tisch, brought the problem to the attention of state Sen. Jack Welborn. ``I said, `Do you guys realize you're outlawing the Tooth Fairy?''' Tisch said. Dentists across the state joined the protest. The dentists had more than the potential disappointment of their young patients to back them up, though. William Burke, assistant executive director of the dental association, explained that dental schools need teeth for study. Because fluoride has cut the number of cavities youngsters get, schools have a hard time obtaining decayed teeth, he explained. Michigan opted out of a two-year EPA pilot program to track medical wastes and adopted its own package, which does not include teeth. The EPA, before adopting its final rules as to what constitutes hazardous medical waste, also decided to drop teeth from the list. ``There aren't too many things we can save in the Legislature, but thank God we can save the Tooth Fairy,'' Welborn said.

There is no indication how dogs will react, but Albertville plans to place a nickel-plated fire hydrant on a granite slab in front of the Chamber of Commerce office Wednesday. It's the millionth hydrant to come off the Mueller Co.'s assembly line since the plant opened in the northern Alabama city 15 years ago. City Council has proclaimed Albertville the ``Fire Hydrant Capital of the World.'' ``When you consider how many fire hydrants there are, the fact that more than 40 percent of all the hydrants being installed today come from this small Alabama city is quite remarkable,'' said Lloyd Darnell, the plant manager. Albertville has about 20,000 people. Mueller's annual payroll is $11.5 million. It turns out more than 400 hydrants a day, destined for points in much of the world. Darnell reckons he knows just about everything there is to know about fire hydrants except one thing: ``I never figured out why dogs like them.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Children Die In Early Morning Trailer Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT names based on new information from sheriff's department.
DOC.TEXT: Fire that roared through a house trailer early this morning killed six children ranging in age from 9 months to 12 years in this rural town about 30 miles southwest of New Orleans. Another fire in Delaware killed five family members. In the trailer, ``one body was found in the hallway leading to the bathroom, one in the kitchen and four were in a bedroom,'' said Detective Paul Lirette, of the Lafourche Parish Sheriff's Department. The cause of the fire was under investigation. Johnell Davis, 34, and Lorianne Davis, 29, escaped from the trailer with two of their children, Denise, 7, and Justin, the 9-month-old twin brother of one of the children who died. Johnell Davis suffered numerous burns, said Lafourche Parish Chief Deputy Eddie Duet. Mrs. Davis was treated and released and the children were being examined, he said. A burning staircase prevented three children, ages 1 to 4, and two adults from escaping a fire of undetermined cause this morning in a townhouse near Glasgow, Del. A fourth child was at school, said officials, who did not immediately release the family's name.

DOC.HEAD: Likely Effects of Japan's Promised Reform Still Hard to Gauge
DOC.TEXT: Some of the government's promises to make the economy more accessible to American companies face an uphill fight, and officials say it is hard to estimate how much the reform will help trim a huge U.S. trade deficit. ``In the long term, it will definitely positively affect our trade imbalance, but we are not sure of the amount of improvement,'' said Hidehiko Nishiyama, deputy director of the America-Oceania Division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. In a report last week on U.S.-Japanese negotiations, Japan promised to spend more money on public works, reform business practices that limit competition, and change tax laws to make more commercial land available at lower prices. A final and more detailed report is due in July. The government could run into resistance from the opposition Socialists, owners of small businesses, and corporate groups that have cozy relationships. ``I don't know how long it will take before the effects begin to show up,'' said Noriko Hama of Mitsubishi Research Institute. ``A lot of political and administrative problems have to be cleared up. We are just standing at the front door,'' she added. In recent years, Japan's sales in the United States have exceeded U.S. sales in Japan by about $50 billion a year. Immediate promises include increased public works spending in the budget for the fiscal year that began April 1. Under Japanese law, the governing Liberal Democratic Party's majority in the lower house of Parliament is enough to ensure it has its way in deciding the budget. They also include an easing of restrictions on opening new large-scale retail stores, tighter enforcement of anti-monopoly laws and a close inspection of preferential supply arrangements among groups of companies. Some of the provisions on stores, however, would require approval by Parliament. Even within the governing party, there is concern about alienating traditional party supporters among Japan's 1.6 million small retailers. ``The large-scale retail stores law and so on involve very difficult domestic political elements, so I am not so optimistic as to the prospect of gaining consensus or endorsement from the congress. As far as the administration is concerned, we are determined to do whatever we made public,'' said Taizo Watanabe, the Foreign Ministry's spokesman. Local governments also could maintain regulations to protect smaller retailers from competition by big stores. U.S. officials say the present law is a barrier to foreign stores and that larger Japanese stores are more likely to carry foreign products. Large retailers have welcomed the proposed changes but have noted that high land prices, a labor shortage and rising construction costs could frustrate expansion plans. Over the longer term, Japan pledged efforts to solve tax laws and other regulations that keep some land underutilized and drive up prices; increase fines for anti-monopoly law violations; look into simplifying merger and acquisition procedures; and formulate a 10-year plan of increased spending on such things as housing, sewers, parks, airports and port facilities. It also said, however, that year-by-year public works spending would be decided flexibly to avoid inflation and overheating the economy. The leading opposition party, the Socialist Party, has supported bigger public works spending but added that ``it must be concentrated on improving the people's livelihood.'' It also has favored a greater role for local governments in retail store regulations. Enforcement of the anti-monopoly laws and the new task of regular checks on Japan's ``keiretsu,'' or corporate groups, would depend on the Fair Trade Commission, an agency that so far has not enjoyed high status and has not rushed to prosecute offenders. Agency figures for the fiscal years 1984-1988 show no criminal charges filed. In fiscal 1988, the commission looked into 180 cases, and in only five told companies that they were violating the law and had to stop. Japan pledged that the commission would more actively press criminal charges and said its fiscal 1990 budget calls for expanding the number of investigators to 154 from the present 129. Meanwhile, it said the commission would take steps against exclusionary practices uncovered in analyses to be conducted of keiretsu activities. Some Japanese say these groups of companies that hold each other's stock and supply each other with goods and services actually are like a major U.S. corporation, such as General Motors, composed of many divisions. U.S. officials and businessmen complain that transactions within such groups freeze out foreign suppliers, and the groups' structure makes it hard for foreigners to invest in Japan. On the question of dealings based on personal ties, Masahiko Ishizuka, an editorial writer for the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun, quoted one Japanese executive as saying of his customers, ``As long as face-to-face relations remain intact, prices are irrelevant. They will continue to buy from us irrespective of prices, virtually shutting out newcomers.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Conviction Against Palestinian
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Insert graf after 2nd to ADD that defendant was arrested in Sweden, also convicted of crimes in Sweden. Pickup 3rd pvs, `Imandi, who...
DOC.TEXT: A court of appeals Tuesday upheld a life sentence against a Palestinian convicted of terrorist attacks against Jewish and American interests in Denmark, officials said. Marten Imandi was one of four Palestinians convicted of bombing a synagogue and Northwest Orient Airlines' office in 1985 in Copenhagen. One person was killed and several people injured. Imandi was arrested in Sweden and also convicted of terrorist attacks in the Netherlands and Sweden. Imandi, who was sentenced to life last December, sought a lessened sentence, arguing that he played a minor role. But the Svea Court of Appeals rejected Imandi's version of events and said, ``This kind of crime is of especially serious nature.'' Another defendant who received a life sentence was Mohammed Abu Talb, who is suspected of complicity in the 1988 explosion of Pan Am Flight 103, which killed 270 people. He is being investigated by Scottish police in connection with that incident.

DOC.HEAD: Three Hostages Held By Abu Nidal Group Freed in Beirut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with family leaving Beirut, Gadhafi comments; Picks up 10th graf, `A police ...'; SUBS 17th graf pvs, `He said ...' to insert that Belgian government has not responded to demand for prisoner's release.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAR1,2, BEI1
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal today freed a French woman, a Belgian man and the daughter born to them in captivity. The couple had been seized from a French yacht nearly 2{ years ago. Jacqueline Valente, 32, Fernand Houtekins, 43, and 2-year-old Sophie-Liberte were released by masked gunmen who sped up to the main gate of the French Embassy in three cars with drawn curtains, police said. ``I embrace all my family. I am well, and the little one also,'' Ms. Valente told French reporters who were given exclusive access to the three. The family later took off for France in a chartered executive jet. Because the hostages released today were believed to have been held in Libya, the case is considered unrelated to the 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. Today's release came about a month after France sent to Libya three Mirage F1 warplanes that Libya purchased in 1986. The sale had been blocked by the French government as part of an arms embargo imposed when France aided Chad in fighting against Libya. There was no public explanation by France for its decision to release the planes. Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi said Abu Nidal's group was ``distancing'' itself from its terrorist reputation by releasing the hostages, Libya's official news agency JANA reported today. Last week, Gadhafi urged the release of hostages in the Middle East as a humanitarian gesture for Ramadan, the Islamic holy month. He singled out Ms. Valente. Gadhafi has supported Abu Nidal, who along with some of his followers has been convicted of terrorist attacks abroad. The Libyan leader is believed to have allowed him to live near the Libyan capital, Tripoli. Houtekins said today that the four members of his family still held by the terrorist group were also well. ``They have morale. They are holding firm,'' he said, adding, ``We expected our freedom, we knew it was coming one day. The day of our freedom has arrived. For those who stay behind, we keep hoping.'' The two, accompanied by their daughter, refused to discuss certain other subjects, including the death of their second child in captivity or their living conditions while they were hostages. A police spokesman said French Ambassader Rene Ala ``apparently had advance notice of the release. Ala was waiting at a cement outpost manned by French Marine guards near the main gate'' of the West Beirut compound. French Embassy spokesman Francois Abi Saab said the three were ``OK.'' He said Houtekins was ``clean shaven and looked relaxed.'' Hours after the release, Walid Khaled, spokesman for the terrorist group, the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, drove to the French Embassy and said he would release a statement ``after my talks with French diplomats.'' The Abu Nidal group announced on Nov. 8, 1987 it had seized hostages from the French yacht Silco in the Mediterranean off the Gaza strip. It accused them of collaborating with Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. Friends said the group was on a holiday cruise. The group acknowledged holding Valente, 32, Sophie and five Belgians: Houtekins, his brother Emmanuel, and Emmanuel's wife and teen-age daughter and son. A boy born to Ms. Valente in captivity in March 1989 died shortly after birth, French government sources said. Khaled had said Monday three European hostages would be freed by the end of Ramadan, about April 26 depending on when the new moon is sighted. Jan Hollants Van Loocke, a Belgian official, said at the same news conference he was in Lebanon to negotiate the Belgians' release. He said the Abu Nidal group had linked freedom for the four other Belgians to the release of Nasser Sa'eed, a Palestinian jailed in Belgium for a June 1980 grenade attack on Jewish youths in Antwerp. A 15-year-old was killed in the attack and 20 people injured. The Belgian government has not yet responded to the offer. Sa'eed is serving a life term. Two other daughters of Ms. Valente were freed after Libyan intervention on Dec. 29, 1988. Daughter Marie-Laure was 6 at the time and Virginie was 5. They were returned to their father Pascal Betille, divorced from Ms. Valente. The two girls surfaced in Libya, where the others were believed held.
