In Seattle, Boeing spokesman Jack Gamble said the company had no comment on the NTSB finding ``except to say we feel, No. 1, those cargo doors are safe.'' ``There were subsequent changes made as a result of the accident, changes and inspection processes. All of the necessary actions have been taken to ensure integrity of that door's operation in flight,'' Gamble said. The board said the current cargo door system on 747s can indicate to the pilot that the door is locked when it is not. That's expected to be changed with an imminent FAA order that would require detectors on the locks, said Ron Schleed, investigator in charge for the accident. The FAA already has issued orders to ensure that Boeing 747 cargo doors are secure and more thoroughly inspected after each closing. Schleed said efforts to locate and recover the cargo door from the ocean would continue. He said a Navy vessel and sophisticated probe device would be available in June to conduct a search that would be limited to about two weeks. Radar was able to track the door as it fell, but it was lost about 3,000 feet before it hit the water, Schleed said. Investigators hope the door will show whether parts were damaged before the failure. They have evidence of damage in the mechanism, which they speculate may have been caused by a faulty electrical device or by turning a wrench the wrong way when the door was closed manually, Schleed said.

DOC.HEAD: Release of Official Election Results Postponed
DOC.TEXT: The release of official final results in national elections has been postponed because of irregularities in several districts, an official said Tuesday. An announcement of final results had been expected by Tuesday. But Janos Nemeth, chairman of the National Electoral Committee, told reporters the official tallies would be released at a later date. He did not say when. Nemeth said the irregularities would be investigated. Voters chose Hungary's first freely elected parliament in 43 years. Unofficial results indicate an overwhelming victory for the main conservative party. The results, released Monday by the national vote counting center, showed the conservative Hungarian Democratic Forum winning 165 of 386 parliamentary seats. The Democratic Forum will hold 42.75 percent of the seats in the new parliament. The unofficial tally also showed the liberal Alliance of Free Democrats with 92 seats, or 23.83 percent; the agrarian Smallholders with 43 seats and 11.14 percent; the Socialist Party, formed by reformers from the now-disbanded Communist Party, with 33 seats and 8.55 percent; and the Federation of Young Democrats and the Christian Democrats even at 21 seats each and 5.44 percent each. The Democratic Forum is expected to form a conservative governing coalition with the Smallholders and the Christian Democrats. The Interior Ministry's electoral office said there were ``major mistakes'' in the figures provided by three constituencies. ``Correction of these mistakes may lead to some major modifications of the results,'' the state MTI news agency said, without elaboration. Nemeth told reporters that in several districts, including Budapest, there were reports some people voted twice. In 11 cases, electoral committees registered people who ``did not have the right to vote,'' MTI said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Word Of New Treatment Not Getting Out
DOC.TEXT: Patients with spinal cord injuries may not be getting a new treatment that reduces paralysis because federal health officials have not sent research data to physicians, a consumer advocacy group said Tuesday. The Public Citizen Health Research Group called it a ``colossal failure of communication'' and said that ``any further delay in notifying all emergency rooms about this is recklessly irresponsible.'' The group called on Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan to send information about the therapy to emergency room and trauma care physicians to alert those who may not have heard about it through the media and to allow them to evaluate data documenting the effectiveness of the drug. On March 30, federal health officials announced the results of a government study showing that high doses of the drug methylprednisolone given within eight hours of a spinal cord injury was able to restore some feeling and movement in virtually all spinal cord injury patients. The drug has been used for years for other purposes, but its use in massive doses marked the first time an effective treatment for such paralyzing injuries had been found. Since about 95 percent of all spinal cord patients are admitted to hospitals within eight hours, most could benefit from the treatment, researchers said. Officials at the National Institutes of Health said they deviated from usual practice and released the results before publication in a medical journal in hopes that patients could benefit immediately. Study results are to be published in May in the New England Journal of Medicine. They said doctors could obtain information about treatment with the drug by calling (301) 496-5751 during working hours. Also, for the first weekend after the news conference, a toll-free number was set up with a recorded message giving information about treatment. More than 1,000 inquiries were received that weekend and 500 have been received on the daytime number, said Jim Brown, an HHS spokesman. But Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the Ralph Nader-founded Public Citizen Health Research Group, noted that a Newsday survey last week found that six of the nine major trauma centers in the New York area had not started to use the treatment because they had not seen the study data. Brown said Wolfe's letter is being reviewed. Wolfe said a breakthrough such as researchers found with high doses of methylprednisolone occurs only once or twice a year, but the public health officials should establish a way for word of these findings to get to physicians quickly. ``The stakes are too high,'' he said. In the case of methylprednisolone, ``this drug makes a difference between being on crutches and being in a wheelchair.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Asks Air Force For Explanation On F-117A
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has asked the Air Force to find out why he was not told for months that a F-117A Stealth fighter-bomber dropped its bomb far off-target in the Panama invasion, an aide said Tuesday. ``The secretary has asked the Air Force for an explanation,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters. He said Cheney was ``eager to know what the chain of information was.'' Air Force officials said there was no intention of misleading Cheney but that ``miscommunication'' took place within the chain of command. Williams confirmed Friday that neither he nor Cheney were told the full story about the F117A's performance during the Dec. 20 operation until April 3. In the days following the U.S. invasion, Pentagon officials said two of the high-tech planes were used for the first time in combat _ each supposedly dropping one 2,000-pound bomb on a field near a Panamanian Defense Forces barracks to create confusion while U.S. paratroopers prepared to drop onto a nearby airfield. One of the planes actually dropped its bomb some distance away due to an apparent pilot error, Williams said. Defense Department sources have described Cheney as ``livid'' over the lack of information, since it left him touting the super-sophisticated jet's ``pinpoint accuracy'' in the aftermath of the Panama invasion. The Pentagon held a highly publicized briefing on April 3 to make public its view that the F-117A Stealth program had been a success and describe the merits of the plane. At the briefing, Williams disclosed considerable information that until then had been classified. He said later he was told about the off-target bomb following that briefing and after he had repeatedly passed on questions about the plane's peformance to Air Force officials at the urging of a New York Times reporter who had photos of the off-target bomb crater. Williams explained that the two planes were told to drop their bombs no closer than 50 meters away from two separate PDF barracks buildings. But due to a last-minute misunderstanding between the pilots, the second F-117A pilot dropped his bomb on a hillside several hundred yards away, Williams has confirmed. Despite that problem, Williams said Tuesday, Cheney and other Pentagon officials believe that the jets accomplished their mission, which was to stun the PDF forces. The bombs, including the off-target one, weigh 2,000 pounds and ``shook the ground considerably,'' he said. The spokesman said that military officials believe no lives were lost by the off-target delivery but that the Air Force is looking into exactly where the bombs landed. ``Now we're asking people to go down there and measure where the bombs landed,'' he said. Williams said that Cheney does not believe that he was purposely misled and is interested in knowing ``when the subsequent information came to light and why it wasn't passed up'' the chain of command.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Harvest Prospects Unchanged
DOC.TEXT: Orange harvest prospects are virtually unchanged from last month, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Production as of April 1 was forecast at 172 million boxes, down 18 percent from 209 boxes last season, primarily because of a freeze in December. Most of the reduction was attributed to a 30 percent decline in the Florida crop, estimated at 103.1 million boxes against 146.6 million in 1988-89. The Texas crop was indicated at 1.2 million boxes, down from 1.85 million in 1988-89. California production, estimated at 66 million boxes, is up from 58.8 million last season, while the Arizona harvest was indicated at 1.9 million boxes, up from 1.7 million last season. Total grapefruit production was forecast at 48.6 million boxes, down 30 percent from last year, reflecting the freeze in Florida and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Editors Fired for Anti-Abortion Activity, Religious Group Protests
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Two editors complained Tuesday that their First Amendment rights of free speech and religion were violated when they were fired from a small Iowa newspaper for organizing an anti-abortion group. The newspaper defended its actions and a lawyer for the Iowa Civil Liberties Union said the editors didn't have a First Amendment case. ``I guess my religious convictions are what brought it about,'' Terri Lambertsen, former People Page editor of the Fairfield Ledger, said in a telephone interview. ``I have to believe that serving the Lord is more important than my job.'' The Ledger is a 5,000-circulation, six-day-a-week afternoon newspaper published about 90 miles southeast of Des Moines. Ms. Lambertsen and News Editor John Kennedy were discharged Monday when they refused to quit as leaders of the Southeast Iowa Pro-Lifers, a newly-formed anti-abortion group. Ms. Lambertsen is president and Kennedy is secretary of the group. Ledger Editor Jan Nierling said the newspaper was forced to fire the two to protect its credibility, even though that left the paper with only a managing editor, a reporter and sports editor. ``We take our business seriously. We just think it endangers incredibly our perception of credibility and objectivity. A newspaper's credibility is its most valuable asset,'' Ms. Nierling said. The firings prompted a protest sponsored by Refocus Ministries, a non-denominational ministerial group. About 40 protestors walked in a circle in front of the Ledger office Tuesday afternoon. ``I have to agree with what John Kennedy said,'' said Larry Rail, co-director of the group. ``He joined a group that is pro-life. It doesn't mean his views as a newspaper reporter and editor are going to change. So it's a blatant violation of his rights.'' The Ledger's policy is similar to many other news organizations, according to William Hirschman, president of the Kansas chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists and the group's Freedom of Information representative for the region that includes Iowa. A common compromise, he said, is to permit reporters to participate in some groups, but not as spokesmen or leaders, and to prevent writers from covering events in which they are personally involved. ``I would have hoped that the two sides would have sat down and discussed it,'' he said. Last October, the Milwaukee Journal fired a receptionist, Diane Dew, for her anti-abortion activities. In December, the paper said it made a mistake and agreed to pay her a settlement. The Journal said it had decided that its code of ethics for newsroom employees did not apply to Ms. Dew. Last spring, reporters for The New York Times and The Washington Post were criticized by their newspapers for participating in an abortion rights march in Washington. No punitive action was taken at either paper. Kennedy, an eight-year employee of the Ledger, said his involvement with the anti-abortion group did not interfere with his newspaper duties. He said the newspaper could send another reporter to cover an abortion-related story if it felt his objectivity was compromised. Neither Kennedy nor Ms. Lambertsen would say if they planned to pursue legal remedies. ``I've got three kids, aged 4, 6 and 7. My wife works part-time as a church secretary for $37 a week. I'm not sure yet what we'll do, but the Lord will take care of us,'' Kennedy said. Ms. Nierling said the newspaper has a longstanding policy of prohibiting reporters from being officers of politically active groups that receive news coverage. ``I'm disappointed that they didn't have a better attitude toward their professional responsibilities,'' she said. Mark Bennett, general counsel for the Iowa Civil Liberties Union, said the First Amendment was not at issue in the case. The First Amendment, he said, applies only to governments that try to infringe religious and speech rights, not to private enterprises, such as a newspaper. An untested theory, he said, would be whether the paper violated Iowa's civil rights laws, which prohibit discrimination on the basis of creed.

DOC.HEAD: Better Math Education, Plus Career Counseling Equals More Workers
DOC.TEXT: Better education plus improved career counseling is necessary to add to the pool of mathematically skilled workers who will be needed in the United States by 2000, the government said Tuesday. The National Research Council said the demand for scientists, engineers and technicians by the turn of the century will exceed the 1986 level by 36 percent _ nearly double the growth in overall employment demand. Meanwhile, the council said, the college-age population is expected to decrease 22 percent from 1981 to 1995. The number of white male students, the traditional pool for scientists and engineers, will shrink 34 percent. ``A Challenge of Numbers,'' the second council report on mathematics, describes the gap between the projected supply and demand and the challenge facing the nation's education system. The first report, ``Everybody Counts,'' studied trends and needs in math education. Other reports later this year will evaluate post secondary math curriculum; discuss resources available for math instruction; and make recommendations on how to ``ensure a healthy flow of mathematical talent'' into an increasingly technological work force. Among the statistics reported Tuesday by the council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, were that: _By 1995, eight of the 10 fastest growing professions will be based on science. _Skills in mathematics and a post secondary education will be needed for a majority of the 21 million new jobs created by the U.S. economy by 2000. _Math enrollments have doubled in the past 20 years, but two-thirds of the enrollees have been in courses lower than calculus. _The number of students receiving mathematics degrees, those who could teach, was lower in 1986 than in 1966. _The percentage of college students studying math may drop as the proportion of blacks and Hispanics, who have traditionally studied math at a lower rate than the general population, increases. The two groups comprised 22 percent of college students in 1985; they are expected to account for 30 percent by 2010. _Women's interest in advanced mathematics has been low. White women earn 17 percent of math doctorates compared with 70 percent by their male counterparts. _Non-citizens comprise nearly half the graduate mathematics population, even as the total number of doctorates awarded has continued to fall. _Three-quarters of math graduates work outside academia, but no one knows much about what they do. The lack of information ``dulls the appeal of mathematics as a major and as a profession,'' the study said.

A fire feeding on thousands of gallons of oil at a suburban Milwaukee oil-packing company destroyed the plant Tuesday and raged out of control for seven hours until a foam spray cut the flames. The fire broke out shortly after 4 a.m. at Harrison Oil Corp. No workers were inside at the time, and no injuries were reported. One firefighter was overcome by fumes and heat, and another gashed his face when he fell. Plant Manager Gil Dombek said nearly all of the 50,000 to 100,000 gallons of outboard motor oil and 2,000 to 3,000 gallons of kerosene were engulfed in the blaze. He also said 150 gallons of a cattle insecticide were believed to have burned and could have produced toxic fumes earlier in the morning. ``But beyond that, really, there shouldn't be that much toxic in there,'' Dombek said. Firefighters were unable to control the fire until a specialized truck from Milwaukee's Mitchell International Airport was dispatched and sprayed thousands of gallons of foam on the flames, said Glendale Fire Chief Norman Wichman. ``The foam did a fabulous job. It really cut the fire,'' Wichman said. A huge plume of smoke that billowed from the plant closed a manufacturer, two schools and a portion of Interstate 43. State Department of Natural Resources officials said an unknown quantity of oil, anti-flame foam and insecticides seeped into the Milwaukee River, and might kill fish and waterfowl there.

DOC.HEAD: Demand for Corn and Soybeans Up
DOC.TEXT: Demand for corn and soybeans has picked up a bit, indicating smaller year-end stockpiles than had been forecast previously, an Agriculture Department report said Tuesday. The new supply-and-demand analysis said the revisions were in line with recent figures showing that March 1 corn and soybean inventories were lower than expected. Thus with greater use in the 1989-90 marketing year, Sept. 1 corn inventories are expected to be about 1.33 billion bushels, down from 1.48 billion forecast a month ago. Last Sept. 1, the U.S. corn stockpile was 1.93 billion bushels, reduced sharply by low yields caused by the 1988 drought. On Sept. 1, 1988, the corn inventory was 4.26 billion bushels. Corn prices nationally are expected to average $2.30 to $2.40 per bushel this marketing year, up five cents from the March forecast but still well below the $2.54 average of the 1988-89 marketing year. In 1987-88, before the effects of the drought, corn prices averaged $1.94 per bushel, the report said. On the international level, the report said global trade in corn and other ``coarse'' grains is expected to be down slightly from the March forecast, while world production is ``largely unchanged.'' ``The prospective corn crop in South Africa is up 500,000 tons, but lower sorghum crops are indicated for Australia and Argentina,'' the report said. Global stockpiles of coarse grain _ which include corn, sorghum, barley, oats, rye, millet and mixed grains _ are expected to be down from last month's forcast to their lowest level since 1983-84 because of the reduced U.S. inventory. Soybean inventories going into the new marketing year on Sept. 1 were put at 305 million bushels, down from the March forecast of 330 million. However, that would be up from 182 million bushels of soybeans on hand last Sept. 1. The Sept. 1, 1988, soybean stockpile was 302 million bushels. Marketing year prices averaged $5.88 per bushel in 1987-88 before soaring to $7.42 in 1988-89. With larger production and smaller demand, soybean prices are expected to average in the range of $5.55 to $5.65 this marketing year, unchanged from the March forecast. Global production of oilseeds, which includes soybeans, was forecast at a record 213.2 million metric tons, down slightly from last month but 5 percent more than last year. The report showed little change in the wheat supply and demand for the 1989-90 marketing year that began last June 1. Wheat stockpiles are expected to be about 442 million bushels this June 1, virtually the same as forecast last month. That would compare with 702 million bushels on hand last June 1 and 1.26 billion bushels on June 1, 1988. Nationally, wheat prices were forecast at $3.70 to $3.75 per bushel this marketing year, down a nickel at the upper end of the range, compared with $3.72 in 1988-89 and $2.57 in 1987-88.

DOC.HEAD: Express Subway to JFK Airport Ending
DOC.TEXT: Express subway service to Kennedy International Airport ends Sunday after 11{ years of subsidized service. ``It was never really the Train to the Plane,'' said Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokeswoman, referring to an early advertising slogan. ``It was always the train to the bus to the plane.'' Passengers paid $7.50 to ride the express subway to Howard Beach in Queens, then special buses to the airport. Lebow said about half the riders were regular commuters from Howard Beach, not airplane passengers. The transit authority expects to save $7 million in operating costs by eliminating the service.

DOC.HEAD: Six Children Die In Early Morning Trailer Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT name of hospital to Lady of the Sea, sted Our Lady of the Sea.
DOC.TEXT: Fire engulfed a mobile home Tuesday and killed six children, ranging in age from 9 months to 12 years, although relatives living nearby rushed to help save the youngsters. Their parents escaped with two other children who weren't harmed. ``We ran over there to the trailer. My daughter was coming out the window with the baby,'' said Irene Allen, the victims' grandmother. ``She fell, but she didn't let the baby fall, she fell. And I grabbed the baby, and I asked her where the other children were.'' ``The smoke was coming into our faces,'' said Lorianne Davis, mother of the victims. ``My husband jumped out the window in the bedroom. He was calling me, he said, `Come on, Lori, come on.' but I went back to try to get them. And then I jumped out. That's when my leg snapped.'' Mrs. Davis, 29, was treated for a knee injury and released. Her husband, Johnnell, 34, was in stable condition at Lady of the Sea Hospital in Galliano with second-degree burns over 10 percent of his body, a hospital spokesman said. The family had just moved the trailer to the area Monday, neighbors said. The trailer had no power and was connected by a single extension cord to another power source. Fire officials said they were investigating the possibility that the extension cord may have caused the fire. Lafourche Parish Sheriff Duffy J. Breaux identified the dead as Cassandra Davis, 12; Johnell Davis Jr., 11; Kerry Ann Davis, 10; Larraine Marie Davis, 6; Laura Davis, 5; Jester Davis, 9 months.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Stands to Profit from Hostage Releases, France Says
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 13th `A Fatah...' to ADD name of spokeman and where he spoke; pickup graf 14 `French relations...'
DOC.TEXT: The government declared Tuesday that its often bitter relations with Libya will improve as a result of the release from captivity of a French woman, her daughter and the girl's father. The three were freed Tuesday by the Libyan-backed Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal. Previous releases of French hostages prompted complaints from critics that France barters with terrorists. France has denied such charges. There has been no confirmation of any deals or even direct talks for the latest releases, but some conservative opposition leaders view the government's effusive mood toward Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi as suspicious. President Francois Mitterrand thanked Gadhafi for ``the determining role he played in the happy ending of this affair.'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas praised Gadhafi's ``noble and humanitarian gesture'' in pressuring Abu Nidal's group to free the three. In return for the releases, Dumas indicated in a statement that Tripoli could expect to benefit from improved ties with France. ``Its real value will be appreciated in the future of relations between France and Libya,'' Dumas said. He did not elaborate. A spokesman for France's conservative Republican Party said it was ``not useful for Mr. Dumas to send flowers to Gadhafi.'' Ladislav Poniatowski said Libya ``remains, in effect, a way station for international terrorism.'' On April 4, Gadhafi called for the release of hostages held in the Middle East and specifically mentioned the French woman, Jacqueline Valente. She, her daughter Sophie-Liberte, and the girl's father, Fernand Houtekins, were held for 2{ years by Abu Nidal and his Fatah-Revolutionary Council. Four other Belgians remain captive. It was the second time Gadhafi interceded for the French. He pressured Abu Nidal's group to free two other daughters of Ms. Valente in 1988. Fatah spokesman Walid Khaled on Tuesday denied assertions the hostages had been held in Libya. Speaking at a news conference in Beirut, he said the hostages had been kept in Lebanon, where they were freed. French relations with Gadhafi have see-sawed. The latest thaw comes one month after France returned to Libya three French-made Mirage jet fighters here for repairs since 1986. Their return was blocked by an embargo imposed when Libya and France backed opposing sides during a civil war in Chad. Relations sunk to a new low in December, when Libya, pressing for delivery of the aircraft, closed its ports to French ships. At the time, Tripoli lambasted Paris on an array of issues, accusing France of involvement in ``the terrorist plot being hatched against Lebanon by the imperialist West.'' In a letter to Mitterrand, Gadhafi accused France of ``oppressing'' Moslems and claimed the government was allowing Jews to ``use France in a new war of religion against Islam.'' However, while railing last month against the United States and West Germany after a fire at a Libyan plant alleged to produce chemical weapons, Libya praised France, saying that ``all misunderstandings have dissipated.'' Gadhafi expressed hope Tuesday that Middle Easterners detained in European and American jails would also be freed.

DOC.HEAD: SDI Uses Laser Radar
DOC.TEXT: An experiment conducted by the Strategic Defense Initiative program successfully used laser radar to track a mock decoy warhead last month, officials said on Tuesday. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams called the March 29 test ``a significant milestone'' in the effort to tell real warheads from decoys in mid-course. The need to tell the difference between warheads and decoys is a key goal of the Strategic Defense Initiative, the space-based strategic missile defense system popularly known as ``Star Wars.'' Missiles with decoys could be launched along with nuclear-tipped missiles to confuse a possible ``Star Wars'' system. Program officials, who briefed reporters Tuesday at the Pentagon about the experiment, said they launched a sub-orbital rocket last month from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Wallops Island, Va., facility, tracked it to a 300-mile highpoint, and observed a payload that was ejected. The program officials used a laser radar, which is faster than conventional microwave radar, to track the payload. The test made use of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory Firepond laser radar located near Westford., Mass., officials said. ``We've added another tool to help distinguish between warheads and decoys in a space environment,'' said Col. Raymond Ross, the director of the sensors and interceptor technology office of SDI.

DOC.HEAD: Judge `in a Quandry' Over Lincoln Savings Figures
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 9th graf, Last week, to clarify reference to bailout.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said Tuesday that regulators should explain why they slashed the estimated value of financier Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and other investments. ``The government says it's $2 billion in the red and the former operator says it's $600 million in the black,'' U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin said. ``I'm in a quandary. Let's get the receiver in here.''

Sporkin's suggestion came after Keating testified that Lincoln was worth $500 million to $700 million when the government seized it a year ago. The financier is trying to regain control of the Irvine, Calif., thrift, which was seized by the government along with its large real estate holdings a year ago. James Murphy, an attorney representing the government in its defense to Keating's suit challenging the takeover, tried to dissuade the judge. He said FDIC reports on Lincoln's status are already court record. Sporkin's suggestion brought broad smiles from Keating and several associates. For months, Keating has claimed that S&L regulators undervalued Lincoln's investments and were grossly mismangaging them since taking over the thrift. ``Now it looks like we may start cutting through the bull and start talking real turkey,'' said Robert Wurzelbacher, Keating's son-in-law and the manager of Lincoln's vast real estate holdings. Last week, the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, raised its estimate of the 30-year cost of bailing out bankrupt thrifts from $257 billion to $300 billion and Comptroller General Charles Bowsher said the figure could climb to $400 billion or $500 billion if interest rates rise or there is a recession. ``I don't think that that the U.S. taxpayer need take that hit, whatever the number is _ $300 billion, $500 billion _ under a proper structure for the industry,'' Keating testified Tuesday. That structure, according to Keating, would return S&Ls to the deregulated status they enjoyed from 1982 until 1985 when federal regulators began reimposing restricitions on thrift investments. Keating recounted how the Federal Home Loan Bank Board criticized his 1984 purchase, using federally insured deposits in Lincoln, of stock in Gulf Broadcasting Co. He said the regulators objected, even though the thrift realized a $50 million profit on the deal 15 months later. ``Their criticism was that we might not have made it (the profit),'' he said. ``We felt we had no downside. There was a feeding frenzy for media properties at that time. I thought we could have ended up with a $400 million gain. That was later proven out by the subsequent liquidation of Gulf's assets.'' Keating said Lincoln settled for the $50 million profit because of regulators' resistance to its participation in what was viewed by some as a hostile takeover attempt against Gulf. As an example of the government undervaluing Lincoln assets, Keating pointed to the luxurious Phoenician Resort that, using the thrift's funds, he built outside Phoenix at a price tag of $275 million. Lincoln later sold a 45 percent interest in the Phoenician and another hotel in Phoenix to Kuwait for $170 million. Keating estimated that Lincoln's interest in hotel is now worth $190 million, almost double $99 million asset value listed by government regulators on their books. ``It's a complete misunderstanding of value to write that hotel down,'' he said. ``Resorts are a highly salable commodity in the world today. It just hurts me. I think they're going to give it away,''

DOC.HEAD: California Puts Cigarette Tax Money to Work In Massive Anti-Smoking Push
DOC.TEXT: State officials on Tuesday unveiled a multimillion-dollar ad campaign, financed by a cigarette tax, that they hope will get 75 percent of California's smokers to quit by the year 2000. Smokers are footing the bill for the $28.6 million propaganda blitz with tobacco taxes levied under Proposition 99, passed by California voters last year. Beginning Wednesday, anti-smoking ads will waft across television and radio airwaves and pop up in newspapers and on billboards throughout the state, said Dr. Kenneth Kizer, head of the state Department of Health Services. The television ads will offer such vignettes as a rap singer rapping about the dangers of smoking and a group of actors playing sleazy tobacco executives plotting to addict people to their product. Kizer said the 15-month ad campaign represents by far the biggest volley ever fired by the anti-smoking camp in its war against the powerful tobacco industry. ``The average state spends about $100,000 a year on anti-tobacco messages and education,'' he said. ``There is nothing out there that even comes close to this.'' But he also cautioned against raising expectations too high, saying the $28.6 million figure is only a fraction of what the tobacco industry spends each year on its pro-smoking campaigns. ``The 1988 preliminary figures indicate they spent $3.2 billion for advertising and promotion of tobacco,'' he said. Still, Kizer said, he hopes the ad campaign, coupled with educational efforts, will result in a 20 percent decrease in smoking by June 1991 and a 75 percent reduction by 2000. He said about 24 percent of California's 29 million residents are smokers. Later plans call for dividing $140 million in Proposition 99 funds between public schools and health agencies that would develop educational programs about the hazards of smoking. Kizer acknowledged, however, that the massive anti-smoking effort could prompt a massive backlash from the well-heeled tobacco industry. ``I think we'll have to just wait and see how they respond,'' he said. ``If we're successful, if we do what we hope, I think they're definitely going to respond. But I'm not sure how.'' Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute in Washington, D.C., said the industry group is also taking a wait-and-see attitude. ``We have not seen the advertisements, we were not shown them in advance,'' she said. ``But in terms of a counter effort, no, we have no intentions at this time of interfering with the process.'' No matter how the industry reacts, Kizer said it's time people got the truth about tobacco and what it does to one's health. Smoking is associated with an increased risk of heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure, emphysema and several types of cancer. Not only is smoking deadly, Kizer said, but the tobacco industry's ad campaigns deliberately exploit young people and immigrant groups who have little information about its hazards. Ms. Dawson denied that the industry tries to lure teen-agers, but said it believes adults should have the right to smoke.

DOC.HEAD: Armitage Named To Lead Talks On Philippine Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf, `The selection ...' to UPDATE with date talks are to begin.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush named former Assistant Defense Secretary Richard L. Armitage on Tuesday to represent the United States in long-delayed talks on the uncertain future of U.S. bases in the Philippines. The selection of Armitage, a specialist on Asian affairs, will enable negotiations to begin on May 14, U.S. officials said. U.S. leases expire next year on Clark Air Base and on Subic Naval Base _ the two largest U.S. military bases overseas _ and on four smaller bases. The talks will be conducted amid rising rising anti-American sentiment in the Philippines. American officials have said they would like to retain the bases, but are prepared to abandon them if the opposition is overwhelming or the price for new leases too high. Armitage, 44, is a former assistant defense secretary for international affairs. In announcing the appointment, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the U.S. military bases in the Philippines ``contribute to the security of the Philippines, the United States and other countries in the region.'' It is the third high-level job over the past year that Armitage has been offered. Bush first selected Armitage to be assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney prevailed on him to stay in the Defense Department. Then, Bush selected Armitage to be army secretary. But before the nomination could acted on by the Senate, Armitage withdrew his name and left government service in June 1989, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family. In his Defense Department job, a position he held throughout the Reagan administration, Armitage played a major role in policy-making in the Persian Gulf, the ouster of Philippine leader Ferdinand Marcos and in overseeing foreign military assistance programs. A senior Pentagon official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Philippines have agreed to proceed with the talks and that Armitage's longtime knowledge of Asia would help get the negotiations moving. Philippine President Corazon Aquino has expressed unhappiness over a $96 million cut Congress made in the Bush administration's request of $360 million to compensate the Philippines for the use of the sites. Preliminary talks on the bases had been scheduled to start last December, but were put off after a coup attempt against the Aquino government. Some Philippine political leaders have suggested that the United States pay annual fees upwards of $2 billion to renew the leases _ a price U.S. officials have suggested is too steep.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins In Second McMartin Pre-School Trial
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES (AP)_ The second trial of Raymond Buckey in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case began Tuesday after the defendant received an extra lawyer and nearly 300 prospective jurors were summoned. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg convened court in the jury assembly room rather than the courtroom because of the large number of prospects. After he told the 287 panelists that Buckey's trial would last at least through the year, all but 90 indicated it would be a hardship to serve so long. The 90 who did not claim a hardship were given questionnaires to determine how much they knew about the case and whether they had opinions about Buckey's guilt or innocence. The others were given questionnaires to determine whether they should be dismissed because of hardship. Jury selection began after a court session to resolve a dispute over delays caused by a back problem suffered by Buckey's longtime attorney, Danny Davis. Davis says he suffers from a herniated spinal disk and had previously sought a delay in the case to have back surgery. On Monday he agreed to try proceeding but jury selection never got under way. He hobbled into court Tuesday leaning heavily on a cane. He said he reinjured a chronic back problem last weekend and is undergoing physical therapy. Attorney John Wagner, who represented Buckey's sister in a successful fight to win back her teaching credentials, was named co-counsel to help Davis through the trial. The 31-year-old Buckey has been a defendant for nearly seven years. He was acquitted of 40 molestation charges Jan. 18, and his mother was acquitted of 12 charges. But prosecutors decided to retry Buckey on eight counts unresolved by the jury. The first trial of Buckey and his mother lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million _ the longest, costliest criminal trial in U.S. history.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Pilots Accused of Flying Drunk Plead Innocent
DOC.TEXT: Three Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying while intoxicated pleaded innocent in federal court on Tuesday. U.S. Magistrate J. Earl Cudd set a trial date of June 11 for Capt. Norman Prouse, 1st Officer Robert Kirchner and flight engineer Joseph Balzer. U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum will preside over the trial. The pilots were arrested at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport on March 8 following a dawn flight from Fargo, N.D. They were accused of drinking at a Fargo bar late the night before. Northwest fired the three, and the Federal Aviation Administration revoked their licenses. Felony indictments for operating a common carrier under the influence of alcohol were returned April 4 against Prouse, of Conyers, Ga.; Kirchner, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; and Balzer, of Antioch, Tenn. A single trial is scheduled, although the attorney for Balzer said he would try to get his client a separate trial. The three face misdemeanor charges in North Dakota and are scheduled to appear in Cass County Court in Fargo on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Ask Sullivan To Overturn Rule On Disabled Poor
DOC.TEXT: Seventeen senators are asking Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan to overturn a new rule that could deny Medicaid benefits to some of the disabled poor. In a letter to Sullivan, the senators said the rule that took effect in January ``nullifies due process rights'' of these Americans. The regulation would require most states to adopt the decision of the Social Security Administration as to whether an individual is disabled, and it would give Social Security 90 days rather than 60 days to decide. HHS estimated the rule would save $5 million annually, but the department said the purpose of the regulation is not to save money, since the savings are a small part of the $80 billion-a-year program. Rather, HHS says the changes will make the Medicaid program more efficient and effective. Previously, states could grant Medicaid coverage to low-income, disabled people even if the Social Security Administration determined that they were not disabled. Some states are more flexible than SSA in determining disability. Under the new rule, an individual who is determined by SSA not to be disabled may not apply to the state for Medicaid on the ground of disability for one year after that decision, except in certain circumstances. The senators, led by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., noted in their March 15 letter that a recent report by the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigatory arm, concluded more than half of the applicants denied disability benefits by SSA should have been granted those benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Battle among Inmates in Venezuelan Prison Kills Six Inmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with six dead, melee a prisoners' battle for leadership, not revolt, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Rival gangs of prisoners fought each other with knives and sharpened iron rods in a western Venezuela prison on Tuesday and six inmates were killed in the three-hour fracas, the warden said. Warden Miguel Garcia said by telephone that two other prisoners were badly wounded before calm was restored at Santa Ana penitentiary. Garcia said the battle was touched off ``by old feuds for leadership in the prison.'' The official news agency Venpres earlier described it as a revolt. The warden said that hundreds fought in the battle between the Llaneros, from the Venezuelan plains regions, and the Colombianos, from neighboring Colombia. ``At some point, it appeared to involve everybody in the penitentiary,'' Garcia said. During the melee, one of the fighting groups took eight prison officials hostage, including the prison director, Col. Edilio Hernandez. ``All of them were released unhurt,'' Garcia said. The penitentiary in San Cristobal, near the border with Colombia and about 500 miles from Caracas, is one of the biggest in Venezuela, holding about 2,200 inmates. An early report said the fight had broken out as a protest against the arrival of new inmates in the already overcrowded prison. It began at midmorning in a basketball court during a recreation period, according to Cpl. Jose Orlando Roldan of San Cristobal police. He said National Guardsmen had surrounded the prison. Warden Garcia said the six inmates stabbed to death belonged to the Llaneros gang, while the two injured convicts were members of the Colombianos. He gave no names.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Diplomat Found Shot to Death in Suriname
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to RECAST, minor editing thereafter. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's second-ranking diplomat in Suriname was found shot to death in a gutter Tuesday in this South American capital, police said. No group or individual claimed responsibility for the killing, and the motive was unknown. The body of Stasis Obukauskas, 41, second secretary and consul in the Soviet Embassy, was found with three bullet wounds in the head, said Inspector Ronald Gayadhar, a police spokesman. Police said Obukauskas' body was in a gutter along Kennedy Highway, the main road between Paramaribo and Zanderij International Airport. Obukauskas had been in Suriname for about 2{ years. There was no comment from the Soviet Embassy. A man who answered the telephone there Tuesday afternoon said the embassy was closed. A preliminary examination indicated Obukauskas was shot at about 1 a.m. Tuesday, police said. A blue Mazda was found abandoned nearby, police said. Obukauskas usually drove a brown Mercedes. Gayadhar said the body was found by motorists who noticed the Mazda parked partly on the highway. He said there were no bullet holes or blood stains on the vehicle, which did not have diplomatic plates. It was the first time a diplomat has been murdered in Suriname. In June, a Soviet diplomat was found hanging at his home and the death was ruled a suicide. Suriname, a former Dutch colony with a population of 400,000, has been governed by a nominal civilian government headed by President Ramsewak Shankar since 1988. The country previously was ruled by army strongman Desi Bouterse, who is now the armed forces chief and continues to wield power behind the scenes. Under the banner of the Jungle Commando, Bush Negro militants have been waging a guerrilla war on and off since August 1986. Suriname gained independence from the Netherlands in 1975. It is the only Dutch-speaking country in South America.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Dismayed By French Overtures to Libya
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of improved relations between France and Libya after the release of three European hostages drew expressions of concern and dismay from U.S. officials Tuesday. ``France is being nicer to Libya than we think they should be,'' said one U.S. official. ``We think people should be keeping the pressure on Libya.'' The officials stopped short of accusing France of making a deal with Libya for the release of the hostages, one of whom is a French citizen. Jacqueline Valente, 32, her Belgian husband and their 2-year-old daughter were released Tuesday after 2{ years of captivity. In Paris, there was no confirmation of any deal. The officials, who spoke on the condition they not be named, said the United States would prefer that France and other countries insist that Libya expel Palestinian leader Abu Nidal and his followers and stop its alleged efforts to make chemical weapons. Abu Nidal's group, the Fatah Revolutionary Council, arranged for the transfer of the hostages to French officials in Beirut. The release came a month after France returned three French-made Mirage jet fighters to Libya. The planes had been in France for repairs since 1986. The return of the planes was blocked by an embargo imposed when Libya and France backed opposing sides during the civil war in Chad. The French government thanked Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi for his role in the release and said relations with Libya would improve. Gadhafi last week called for the release of hostages as a humanitarian gesture. The U.S. officials said American diplomats have told the French they have strong opposition to negotiating with terrorists. ``Libya continues to host the Abu Nidal organization and provide it with support. We have repeatedly called on Libya to expel this group and end Libyan support for terrorism,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. As for Gadhafi, Ms. Tutwiler said, ``people everywhere should do what they can to end the barbaric practice of hostage taking. Basic civilized behavior requires nothing less.'' Ms. Tutwiler noted that the 18 American and other Western hostages in Lebanon are being held by pro-Iranian groups and reaffirmed U.S. opposition to negotiating with hostage-takers.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Said to Confirm Presidential Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Walesa running for Solidarity post, INSERTS 3 grafs after graf 10 pvs, `Kaczynski said...'; pickup 11th pvs, `Jaruzelski was...' ^By JOHN DANISZEWSKI
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa was quoted Tuesday as saying he will run for president in the next election. The report by the government news agency PAP could not immediately be confirmed with Walesa or his spokesman. Aides and colleagues of the Solidarity leader have long been saying he is considering a presidential bid. Jaroslaw Kaczynski, a close associate of Walesa's and editor of the Solidarity Weekly newspaper, said the leader's comments to PAP should only be ``understood as a general declaration, not connected with present events.'' ``I confirm,'' PAP quoted Walesa as saying when asked if he would run for president. ``We have many wise and valuable people in government, holding various posts. However, one must speed up the pace of reforms and destroy the old arrangements.'' President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the general and former Communist Party leader elected by Parliament in July, officially is to serve a six-year term until 1995. However, there is widespread belief that the next presidential election will be moved up as part of an overhaul of the Polish Constitution. The most likely time for elections appears to be spring 1991, when Poland would be marking the 200th anniversary of its first written constitution. Nothing in his remarks on PAP indicated when Walesa thought the election might be, and Kaczynski suggested the leader was not talking about an immediate presidential campaign. ``Nobody is talking about the date for elections or about starting any procedures,'' he said. ``He just states the certain fact'' that he will run when Jaruzelski leaves offices. ``This should be understood as a general declaration, not connected with current events,'' Kaczynski added. Kaczynski said Walesa is committed to winning re-election as Solidarity's chairman next week, when the union holds its first national congress in nine years. ``I will run in the election and you know that when I run I want to win,'' Walesa told the Solidarity Executive Commission on Tuesday in Gdansk. ``And I count on your support.'' Walesa is expected to be challenged by union members who feel Solidarity has strayed from its ideals of 1980, putting politics ahead of trade-union goals like defending workers' interests. A long-time Walesa critic, Marian Jurczyk of Szczecin, has formed a rival faction called Solidarity '80. Jaruzelski was elected president at a time when Poland was the only East bloc country to have a legal opposition and to be making such bold moves toward democracy. Jaruzelski was to serve as a guarantee to the Soviet Union and Poland's Warsaw Pact allies that Poland would do nothing to upset the East bloc alliance. However, that purpose has changed with the fall of communists from power in all six Warsaw Pact countries except the Soviet Union. More radical reformers in Poland feel it is time to oust Jaruzelski in order to speed up changes in the country. Jaruzelski also has his advocates in the Solidarity-led government and Parliament. They feel that as president, he has behaved with restraint and shown good cooperation with Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki. Elections now would be a divisive distraction from coping with the country's pressing economic problems, they say.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Give Airspace Over Seven Cities Critical `Black Star' Rating
DOC.TEXT: International pilots will be warned that safety in the skies over seven U.S. cities is critically deficient due to a change in air traffic control rules, the Air Line Pilots Association announced Tuesday. The Federal Aviation Administration, which changed the rules two years ago, defended the procedures, saying they have brought ``no accidents and no close calls.'' Airspace over Charlotte, N.C., Cleveland, Dallas-Fort Worth, Los Angeles, Memphis, Philadelphia and Phoenix was added to the international ``black star'' list of airports and airspace that could pose problems for pilots. Only one other U.S. site is among 23 other locations on the list _ the Cyril E. King International Airport in St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands. Surrounding terrain requires special training and no night flights, according to pilot groups. ALPA announced the new list after the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations added the seven U.S. airspaces to its list. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said the pilots' complaints arise from a test that has been going on since 1987 in Terminal Control Areas over the seven airports. In 20 other sectors over major U.S. airports, controllers must maintain a separation of three miles between all aircraft. At the seven cities, Farrar said, controllers under limited circumstances need not comply with any set separation between aircraft as long as they are kept safely apart. The new standard, called ``conflict resolution,'' has been used in the vast airspaces between airports for six years, Farrar said, also without any accidents or close calls. The ``conflict resolution'' procedure is only allowed during clear weather when one plane is flying by instruments and the pilot of the second plane is relying on what he sees out the window, Farrar said. ALPA said the ``black star'' designation, formally known as the Critically Deficient list, does not indicate unsafe conditions but is viewed as ``a serious deficiency in our nation's aviation safety structure'' about which unfamiliar pilots should be warned. ``The added risks, coupled with the inability to measure any gains in efficiency, make this a highly questionable exercise by the FAA,'' said ALPA President Henry Duffy. He said the FAA benefits from the new system because it reduces the number of reportable operational errors, making the skies appear to be safer. No longer do all violations of the three-mile separation have to be reported, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Police Free Two Hostages, Three Gunmen Dead
DOC.TEXT: State troopers stormed an apartment building in southeastern Brazil on Tuesday, killing a gunman who had been holding a woman and her baby hostage, police said. Two other kidnappers were killed earlier. ``The hostages are in perfect health,'' said Capt. Hermann Silveira from Vitoria, a city 315 miles north of Rio de Janeiro. Silveira said the two accomplices died after they were wounded in a shootout while trying to flee. He said police then decided to storm the building because they feared for the hostages' lives. The episode began Sunday night, when the three armed men drove past a Vitoria bar and riddled it with bullets, Silveira said. No one was reported injured. Military police in Vitoria say the three gunmen had connections with organized crime and were probably involved in a mob hit. On Monday, police found the men at the apartment building where they lived. But the suspects spotted the officers and took their two neighbors hostage, Silveira said.

DOC.HEAD: Census Response Reaches 50 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Half of America has already stood up to be counted. The Census Bureau reported Tuesday that the response rate for its 1990 national head count has reached 50 percent. ``We expect the number to grow,'' said spokeswoman Paulette Lichtman-Panzer, noting that the halfway mark was reached last Friday. And that response rate counted only forms that have been ``logged in'' by census offices across the nation, she said. Many places have a backlog of returns waiting to be checked in. The Bureau mailed out 88 million forms on March 23 and hand delivered an additional 11 million to homes where proper mailing addresses could not be obtained. In addition, census takers are working with postal officials to correct problems in several communities where forms could not be delivered for one reason or another, officials said. ``If anyone has put off answering the census, now's the time to do so,'' said Lichtman-Panzer, stressing the need to increase the mail response rate. Census officials have told Congress that they hope for a 70 percent response rate. Sending workers out to count those who do not answer the mailed request costs an estimated $10 million for every percentage point, officials have estimated. Census offices will begin sending out workers April 26 to homes where no form has been sent back, said Lichtman-Panzer. They will try to interview the residents to get the necessary information. In some cases, she pointed out, homes are vacant or may have been torn down, resulting in no form being returned. While half the census forms are now back, tabulating the information they contain will take months. The first results of the census, population totals for each state, will be reported on Dec. 31 and more detailed information will follow after the first of the year. The total cost of the census is expected to reach $2.5 billion. The national head count is conducted every 10 years. It is required by the Constitution to produce population totals used in reapportioning seats in the House of Representatives. In addition, census population totals are used in dividing up billions of dollars in federal funds for state and local governments.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Warn of New Fighting If Contras Don't Demobilize Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with U.N. troops arriving from Venezuela in Honduras, INSERTS 3 grafs after 13th pvs, `On Monday'; pickup 14th pvs, `Monday's accord...' ^By DORALISA PILARTE
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Sandinistas said Tuesday new fighting could break out because an agreement between the newly elected government and Contra rebels failed to set a deadline for the rebels to disarm. The Sandinista party newspaper Barricada and the pro-Sandinista daily El Nuevo Diario ran editorials and stories dismissing the accord as a rebel ploy to gain time and influence before the April 25 change of government. The accord was reached Monday. They also accused the rebels and the United National Opposition of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of trying to take over the Sandinista People's Army. ``The People Ask That The EPS Act!!!,'' said El Nuevo Diario in a front-page headline, referring to the Sandinista army by its Spanish initials. It added in a subhead: ``Either The Contra Is Wiped Out or They'll Wipe Out Everything.'' Outgoing leftist President Daniel Ortega, defeated by Mrs. Chamorro in elections Feb. 25, was quoted by El Nuevo Diario as saying that the Contras, in collusion with ``extremist sectors'' of the pro-U.S. United National Opposition, were adopting a hard line about demobilizing. This, Ortega was quoted as saying, ``is a point that worries us and obliges us to maintain ourselves alert.'' In an editorial titled ``The First Test of the New Government,'' Barricada said ``there is nothing to discuss with the Contras,'' save their demobilization by April 25. That is when Mrs. Chamorro takes office for a six-year term. ``The intransigent attitude assumed by some Contra ringleaders and extremist (UNO) politicians ... is placing the nation in a very dangerous situation,'' the editorial said. ``Unless this situation is resolved in the briefest term ... all the efforts for peace and reconciliation could ... revert into a fresh outbreak of the war,'' the editorial added. Barricada's editorials are considered the official Sandinista party line. The war between the Contras and the Sandinistas has killed an estimated 30,000 people since it began in 1981, two years after the Sandinistas came to power in a revolution that toppled rightist dictator Anastasio Somoza. An estimated 9,000 Contras based in Honduras have moved back to Nicaragua. On Monday, negotiators for the Contras and UNO said rebels in camps at Yamales, in the Honduran jungle near the Nicaraguan border, would be the first to turn in their weapons. They said the surrender of weapons would begin April 18. A contingent of 170 Venezuelan troops arrived Tuesday in Honduras to strengthen a United Nations force of observers, who are to supervise the disbandment in Honduras and Nicaragua. Gen. Agustin Quesada Gomez, their Spanish commander, said Venezuela will send a total of 700 soldiers. They will be joined by troops from several other countries. The observers will supervise the disarmament of the rebels at Yamales and the concentration of Contras in predetermined ``safety zones'' inside Nicaragua once the U.N. peacekeeping force can ensure a cease-fire. Monday's accord in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, also calls for a Contra commission to go to Managua before April 18 ``to speed up the demobilization'' but it did not set a deadline for completion. Contra leaders have been issuing conflicting signals, saying they would demobilize in support of Mrs. Chamorro's new government, but also saying they do not trust the Sandinistas. Forcing the Contras to demobilize by April 25 would amount to a moral victory for the Sandinistas. But none of the accords the rebels signed requires them to disband by that date.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item on Siskel and Ebert to CORRECT title of show to ``Siskel & Ebert & The Movies,'' sted ``At the Movies.
DOC.TEXT: Twentieth Century Fox has lifted its ban against critics Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel, who gave harsh reviews of a recent Fox film. The studio said three weeks ago that Ebert and Siskel would be barred indefinitely from preview screenings after both critics said on a television talk show that the comedy ``Nuns on the Run'' wasn't funny. But Siskel called Fox shortly before a Monday screening of another Fox film and asked if he was still unwelcome. It was the first Fox screening here since ``Nuns on the Run.'' The ban was over, a company spokesman said, and Siskel went to the show. Ebert didn't know about the lifting of the ban and was out of town. ``I'm happy the ban is lifted,'' Ebert said. ``I feel vindicated. In the future I will continue to review Fox films in the same evenhanded way I have in the past. ``The only thing I'm disappointed about is that I had predicted the ban would last only one film and Roger had predicted it would last none,'' Siskel said. ``Roger was right and he's going to be hard to deal with when he gets home.'' The two appear on ``Siskel & Ebert & The Movies,'' a syndicated half-hour television show.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Firm Agrees To Divest Diamond Drill Bit Business
DOC.TEXT: A Houston firm agreed to divest its diamond drill bit business to avoid a Justice Department antitrust suit over its proposed $550 million purchase of a Salt Lake City company, according to court papers filed Tuesday. The Justice Department simultaneously filed the antitrust suit challenging the proposed acquisition of Eastman Christensen Co. of Salt Lake City by Baker Hughes Inc. of Houston, along with a consent decree settling the suit. Diamond drill bits are used to drill for oil and gas, and both companies are large, diversified suppliers of a wide variety of oil field products and services. The two companies are major manufacturers of three types of diamond drill bits: natural diamond bits; synthetic diamond bits called polycrystalline diamond compact bits; and thermally stable synthetic polycrystalline diamond bits. In the United States last year, sales of the three types of diamond drill bits totaled more than $30 million. Baker Hughes accounted for about 15 percent, or $4.6 million, and Eastman Christensen accounted for about 25 percent, or $7.7 million, according to the Justice Department. Worldwide, Baker Hughes earned about $18 million of its total sales of $2.3 billion from its diamond drill bit business, the department said. For Eastman Christensen, worldwide diamond drill bit sales accounted for $35 million of its $211 million total sales. The antitrust suit filed in U.S. District Court in the District of Columbia alleged that the proposed acquisition would hamper competitiveness in the U.S. market for those three types of drill bits. ``The divestiture will ensure that the merger of Baker Hughes and Eastman Christensen will not raise the cost of drilling for oil and gas in the United States,'' James F. Rill, assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, said in a statement. Under the consent decree, Baker Hughes must divest its entire diamond drill bit business, including foreign and domestic facilities, by Aug. 6, or a trustee will be appointed to carry out the divestiture, the department said. Baker Hughes' diamond drill bit business includes its patents, manufacturing facilities in Houston; Aberdeen, Scotland; and Escobar, Argentina; and a research and development center.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Do Anti-Drug Commercial
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, are helping to promote an upcoming TV cartoon that will feature an anti-drug message for children. The White House, making the announcement during Bush's trip to Canada, said Tuesday that the Bushes taped a public service ad promoting the special, ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue.'' The animated show will be simultaneously aired April 21 by ABC, NBC and CBS _ a first in programming. It also will be shown on cable. The commercial will run before the program. The program features Bugs Bunny, Alf, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Winnie the Pooh, the Smurfs, Garfield, Daffy Duck and other cartoon characters. In the message, Mrs. Bush calls the program ``the powerful story of a teen-ager dealing with drug and alcohol abuse'' and tells children to ``make the right decision _ stay away from drugs and alcohol.'' ``Some of your favorite cartoon characters are going to help you understand how drug and alcohol can ruin your life,'' the president says. ``So, watch the program. Talk about it with your family.''

DOC.HEAD: Severe Thunderstorms in South-Central, Rain Across East
DOC.TEXT: Rain and storms stretched from Texas to New England on Tuesday after a night of thunderstorms and tornadoes that caused damage and one death in the southern Plains. Thunderstorms moving out of the central High Plains into the lower and middle Mississippi Valley produced severe weather during the night in Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas and Arkansas, the National Weather Service said. In Oklahoma, severe storms killed the pilot of a small plane, injured at least five people and damaged more than a dozen houses late Monday and early Tuesday. Much of the damage came when a tornado cut a swath from Lone Grove to Ardmore. Ten houses and five mobile homes were damaged and a barn was tossed into the middle of a city street, authorities said. Also in Oklahoma, Cherokee and Haskell county officials reported 60 mph winds early Tuesday, and officials said power lines were blown down near the Haskell County town of Kinta. Kiowa County reported 65-mph winds south of Snyder. A storm in Rogers County, Okla., had ``lots of lightning ... blinding rain,'' said Sheriff Buck Johnson. He said the wind blew his van into a ditch while he was driving to the site of the fatal plane crash. Strong thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds across parts of northern Texas early Tuesday, along with at least one report of a tornado. Hail almost the size of golf balls was reported in Gainesville, with wind up to 60 mph tearing roofs from several homes and breaking windows, the weather service said. Thunderstorms spawned several tornadoes in south-central Kansas late Monday, the weather service said. Hail as big as baseballs was reported east of Halmstead, Kan. Heavier rainfall totals overnight included 2.65 inches at Wesley, Ark., 2.28 inches at Joplin, Mo., and 2.25 inches at Grandfield, Okla. Tuesday afternoon, rain developed along and ahead of a cold front stretching from south central Texas to New England. Thunderstorms with locally heavy rain extended from southeastern Texas to western Kentucky. Light snow fell on northern Maine. A winter storm watch was in effect into Wednesday. Light snow also was reported in Wyoming, Nebraska and the Dakotas. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 20s and lower 30s from the northern high Plains to northern Minnesota. Temperatures early Tuesday dipped below freezing in the Great Basin that includes Nevada and western Utah, and from the northern and central Rockies to Upper Michigan. Readings dropped below 20 degrees overnight in Montana and western North Dakota. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 22 degrees at Cut Bank, Mont., to 91 at Gila Bend, Ariz. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 4 degrees in Cut Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Couple and Child Freed by Abu Nidal Group, Flown to France
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with color at airport, Bush quotes, U.S. officials critical of France; pickup 11th pvs `The release...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAR1,PAR1, BEI1
DOC.TEXT: The Libyan-backed Palestinian group headed by Abu Nidal freed a French woman, a Belgian man and their young daughter Tuesday after holding them for nearly 2{ years. The three arrived to the cheers of a crowd of relatives and French officials at a military airport outside Paris late Tuesday after a five-hour flight from Beirut. They had been dropped off at the French Embassy in the morning by masked gunmen who arrived in cars with drawn curtains. Jacqueline Valente, 32, Fernand Houtekins, 43, and their 2-year-old daughter Sophie-Liberte, born in captivity, made no public statements though the couple smiled as they got off the plane. They were taken to a military hospital to spend their first night in freedom after 882 days' captivity. Abu Nidal's group announced Nov. 8, 1987, it had seized the hostages from the French yacht Silco in the Mediterranean off the Gaza Strip. It accused them of collaborating with Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. Friends said the group was on a holiday cruise. The French government thanked Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi for his role in the release and said relations with Libya would improve. Gadhafi last week called for the release of hostages as a humanitarian gesture. President Bush, in Toronto, said he didn't know enough about the release to say whether Gadhafi deserves any credit. ``We've got some major differences with Libya that continue to exist, but look, who am I to argue in this case if someone can help free one hostage? ... Give that person credit,'' Bush said. The hostages, released by the Fatah-Revolutionary Council, used an executive jet in Beirut provided by the French government to fly to Villacoublay near Paris. Ms. Valente was the first to disembark, followed by Houtekins, holding their daughter in his arms. All appeared healthy. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council has been blamed for scores of terrorist acts, including the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people. Because the hostages were believed to have been held in Libya, the case is considered unrelated to the 18 Westerners, including eight Americans, held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. However, Fatah spokesman Walid Khaled denied assertions that the hostages had been held in Libya. Speaking at a news conference in Beirut, he said the hostages had been kept in Lebanon. The State Department welcomed the release and called for freeing of other captives. However, U.S. officials in Washington were critical of France's warm words for Gadhafi. The officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said France and other countries should press Libya to expel Abu Nidal and his group and stop alleged efforts to make chemical weapons. ``France is being nicer to Libya than we think they should be,'' said one U.S. official. The release came a month after France returned to Libya three French-made Mirage jet fighters that had been in France for repairs since 1986. The return of the planes was blocked by an embargo imposed when Libya and France backed opposing sides during the civil war in Chad. In December, Libya, pressing for delivery of the aircraft, closed its ports to French ships. Gadhafi said Tuesday that Abu Nidal's group was ``distancing'' itself from its terrorist reputation by releasing the hostages, Libya's official news agency JANA reported. Last week, Gadhafi urged the release of hostages in the Middle East as a gesture for Ramadan, the Islamic holy month. He singled out Ms. Valente. Gadhafi has supported Abu Nidal, who along with some of his followers has been convicted of terrorist attacks abroad. The Libyan leader is believed to have allowed him to live near the Libyan capital, Tripoli. Houtekins said after his release that four members of his family still held by the terrorist group are well. ``They have morale. They are holding firm,'' he said, adding, ``We expected our freedom, we knew it was coming one day. The day of our freedom has arrived. For those who stay behind, we keep hoping.'' ``I embrace all my family. I am well, and the little one also,'' Ms. Valente told French reporters. Only two French news organizations were given access to the hostages. The hostages refused to discuss conditions of their captivity or where they were held. They did not mention a second child born in captivity in 1989. French Ambassador Rene Ala said Ms. Valente told him the boy died recently of problems with his digestive system. A police spokesman said French officials ``apparently had advance notice of the release. Ala was waiting at a cement outpost manned by French Marine guards near the main gate'' of the West Beirut compound. In Beirut, the Fatah-Revolutionary spokesman said, ``Direct talks between our movement and the French side have resulted in an agreement on their release.'' Khaled did not elaborate. There was no evidence of any deal, but French President Francois Mitterrand personally thanked Gadhafi for ``the determining role he played in the happy ending of this affair.'' Foreign Minister Roland Dumas praised what he called Gadhafi's ``noble'' gesture. ``(The release's) real value will be appreciated in the future of relations between France and Libya,'' Dumas said without elaborating. In Brussels, Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said he hoped the release ``can be considered as a testimony of good faith concerning the release of the other'' hostages. The Abu Nidal group still holds Houtekins' brother Emmanuel, and Emmanuel's wife and teen-age daughter and son. The group linked freedom for them to the release of Nasser Sa'eed, a Palestinian serving a life term in Belgium for a June 1980 grenade attack on Jewish youths in Antwerp. The Belgian government has not responded to the offer. Two other daughters of Ms. Valente were freed as a result of Libyan intervention on Dec. 29, 1988. In France, Jacqueline's mother Brigitte Valente said Tuesday: ``The nightmare is over and I'm trembling with joy. I can't even talk. It's too beautiful.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Reforms To Be Decided This Week
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday he and senior government advisers will agree before the end of the week on a much-anticipated program of radical economic reform. He said he wants to quicken the pace for overhauling the economy. His announcement came as senior Soviet officials debate whether to initiate Polish-style economic shock therapy here that would free prices and sharply increase unemployment while slashing the value of the ruble. The officials have cautioned, however, that the government will be able to go only as fast as angry and disillusioned consumers allow. On Tuesday, Gorbachev told a congress of the Komsomol Communist youth group, ``Analyzing the situation, we came to the conclusion that it is necessary to speed up economic reform. Already this year and at the beginning of next year, we will take the basic steps in this direction that were planned for 1992-1993.'' Gorbachev said the Presidential Council and the Council of the Federation _ two new advisory groups formed after he took office last month as the country's first executive president _ will meet Saturday to decide on proposals from government ministers to put reforms into effect. Soviet leaders want to boost industrial production and remedy perennial shortages of a range of consumer goods. Gorbachev said the proposals will be presented for public debate before they go into effect. He did not go into particulars. One day earlier, Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin dodged questions on the details of economic reform at a news conference, creating the impression the government still had not decided many questions. Abalkin also said public worries about rising prices and unemployment were a key factor. ``A speedy transition to a market economy will come up against powerful opposition,'' he said. ``What we must do first is to make all people understand and see clearly that without such a transition the country has no future as a highly developed great power,'' Abalkin said. In Bonn, West Germany, on Monday, the Soviets pledged in an international accord to support free-market economic policies. The Soviet economy is now stalled somewhere between central planning and free markets. On Tuesday, the Soviets asked the Western nations in Bonn for the Conference on Economic Cooperation in Europe to ease limits on the sale of high-technology goods to the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Gadhafi For Role In Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday complimented Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi for an apparently positive role in the release of three European hostages but said major differences with Libya remain. Bush said he didn't know if the release had implications for U.S. hostages being held, but called anew for their release as ``a manifestation of good will.'' The president, during a question-and-answer session with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, was asked about the action by a Libyan-backed Palestinian group in freeing a French woman, a Belgian man and their young daughter Tuesday after holding them for nearly 2{ years. The three arrived in Paris on Tuesday after a five-hour flight from Beirut, where they had been dropped off at the French Embassy by masked gunmen. Gadhafi last week called for the release of hostages as a humanitarian gesture. ``Look, who am I to argue on this case? If somebody can help free one hostage, any person held against his or her will, give that person credit,'' Bush said. ``A person deserves credit for facilitating the release of people held against their will anywhere in the world, I would certainly say fine, give the person credit,'' Bush said, while saying he didn't ``know enough about the facts of this release.'' ``If this individual, Col. Gadhafi, had a part in it, I would say that's very positive. But we've got some major diffences with Libya that continue to exist,'' Bush said. The president said said he did not know whether the release ``has any implications at all'' as it related to the eight U.S. hostages in Lebanon, including Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who has been held more than five years. ``A few weeks ago, there was a flurry of understandable excitement about the release of these people,'' Bush said. ``And I had difficulty understanding where was all this coming from? What's driving this news flurry?'' ``And I still don't know the answer to that.'' But, he added, ``I would just repeat that good will begets good will. And a manifestation of good will would be the rlease of these American hostages.''

DOC.HEAD: Arsonist Sought as U.S. Expert Notes Fire Hit Same Ship in 1988
