DOC.TEXT: Police searched files of known arsonists Tuesday and explored the black shell of the ferry Scandinavian Star for clues to the fire that killed about 200 people _ two years after there was a blaze on board the same vessel. Investigators in Sweden's west coast port of Lysekil said entire decks were burned of everything combustible, and it may be impossible to pinpoint physical evidence on how the weekend fire began. In Oslo, Norwegian police who took charge of the case said they were looking for one or more arsonists, but added that the firebug could have been among the victims of the flames that engulfed the 10,500-ton ship en route from Norway to Denmark. Allan Pollock, spokesman for the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board, said Tuesday in Washington that the vessel's owners failed to respond to any of the board's recommendations after a non-fatal March 15, 1988, engine-room fire on the Scandinavian Star off Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. The chairman of the NTSB, James Kolstad, said, ``It is ironic that many of the problems the board cited in its investigation of a fire aboard the same vessel two years ago are being reported by survivors of the North Sea fire.'' Kolstad, in an interview Tuesday, said he was sending an investigator to act as an observer in the investigation. An American entertainer on the ship, Ruth E. Rome of East Lansing, Mich., was among the presumed dead. After the first fire, the board recommended increased crew training, more life vests on the deck, smoke detectors, modifications to prevent smoke from traveling through air ventilation systems and other steps to improve safety. The Danish-based Da-No Line bought the 20-year-old Scandinavian Star last month from SeaEscape of Miami. The ship was registered in the Bahamas and had been working the Norway-Denmark line for one week. Oslo's assistant police chief, Magnar Aukrust, said Tuesday, ``I believe we will be able to discover whoever was behind the fire. We have some detailed information.'' Aukrust said about a third of the rescued passengers and crew have been questioned so far. His deputy, Arne Huuse, said, ``We have no specific ... suspect. But suspicions of arson were strengthened by the technical investigation on board.'' Oslo police will publish a list of 186 people considered missing of the estimated 534 people who boarded the ship. Figures changed as people considered missing reported in, said Oystein Berger, a senior police officer. Police opened the final cabins for inspection Tuesday, three days after the smoldering ship was towed into port. Officers said the devastation will make it hard to identify the victims, or even count them accurately. More than 120 bodies were recovered. ``The bodies left on board are so badly burned you can put them in a teacup,'' said Police Inspector Leif Skoglund. ``I went on the ship this afternoon. It was terrible.'' About 20 bodies lay in corridors, people who succumbed to the smoke as they tried to flee. ``A lot of people hid in the shower or the toilet,'' Skoglund said. ``In one toilet a policeman who tried to count the bodies couldn't tell if there was one or four.'' Skoglund said the temperature in midships cabins reached 572 degrees. ``It destroyed everything.'' Members of the royal family, Prime Minister Jan P. Syse and U.S. Ambassador Loret Miller Ruppe led about 1,000 people who attended a state memorial service in Oslo's main cathedral. Witnesses said one fire began some time after 2 a.m. Saturday, but that the fire alarm sounded only at 2:30 a.m. Investigators said at least two fires were started independently, supporting the theory that an arsonist was to blame. Marine experts from Norway, Sweden and Denmark gathered in Copenhagen to discuss tightening safety regulations, especially on board foreign-registered vessels. Danish Industry Minister Anne Lundholt said the commission also would consider requiring full passenger lists for the ferries and ways to improve emergency training. A separate maritime inquiry was due to start in the Danish capital on Wednesday. News reports in Denmark said the Scandinavian Star received a clean bill of health from an inspection in January by Lloyd's Register in Miami, where it was then owned by SeaEscape. In 1988, a crew member discovered an engine-room fire aboard the Scandinavian Star as it was returning from Cozumel, Mexico, to its Tampa home port with 439 passengers, mostly Americans. Smoke detectors apparently failed, as did an automatic system to douse flames. The emergency generators didn't work for an hour, leaving the vessel without power in rough seas in the Yucatan Channel, according to NTSB reports released as the agency's three-day hearing opened in Miami in June 1988. ``Although there were no injuries or deaths, the failure of the vessel's safety systems highlights the potential for a catastrophic loss of life in this accident and future vessel fires,'' Jim Burnett, chairman of the NTSB, said then.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Protests Killing of American by Liberian Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No hometown in Kentucky given
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Tuesday protested the death an American who died in surgery from a leg wound he suffered after being shot by Liberian troops. The U.S. Embassy said Martin Joseph Millay of Kentucky was on the campus of a Roman Catholic school last Friday when troops fired at Millay's car at a roadblock. The embassy's statement disputed Liberia's claim that the shooting occurred outside the residence of President Samuel Doe. A Liberian spokeswoman said the government deeply regretted the incident, addign that the soldiers involved have been arrested and face a court martial. Relations between the United States and the West African nation have been strained since a fire last month destroyed several million dollars worth of goods at two U.S. Embassy warehouses. American aid to Liberia has been sharply reduced. Liberia was founded in 1847 by freed American slaves. It is the biggest recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa and is the only West African nation that routinely allows U.S. military planes to refuel on its territory.

DOC.HEAD: Two Prisoners Surrender at Strangeways
DOC.TEXT: Two prisoners surrendered at Strangeways Prison on Tuesday, leaving no more than 20 inmates continuing a standoff that began April 1 as a riot over crowded living conditions, authorities said. Several inmates who surrendered earlier claimed they had seen dead bodies in the badly-damaged cell blocks, but one of those who surrendered Tuesday insisted there had been no deaths. ``He is absolutely certain that there are no dead bodies at all in Strangeways,'' said attorney Charles Peter, who did not identify his 24-year-old client. Earlier, two prison officers were injured by objects thrown by inmates. One was admitted to a hospital with bruises and a suspected cracked rib, the Home Office said. Hundreds of prisoners rioted over a week ago in the overcrowded prison, which was heavily damaged when inmates set fires and hurled roof tiles at guards and firefighters. The government on Sunday said it was too dangerous to forcibly end the siege because of the condition of the largely demolished prison buildings. Government officials said Strangeways disturbance sparked unrest at eight other prisons in England and Wales on Sunday, ranging from a sitdown protest at Leeds Jail to rioting at Dartmoor prison.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Soviet Communists Hint at Expulsion of Radicals
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party's policy-making Central Committee accused a radical faction on Tuesday of trying to split the party and indicated its members could be expelled. It said in its statement that the Democratic Platform _ a group that includes populist Boris N. Yeltsin, historian Yuri Afanasiev and economist Gavriil Popov _ was trying to turn the party into a ``formless association with full freedom for factions and groups. That is, to actually break it apart.'' The Democratic Platform seeks faster and deeper political and economic reforms than President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``The time has come ... when it is necessary to work out what to do with those party members who are persistently and purposefully leading affairs to a break,'' the statement said. ``Can these kinds of people really remain in the ranks of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union?'' A party congress begins July 2. The party is trying to prevent more splits after party members in the Baltic republics of Lithuania and Estonia decided to break away and form independent parties. Democratic Platform has been debating since its formation in January whether to break with the national Communist Party to form a Social Democratic Party. Such a split could be more serious than the break with the Baltic parties. Some of the most progressive party members from across the Soviet Union would likely join the breakaway group, thereby forming a nationwide opposition. The statement of the 248-member Central Committee, a body that includes all major party leaders, said party organizations must decide whether individual Democratic Platform members should remain in the party. Gorbachev, who is both president and party leader, has pushed the Communists to accept a multiparty system but at the same time has tried to prevent a split among its 19 million members. He says party unity is necessary to carry out his reform plan. Tuesday's Central Committee attack came days after the party in the Byelorussian republic, which is known for its conservatism, gave local party organizations the power to expel members of the Democratic Platform. In an interview with the national daily Selskaya Zhizn published last weekend, Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev attacked the radicals. Ligachev, widely thought by reformers to be among the most conservative members of the party Politburo, said the Democratic Platform was reviving the social democratic parties that battled the Bolsheviks for power as the Russian Empire crumbled.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Announces Picks for Cabinet Amid Talk of Defections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Labor Cabinet members announced, Peres trying to end talk of defections; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said Tuesday he wants to serve as both prime minister and foreign minister in a proposed coalition government, but his announcement was clouded by reports that two key supporters may defect. The media reports, if true, jeopardize the Labor-led coalition's anticipated 61-59 majority in Wednesday's Parliament vote on the government. Peres tried to quell the talk of defections in an impassioned speech to Labor's 1,500-member Central Committee, which approved his party nominees for 11 Cabinet posts in the new government. ``We have the support of 61 legislators in Parliament, maybe more,'' Peres told members of his left-of-center party. Peres said all 11 Labor ministers who served in the collapsed coalition with the right-wing Likud bloc would join the new Cabinet. He added that at least four more Labor members would join at a later stage. The announcement was met by boos from party activists who had demanded fresh faces in the new government. Other parties in the new coalition would be given other ministries, Peres said. Peres, who was finance minister in the outgoing government, said he would serve as foreign minister in addition to prime minister. Labor's No. 2 leader, Yitzhak Rabin, would be defense minister. Israel radio Tuesday reported growing speculation that two legislators from the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel party would renege on their party's coalition agreement with Labor and either abstain or vote against Labor on Wednesday. If Agudat Israel legislators Avraham Verdiger and Eliezer Mizrahi abstain, Peres would still have a narrow majority. If they vote against Labor, Peres apparently would be unable to form a government. Agudat Israel has five legislators. It signed a coalition agreement with Labor last month after the deal was approved by the party's spiritual leaders, the Council of Torah Greats. Rabbi Menachem Porush, a legislator with the party, denied the speculation about the defections, saying Verdiger and Mizrahi are bound by the decision of their spiritual leaders. ``There is no doubt that the decision of the Council of the Torah Greats was accepted by all our members,'' Porush told Israel radio late Tuesday. The 61 legislators Peres has been counting on include 39 from Labor, five from Agudat Israel, five from the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement (CRM), three from the socialist Mapam Party, two from the left-wing Shinui Party, three from the communist Hadash Party, and three tiny parties with one legislator each. The 61st is Avraham Sharir, a former tourism minister who defected from the right-wing Likud bloc last week and signed a coalition agreement with Labor. Labor so far has failed to bring the Citizen's Rights Movement, Mapam and Shinui into the government. ``We are going to support the government tomorrow, but we are not going to join it because of the nature of the coalition between the Labor Party and a defector,'' Citizens Rights Movement legislator Yossi Sarid said Tuesday, referring to Sharir. ``We would join the government at a later stage when and if other legitimate parties join,'' Sarid told The Associated Press. Agudat Israel will receive the portfolios of housing and social welfare. Sharir will become minister of transportation and tourism in return for his defection from Likud. The outgoing Cabinet had 25 members, including several without portfolio. It was not clear whether Peres would keep the Cabinet at the same size. Labor brought down the Likud-Labor coalition March 15 after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Likud refused to accept U.S. Middle East peace proposals. Those proposals, supported by Peres, were intended to clear the way for Palestinian-Israeli talks in Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Complains of Libyan Actions
With AM-Hostages, Bjt; AM-France-Libya
DOC.TEXT: Chad on Tuesday accused the international community of complacency toward Libya and said Col. Moammar Gadhafi was violating human rights in his own country while continuing aggression against Chadian forces. Chad's embassy in Paris released a statement from Foreign Minister Acheikh Ibn Oumar in which he accused Libya of a military buildup in the Aouzou region along the border of the two African countries. He said members of breakaway Palestinian guerrilla factions were being used by Libya as mercenaries against Chad. He also claimed Libya was holding thousands of citizens of Chad, Mali, Nigeria and Togo in desert concentration camps on the pretext that they were in Libya illegally. The foreign minister contended that Sudan had signed an accord with Libya to obtain weapons and money in return for allowing Libya to mobilize dissident Chadian forces on Sudanese territory. France sent 146 soldiers to Chad as reinforcements in late March after a series of attacks on Chadian troops by the Libyan-backed rebels. However, the situation has calmed down since then, and the reinforcements reportedly have been recalled. France sent large contingents of troops to Chad in 1983 to help the government of President Hissene Habre combat a major intervention by Libya in support of Chadian rebels. Habre's troops triumphed in 1987, forcing Gadhafi's troops from northern Chad.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Resigns From All-Male Club In Suburban Washington
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Sam Nunn said Tuesday he has resigned from an all-male suburban golf club, a resignation certain to fuel speculation about his presidential ambitions. ``I have dropped out for personal reasons,'' Nunn said in a statement released by his office in response to questions about his membership in the Burning Tree Club of Bethesda, Md. Nunn, who considered running for the Democratic nomination for president in 1988, did not elaborate on his reasons for resigning from the club, whose members include some of the nation's most powerful political leaders. ``My priority is to run for re-election to the U.S. Senate,'' Nunn said. ``As I have said many times, I have no plans or inclination to run for president. At no time have I ever established a pre-set time frame for contemplating a decision on a future presidential campaign.'' Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, was the favorite son of Southern and conservative Democrats during the early part of the 1988 campaign, but he twice refused to jump into the race, citing family pressures and his Senate duties. The Burning Tree Club, which has been an all-male bastion since its founding in 1922, last year lost a court battle to regain a tax break the Maryland Legislature had taken away from it in 1986 because of the club's refusal to admit women as members. The club had a long-standing agreement with the state to preserve its open spaces in return for favorable property tax treatment. But the legislature, responding to pressure from women's groups, canceled the agreement, forcing the club to choose between admitting women or losing its tax break. The Supreme Court last fall upheld a lower court ruling that the new law did not violate members' rights, and in January, the club paid $1.2 million in back taxes resulting from the case. Robert Zarnock, a Maryland assistant attorney general, said Tuesday the private club has not re-applied for the tax break, which it could do if it changed its admissions policy.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Daughter Engaged
DOC.TEXT: Kara Kennedy, daughter of Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., plans to marry Michael Allen in the fall, according to a statement issued by her family Tuesday. Ms. Kennedy, a 1983 graduate of Tufts University, is a producer for a television program in Boston. Allen was graduated from the Rhode Island school of Design in 1981 and is an architect in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Bill Authorizing $2 Billion Sale of Telephone Co.
DOC.TEXT: Bucking heavy union opposition, Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon on Tuesday signed a bill authorizing the $2 billion sale of Puerto Rico's government-owned telephone company. ``Never before have government officials of the executive and legislative branches been confronted with so much pressure and so much opposition as was unleashed against this bill,'' the governor said during a signing ceremony at La Fortaleza, his official residence. Earlier in the day, both legislative houses easily approved the measure. The Senate vote was 16-8, with 3 abstentions; the House of Representatives vote was 34-17, with 1 abstention. Led by a coalition of about 60 unions, opponents have fiercely opposed the sale of the Puerto Rico Telephone Co. since Hernandez Colon proposed it in his annual State of the Commonwealth message in February. On March 28, thousands of unionized workers staged a one-day general strike and rally at the Capitol to protest the sale, which critics say will result in mass layoffs and higher phone bills. At Tuesday's signing, Hernandez Colon accused labor leaders of ``only looking out for their own interests.'' ``To try to stop this sale by threatening buyers is to go against the interests of the Puerto Rican people,'' he said, referring to threats of labor unrest among telephone workers against any private owner. Proceeds from the sale will be used to set up two $1 billion trust funds, one for education and the other for improving public services such as highway maintenance, sewerage, water and power systems. The government expects $85 million to $95 million in interest per year. The U.S. commonwealth bought the telephone company from ITT Corp. in 1974 for $165 million. It now earns $70 million a year and employs 8,000 people. Hernandez Colon said the sale should be completed by the end of this year or early 1991. Among U.S. communications companies said to be interested in buying the telephone company are Contel, GTE, United Telecommunications Inc. and the Baby Bells.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Busts' Riches Threaten to Divide Police Agencies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `O'Hair' in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The hundreds of millions of dollars in cash, cars, and other property seized from drug dealers is setting off disputes among police departments and other agencies, law enforcement experts said Tuesday. Police at a Michigan State University conference on community policing said departments can become so addicted to the huge sums of money seized from dealers that raising money becomes more important than fighting drugs. ``Decisions start getting made based on `What's this guy got?' If he's got a (costly) boat am I going to deal with him or put my resources on this little guy selling marijuana at the high school?'' said Robert K. Olson, former police chief in Corpus Christi, Texas. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration expects to seize more than $1 billion in assets from drug traffickers this year, said David Westrate, assistant administrator for operations. Wayne County Prosecutor John O'Hair, who is involved in a court battle with the city of Detroit over access to records of how it has spent seized assets, warned that failure of departments to account for the money could undermine public confidence. ``We have public support for forfeiture in dealing with the drug problem, but when you have a city administration that shrouds these dollars in secrecy, you erode public support,'' he said. Corpus Christi police routinely made big hauls from drug busts, Olson said. Controls over the money were lax initially, with up to $250,000 in cash routinely kept in an old safe. ``They were just going out and busting bad guys and stuffing money in the safe,'' Olson said. The city used the money to start drug education programs in local schools and buy equipment, as well as finance more undercover drug buys. But Olson said one unidentified city became so dependent on drug money to pay drug agents' salaries that its chief pulled out of an interagency drug task force because he wanted to keep 100 percent of the forfeited assets rather than a 40 percent share. Agencies hungry for drug profits can also end up bidding for tips from informants, Olson said. Michael J. Leverenz, assistant police chief in Tucson, Ariz., said early use of seizure laws in that community gave police access to fancy cars they could use for undercover work, but he warned against letting those who seize the assets decide what should be done with them. ``As much as possible you want to remove people from the mentality, `If I go out and seize that Corvette, I'm the one that's going to drive it,''' he said. Bitter battles have been waged between police departments and city managers in some Arizona cities over how seized assets should be spent, he said. In one small city that netted $1.2 million, the police chief threatened to let the money go to the federal government if city officials refused to let him spend it the way he planned, Leverenz said. Michigan law requires seized assets to be used for enforcing drug laws and they may not replace existing funds, O'Hair said.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Cabinet Reshuffle Announced in Sudan
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military ruler Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir reshuffled his 22-man Cabinet Tuesday, replacing four ministers, the Egyptian state news agency reported. The Middle East News Agency dispatch from Sudan's capital Khartoum gave no reason for the change. Mohammed Khowelgi Salheen replaced Ali Mahammed Shumu as minister for culture and information; Abdel-Rehim Hamdi took over the finance and economic planning ministry from Sayed Ali Zaki; Abdullah Mohammed Ahmed was named education minister in place of Mahjoub el-Nadawi; and Hussein Abu-Saleh replaced Lt. Gen. Mohammed al-Hadi Maamoun. Until his appointment Tuesday, Salheen was general manager of the official Sudan News Agency. It was not immediately known who would replace him in the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey's Second Molestation Trial Begins Nearly Seven Years After His Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0739 to fix slugline; ADDS quotes, background.
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES (AP)_ The second trial of Raymond Buckey in the McMartin Pre-School molestation case opened Tuesday, nearly seven years after his arrest triggered public hysteria and the nation's longest criminal trial. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg told 287 prospective jurors that the retrial could stretch into 1991, and all but 90 said it would be a hardship to serve so long. The judge convened court in the jury assembly room because of the large number of prospects. More jury candidates will be summoned if the first group of 287 fails to survive questioning on hardship, publicity and personal views on the widely publicized case. Buckey, 31, has been a defendant for nearly seven years. He was acquitted of 40 molestation charges Jan. 18; his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, was acquitted of 12 charges. But prosecutors decided to retry Buckey on eight counts unresolved by the jury. Jurors deadlocked on 13 charges, but the prosecution dropped five. The first trial of Buckey and his mother lasted nearly three years and cost $13 million, making it the longest, costliest criminal trial in U.S. history. The eight remaining charges involve three children, a dramatically diminished number compared to the hundreds once described as alleged victims at the McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach. Jury selection began a day late due to delays caused by back trouble plaguing Buckey's longtime attorney, Danny Davis, who said he could proceed for four hours a day if another attorney could relieve him. Attorney John Wagner, who represented Buckey's sister in a successful fight to win back her teaching credentials, was named co-counsel. Peggy Ann Buckey was one of seven original defendants in the case. Charges against her and four others were dismissed before the first trial. Wagner, primarily a civil attorney, said one of his key qualifications is an adamant conviction that Buckey is innocent. ``This stuff never happened,'' he told reporters. ``This is the witch hunt of 1990.'' Buckey told reporters he is pleased with his new lawyer but was not looking forward to ``rehashing the McMartin case again.'' He said he was confident of acquittal because ``I know what they don't have.'' Davis said he considers the retrial ``a farce'' and ``absurd.'' ``This is nothing but a primary election ploy,'' he said, referring to District Attorney Ira Reiner's campaign for state attorney general. Deputy District Attorney Joe Martinez, who recently took over the prosecution, disagreed. ``We are convinced that Mr. Buckey is a child abuser and until it's resolved we will continue to prosecute Mr. Buckey,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Political Leaders Squabble Over East German Cabinet Seats
DOC.TEXT: East German political leaders squabbled over the Cabinet seats still open on Tuesday as Prime Minister-designate Lothar de Maiziere struggled to form a broad-based coalition government. Christian Democrat De Maiziere, who intends to lead the fledgling democracy to unity with West Germany, said he still sought a consensus on several issues. He added, however, that negotiators made ``a good bit of headway'' in the drawn-out bargaining and that he was determined to present the Cabinet list to Parliament for approval Thursday. Hans-Wilhem Ebeling of the German Social Union, tapped as minister for economic cooperation, said negotiators had a night or two of work ahead before the list was complete. The Christian Democrats' Gerhard Pohl appeared the likely choice for the Economics Ministry, which will oversee melding a centralized system of state-owned companies with West Germany's free market. He will also be a key player in negotiations with West Germany over replacing East Germany's nearly worthless currency with the powerful deutsche mark. Apparent differences emerged Tuesday between Pohl and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, an important ally among the West German Christian Democrats. Weeks ago, Kohl suggested East German savers be given a 1-to-1 exchange rate for up to 2,000 East German marks. But Pohl told the Cologne Express newspaper a 1-to-1 swap should be allowed for up to 30,000 marks a person. ``An exchange amount of 2,000 marks is no good, it's much to small,'' the newspaper quoted him as saying. A West German mark is worth just under 60 cents. Pohl also told the newspaper that ``at least 30 percent of state-owned operations'' in East Germany are in danger of extinction. The 52-year-old conservative politician was a member of the previous Communist-dominated Parliament and is his party's leading economics expert. Under an agreement reached Monday, 14 of the 24 Cabinet seats will go to the winning three-party conservative alliance led by de Maiziere, seven to the left-leaning Social Democrats and three to a smaller liberal alliance. De Maiziere announced the names of 11 designated ministers and was expected to announce the rest Tuesday evening before differences among the prospective coalition partners made more talks necessary. The freely elected government will replace the Communist caretaker administration that has been running East Germany since last October's pro-democracy revolt. Differences remain between the Christian Democrats and the Social Democrats over the sticky problem of privatizing East Germany's state-run companies. The Social Democrats want employees to be allowed to take part in ownership. Christian Democrats favor straight privatization of the companies. Social Democrat leader Markus Meckel said during a breather in the talks that the atmosphere was ``tense.'' The parties did agree the property of East German citizens should be protected for 10 years, and that East Germans should have preferences in buying land, shares in companies and housing after the two German states are unified. East Germans own no land, and some West Germans have made claims on property their ancestors owned before Germany was divided after World War II. Although de Maiziere's alliance won the most seats in the 400-member Parliament, it wants a coalition with the Social Democrats to ensure the two-thirds majority needed to enact constitutional changes to allow quick unification with West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Dissenters Leave Chilean Communist Party
DOC.TEXT: Chile's pro-Moscow Communist Party split Tuesday when a group of leading members resigned over demands for more democracy within the body. The breakaway group is led by former Sen. Alejandro Toro and Patricio Hales, who was one of the party's few spokesmen during the 16 years it remained outlawed under the military regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Pinochet yielded power to elected civilian President Patricio Aylwin on March 11. The leaders of the party dissidents say they have a following of about 2,000 members of the party, which was legalized last week. The party, founded 60 years ago, had never before split. In a statement announcing their resignations, the dissidents said they urged the party leadership to change policies for years, but they were not heard ``because there has not been an internal democracy.'' They also criticized the party's support of armed struggle against the Pinochet regime, saying the stand ``endangered efforts to restore democracy in Chile.'' The resigning party members are also known to enthusiastically support the recent changes in Eastern Europe. The party leadership did not immediately comment on the resignations. The Chilean Communist Party was considered the second largest in the southern hemisphere, after Cuba's, before the 1973 military coup led by Pinochet. At that time, it had around 16 percent of the national vote. In December's general election, it failed to elect a single congressman.

DOC.HEAD: 2 USAir Pilots, FAA Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The captain and co-pilot of a USAir jetliner that crashed at LaGuardia Airport last year can fly again if they pass recertification tests, the pilots and the Federal Aviation Administration have agreed. The FAA had revoked the captain's license of Capt. Michael Martin and suspended the license of co-pilot Constantine Kleissas, who was at the controls before their Boeing 737 slid off a runway Sept. 20, killing two. Both agreed to drop their appeals of the FAA's action, meaning they can apply for recertification sooner than they could have otherwise, FAA spokeswoman Kathleen Bergen said Tuesday. Both could have applied in any case. In revoking Martin's captain's license in March, the FAA said he ``does not possess the care, skill, judgment and responsibility'' of a commercial pilot. It charged that he failed to check a rudder control or monitor engine thrust, and waited too late before aborting takeoff. Martin dropped his appeal without admitting wrongdoing. The FAA agreed to backdate the revocation to Sept. 21, meaning he can apply for a new captain's license in September rather than waiting until March. The FAA also agreed not to revoke Martin's co-pilot's license, which it had suspended. Martin can apply for recertification for that license at any time, as can Kleissas, Ms. Bergen said. The test includes oral and flight simulator exams. Martin and Kleissas have been suspended with pay from USAir since the accident. The airline will retrain them and return them to flight duty if they pass airline and FAA requirements, said USAir spokesman John Bronson.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Townhouse Blaze
DOC.TEXT: A fire raced through a townhouse Tuesday, claiming the lives of a young couple, their son and two daughters, authorities said. A neighbor said the father screamed in vain for help. The only member of the Buchanan family left alive was 6-year-old Staci, who had already left for school when the blaze broke out at the central Delaware home around 8 a.m, said state Fire Marshal J. Benjamin Roy. ``We think it began in the living room near the steps'' and quickly swept up the steps, trapping the family, Roy said. Four bodies were found in second-floor bedrooms. A 1-year-old baby was found in the living room. Next-door neighbor Judy Koria said she heard the father, 27-year-old Eddie Buchanan Sr., calling for aid. ``He was screaming out back for help, but there was nothing I could do,'' she said. The other victims were tentatively identified as Buchanan's wife, Susan, 23; daughter Crystal, 1; daughter Amber, 4, and son Eddie Jr., 3. ``I still have to explain to my son that the little boy he's been playing with for two weeks is not coming back,'' said Koria. ``How do you explain to a little girl that she has nothing to come home to?'' Staci, who moved to the area with her family about a month ago, was placed in her grandmother's care. Roy said there was no evidence to indicate arson, but that the cause of the blaze was still under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says No Presidential Rule in Lithuania _ for Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with White House confirmation of meeting with American Baltic groups, SUBS grafs 20-22 with two grafs, `In Washington...'; picks up 23rd pvs, `The United...' ^By ANN IMSE
DOC.TEXT: One day after issuing a harsh new warning to Lithuanian separatists, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev backed off the tough line Tuesday by declaring he does not yet see a need to impose presidential rule. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, responding to the severe tone of Monday's declaration by the Kremlin, sent a telegram to Gorbachev saying he feared that ``ultra-rightist imperial forces are compelling you to take a wrong step: to continue the wrongs of the 1940s in the Baltics.'' ``In the name of peace, justice and concord on earth, do not do this,'' he wrote. He was referring to the Soviet occupation and forced annexation of the three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia _ in 1940. Since March 11, when Lithuania declared its independence restored, the Kremlin has repeatedly alternated between threatening and conciliatory tones. On several occasions, threatening military movements were followed by kinder words. Speaking Tuesday at a Young Communist League congress in Moscow, Gorbachev said presidential rule would be used only as an extreme measure during a civil conflict, the Tass news agency said. He said Soviet leaders are still trying to persuade Lithuanians to rescind their declaration of independence. Presidential rule could include martial law and dissolving Lithuania's parliament. It was elected in March and is Lithuania's first freely elected parliament in 50 years. However, in a meeting Tuesday with British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, Gorbachev said, ``The adventurist actions of the current leadership can cost the Lithuanian people themselves, the Soviet Union and world peace dearly. ``We display the maximum political goodwill, although it is increasingly harder to do,'' Tass quoted the Soviet leader as saying. In the latest Soviet show of strength, several tanks rolled through Gediminas Square in the center of Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, overnight Monday, according to Eduardas Potasinskas of Lithuanian television. At his own news conference Tuesday, Gorbachev spokesman Arkady Maslennikov said the Soviet Union plans no economic blockade among the unspecified ``economic and political measures'' threatened Monday by Gorbachev's presidential council. But Maslennikov implied the Soviet Union might start demanding world market prices from Lithuania for the subsidized oil, gas and other raw materials that the small Baltic state needs. He said this would cost Lithuania $6 billion. He said some Soviet enterprises have talked of refusing to extend existing contracts with Lithuania, and he warned that items in short supply might be sent elsewhere. ``We are not saying, `Please, stop thinking about independence,''' Maslennikov said after several tougher statements. ``But don't do it overnight. Don't tear well-established economic, political and other links, including defense.'' He suggested Lithuanian leaders consider a moratorium on all decisions since they declared independence. He also suggested that Lithuania ``not insist on state-to-state negotiations'' with the Soviet Union. Lithuania has offered to discuss Gorbachev's claim that its action violates the Soviet Constitution. But Gorbachev has demanded Lithuania rescind its declaration of independence before discussing anything. Also Tuesday, the Lithuanian-appointed public prosecutor, Arturas Paulauskas, was barred from entering his office, which he has shared for the past week with a competing prosecutor appointed by Moscow. Soviet troops occupied the building March 30 but until Tuesday had allowed Paulauskas to enter. Paulauskas' secretary, Henrika Pocei, said by telephone that Paulauskas would work elsewhere in the city. Virtually the entire staff in the main building is continuing to report to him and ignoring the new prosecutor from Moscow, she said. Maslennikov said the Soviet Union is not worried that its actions in Lithuania might upset plans for a U.S.-Soviet summit at the end of May. In Washington, President Bush was to meet Wednesday with American Baltic organizations supporting the independence drives of Lithuania as well as Latvia and Estonia. The White House schedule listed the meeting for 10 a.m. EDT. ``In our view, a meeting between Baltic groups and the president will send a clear signal to Moscow, regardless of what we discuss, that the U.S. is ready to step up pressure in support of Baltic independence,'' said Olars Kalnins, head of the American Latvian Association. Kalnins, in London for a meeting of the World Federation of Free Latvians, was to cut short his European visit and fly to Washington for the meeting. The United States has expressed support for Lithuania's independence drive, but it has been reluctant to say or do anything that might undermine Gorbachev and his reform program. Bush, in Toronto for a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, issued a fresh warning to Gorbachev on Tuesday to avoid using force in Lithuania. But he coupled his words with praise for the Soviet president's commitment to ``peaceful change and the evolution of democracy'' in Europe and the Soviet Union. ``I would just appeal to all sides and anyone with any influence to encourage dialogue and discussion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian House Passes 7 Percent Consumption Tax
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons ended nine months of rancorous debate on Tuesday and passed a 7 percent goods and services tax presented by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative government. The vote was 144 to 114. The consumption tax proposal now heads for debate in the Liberal-dominated Senate. If passed by both chambers, the tax would take effect next Jan. 1, replacing the existing 13.5 percent federal sales tax hidden in the price of manufactured products. Under the Constitution, the tax legislation must be passed by both the Commons and Senate and approved by the governor general before it becomes law. Cheers and jeers echoed through the Commons as the vote was concluded and two protesters were hauled out of a visitors' gallery for throwing rolls of paper over a balcony onto the chamber floor. On Monday, the Pro-Canada Network, an umbrella organization of unions, churches and social lobby groups, said it counted more than 2 million votes from across Canada against the measure and in favor of tax reform based on ability to pay. Recent polls indicate that up to 80 percent of Canadians oppose the tax. Finance Minister Michael Wilson, architect of the tax, and Mulroney were not in the Commons. Wilson was in Europe on government business and Mulroney was in Toronto to watch a Blue Jays baseball game with President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Trio Returned to Ohio
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Tuesday that a cult leader and two followers could be extradited to Ohio, where they have been charged with 10 others in the slaying of a five-member family. Municipal Judge Terry J. Knoepp issued the extradition order following a 15-minute hearing for cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren, Kathryn Johnson and Daniel Kraft. Each had fought extradition since their arrests three months ago. The three are among 13 alleged cult members indicted in the slayings of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters. Authorities believe the killings took place last April 17 at the group's farm in Kirtland, Ohio. Lundgren, 39, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Days Saints, is charged with 10 counts of aggravated murder and kidnapping. He could face the death penalty if convicted. Kraft, 25, faces five counts of aggravated murder, while Johnson, 36, is charged with conspiracy to commit murder. Prosecutors in Ohio have alleged that the Averys, who also belonged to Lundgren's cult, were killed as part of a ``cleansing'' sacrifice before group members left the Kirtland farm on wilderness treks in other states. Their capture ended a nationwide manhunt. On Jan. 3-4 the bodies of the Avery family were found buried under a barn on the rented farm where the group lived commune-style in Kirtland, about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Authorities in Lake County, Ohio, have until April 20 to pick up the defendants and return them. Defense attorneys had filed legal challenges to the extradition, but they were denied by a state appeals court last week. Lundgren's attorney, Militza Durovic, sought a review by the state Supreme Court, but told the judge that she had received no response. Lundgren's return could be postponed if the high court issues a stay of extradition before he leaves San Diego, but Durovic acknowledged outside court that such a ruling was ``a long shot.'' Attorneys for Johnson and Kraft did not seek a Supreme Court review. Lundgren, his wife, Alice, 38; and 19-year-old son, Damon, were arrested Jan. 7 in a San Diego-area motel room near the Mexican border. Kraft, of Nauvoo, Ill., and Johnson, of Holden, Mo., were arrested Jan. 10. Damon Lundgren was returned to Ohio last week after legal challenges to his extradition failed. He has pleaded innocent to five counts each of aggravated murder and kidnapping. Alice Lundgren waived extradition shortly after her arrest and was returned voluntarily to Ohio in late January. She has pleaded innocent to five counts each of complicity, conspiracy and kidnapping. Jeffrey Lundgren also had been a tour guide at the Kirtland temple of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints until he was ousted for radical teachings and formed his sect. The church is separate from the Salt Lake City-based Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, known as the Mormons, although they have common roots and share some beliefs.

DOC.HEAD: LA County Declares Measles Public Health Hazard
DOC.TEXT: The Board of Supervisors declared the county's measles epidemic a public health hazard Tuesday, clearing the way for it to apply for $300,000 in state funds to boost local immunization efforts. Officials say 1,500 county residents, mostly children, have been afflicted with measles so far this year; six have died. ``We are having the worst measles epidemic,'' said Supervisor Kenneth Hahn, who asked that all county health centers be kept open evenings and Saturdays to get more people vaccinated. County officials said several clinics in areas where the measles epidemic is the worst are already staying open nights and weekends to provide free measles vaccinations. That service is expected to cost the county $370,000. Robert Gates, the county's health services chief, said he would look into Hahn's request to keep all clinics open. A measles outbreak has been plaguing much of the state since 1987, but worsened during the first few weeks of this year. ``It's out of control,'' Dr. Loring Dales, head of the immunization unit of the state Department of Health Services, said earlier in the year. Other afflicted areas include San Bernardino, Riverside, Orange, San Diego and Alameda counties and the San Joaquin Valley. Nationwide, 16,000 cases of measles were reported last year; 45 resulted in deaths. Health officials have blamed the epidemic in part on a large influx of poor people from foreign countries, many of whom are not immunized and who don't know about the free health services available in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Convicted of Conspiracy, Preventing FBI-Led Raid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to ADD maximum penalty. Name `Kakwirakeron' is cq and is pronounced `Gah-wee-la-gair-loo'
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury Tuesday convicted a Mohawk Indian of leading armed resistance to a gambling raid at two reservation casinos last summer, but found him innocent of a more serious felony charge. The U.S. District Court jury acquitted Kakwirakeron, 47, of using a deadly or dangerous weapon to turn back FBI agents, and did not consider another felony charge of using a firearm in commission of a crime. Kakwirakeron, also known as Arthur Montour, was convicted of conspiracy and forcibly impeding the execution of federal search warrants during the July 20 raid at the St. Regis Reservation. Kakwirakeron faces up to three years in prison and a $5,000 fine. Sentencing was set for June 12. The verdict came during the first full day of deliberations after jurors listened to nearly four hours of testimony by the defendant and four state police investigators. In closing arguments Monday, Assistant U.S. Attorney John Duncan charged that Kakwirakeron should not be excused because of the Mohawks' beliefs the 28,000-acre reservation on the U.S.-Canadian border is sovereign, and therefore exempt from state and federal law. Duncan also disputed the contention that the Mohawks mistook the casino raid as an assault on their land. He said Mohawk sovereignty was not at issue and charged that Kakwirakeron wanted to force a conflict. The confrontation led to a 12-day standoff. Defense Attorney Seth Shapiro had argued the government presented ``not one credible shred of evidence'' to prove his client ordered barricades be erected outside Tony's Vegas International and The Bear's Den casinos during the raid. Kakwirakeron has said he was just one of many spokesmen for the Warrior Society, a self-appointed security force. Although other casinos were searched and 13 people arrested, a group of armed Mohawks blocked a highway and refused to let authorities search the two casinos. Two undercover investigators testified that casino workers were removing slot machines from the gambling parlors in the hours before the pre-dawn raid. Kakwirakeron testified during the six-day trial that he spent the entire day of the raid on a portable telephone trying to negotiate a peaceful settlement to the standoff. Witnesses for both sides testified Kakwirakeron had helped negotiate settlements in past conflicts with the Mohawks in 1974, 1977 and 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Center-Right to Dominate Slovenia Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Partial election results on Tuesday showed a center-right coalition with a large majority in Slovenia's first multiparty parliament, but the Communists will remain the largest single party. With about 43 percent of the ballots counted from Sunday's elections, the first in the Yugsolav republic in 45 years, the DEMOS coalition of six center-right and conservative parties had 76.3 percent. The Communists, whose monopoly on power in the republic was abolished, received 17.3 percent. Final results are expected Thursday. The Slovenian Liberal Party, campaigning outside DEMOS, trailed the Communists as the second-largest single party with 15.6 percent. The Slovenian Christian Democrats received the most votes in the DEMOS coalition with 13.3 percent. Slovenian Communists have moved quickly the past three years to create a pluralistic political system in their republic. Their reforms have been initiated despite harsh criticism from Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, where Communist leaders demand continued Communist dominance. Presidential candidates Milan Kucan, of the Slovenian Communist Party that changed its name to the Party of Democratic Renewal, and Joze Pucnik of DEMOS coalition will face each other in a runoff April 22. In Sunday's primary Kucan took 44.5 percent and Pucnik 26.6 percent. Elsewhere, a U.S. congressional delegation on Tuesday toured the southern province of Kosovo, where a crackdown against Albanian dissent appeared to be gaining momentum. The mission headed by Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., was scheduled to meet with members of ethnic Albanian opposition groups and with officials of the local administration in the regional capital of Pristina, 140 miles south of Belgrade, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said. DeConcini was accompanied by Reps. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., Helen Delich-Bentley, R-Md., and Jim Moody, D-Wis., on a factfinding mission to the province that has been the scene of continuing unrest. The delegation was also scheduled to meet with representatives of the Serbian minority in Kosovo, who claim they are being harassed by the Albanians, the Tanjug news agency reported. Kosovo is an administrative part of Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia, whose hard-line Communist leadership brought the region under strong central control last year by changing the state constitution that had granted self-government to the area.

DOC.HEAD: Bush And Mulroney Take In The Blue Jays' Opener
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 8th graf: ``Spotting a,'' with Bush comment on ladies in the locker room
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney together tossed out the first balls Tuesday to begin the Toronto Blue Jays' opening game against Bush's homestate Texas Rangers. The two smiled broadly as they threw the balls to a group of ballplayers standing under the covered Skydome. Boos were mixed with applause as Bush and Mulroney came onto the field and a huge banner reading ``Axe the Tax'' was plastered across the bleachers. Mulroney's proposed 7 percent tax on goods and services, passed Tuesday by the House of Commons, is widely unpopular. Bush and Mulroney wore matching royal blue baseball jackets _ Mulroney's emblazoned with the Blue Jays' logo and Bush's with the name of the Texas team partly owned by his son, George W. Bush. They later shed the jackets for their suit-and-tie outfits as they sat in an upper-level VIP box overlooking the field. Bush, a baseball fan and former captain of his Yale University team, ate snacks as they watched the game. Before the game, Bush and Mulroney visited the locker rooms of each team. In the Rangers' dressing room, Bush said he was cheering for his son's team. ``Got to raise the flag,'' he said. Bush's adoptive home state is Texas. Spotting a woman photographer in the Rangers' locker room, Bush exclaimed: ``Ladies in the locker room! A new era!'' The Blue Jays, the defending American League East champions, drew a near-sellout crowd to the 51,000-seat stadium. The stadium officials provided visiting reporters with ``skyfacts'' about the venue Bush's entourage was visiting. Among them: _Eight miles of zippers hold down the baseball field's bright green turf. _The facility's 1,280 toilets, if flushed simultaneously, would use the amount of water that flows over Niagra Falls in three seconds. _The amount of toilet paper used in its first year of operation could reach to the moon.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Bows Out of Consideration for 1992 Dem Convention
DOC.TEXT: Debt-ridden Detroit, one of five finalists to host the 1992 Democratic National Convention, withdrew from consideration Tuesday. The city can't afford the convention and Mayor Coleman Young is too busy working on finances to devote time to it, said Dorothy Brodie, executive mayoral assistant for federal affairs. The Democratic National Committee has asked any city bidding for the convention to commit to spend $15 million, Brodie said. Detroit faces a deficit estimated at $50 million to $81 million. A site-selection team from the national committee has inspected three of the finalists _ Cleveland, Houston and New York City _ and had been scheduled to visit Detroit next week, said committee press secretary Ginny Terzano. ``We still hadn't eliminated any of the finalists. Detroit was still very much in the process,'' she said, adding that the team will visit New Orleans at the end of this month. Young's staff told her the city was withdrawing its bid early Tuesday. ``We regret that,'' Terzano said. ``It's unfortunate, but we understand that he (Young) wants to look at his own back yard.'' But she said the upfront costs of being host of the convention paid off. ``The money you initially put in is returned three to fourfold. And you have to look at all that free publicity,'' Terzano said. Brodie agreed that the costs can pay off. ``The national attention directed to a city is good in terms of booking subsequent conventions,'' she said. ``There's a monetary spinoff with people spending in the city.'' But ``there are issues the mayor feels need his attention and unfortunately this isn't one of them,'' Brodie said. Young is to present his budget to the City Council on Thursday. Young's decision was generally supported. ``I think in some ways it's tragic because we could use it,'' City Councilman David Eberhard said. ``But you have to put things on a priority level.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Man Arraigned on Murder Charges in Camarena Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT name to `Ballesteros,' sted `Ballestros.'
DOC.TEXT: A Mexican man accused of taking part in the 1985 murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena was arraigned Tuesday on federal charges that included conspiracy and kidnapping and ordered held without bail. Humberto Alvarez Machain, 42, was arraigned on charges of conspiracy to commit violent crimes in aid of racketeering, conspiracy to kidnap a federal agent, committing violent crimes in aid of racketeering, kidnapping a federal agent and murdering a federal agent, said Grace Denton, spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's office. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie ordered Alvarez held without bail pending trial May 1. Alvarez was arrested April 3 in El Paso, Texas, Ms. Denton said. He is one of 18 people accused in the kidnapping and murder of Camarena. Prosecutors say Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent, was tortured and killed by members of the Guadalajara, Mexico, narcotics cartel, an organization that allegedly distributes tons of marijuana and cocaine. Camarena disappeared in February 1985. His badly beaten body and that of his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were found the following month in a remote area north of Guadalajara. Of the 18, four are in U.S. custody awaiting trial, including Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, allegedly a Honduran drug kingping, and prominent Mexican businessman Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria.

DOC.HEAD: American Soldier's Heart Transplanted Into Frenchman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with army identifying soldier as Chevers, sted Cheever, hometown, duties, gives army location of base as Schaffenburg sted Schlassenber.
DOC.TEXT: The heart of a U.S. soldier killed in a barroom fight in Nice has been successfully transplanted into a Frenchman with coronary disease, a medical spokesman said Tuesday. The operation took place March 19 at a clinic in the southern town of Saint-Laurent-du-Var. It was carried out less than 48 hours after 29-year-old Pfc. Edward R. Chevers was fatally injured during a brawl with bar workers. The medical spokesman listed the dead soldier as Edward Cheever, but army spokesman Lt. Col. Arnie Laidig in Washington identified the enlisted man's name as Chevers. Laidig said Chevers was from Sherman, Texas, and was a communications maintenance specialist with Headquarters and Headquarters Company, 4th Battalion, 7th Infantry based at Schaffenburg, West Germany, 37 miles outside Frankfurt. Details were not announced until Tuesday because doctors wanted to be sure the operation was successful. Chevers, who had stipulated his body be donated to science, was in France with three companians on leave. The heart recipient, 32-year-old Robert Ruiz, came through the operation well, according to his father, Emile. He said his son was able to walk four days after surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Seeks Solutions to Hispanic Education
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said Tuesday that parents and teachers must lead the way to improve education for Hispanics, a group that suffers a 40 percent dropout rate before completing high school. At the first of five hearings across the nation on Hispanic education, Cavazos said he supports ``school-based management'' in which local educators and parents have more input in education reform. ``President Bush and I believe strongly that parents and teachers hold the key to successful educational reform,'' Cavazos said. ``Parental involvement is a responsibility and also a right.'' Cavazos said the hearing's purpose was not to produce another study but to seek solutions for Hispanic education.Other hearings are scheduled in Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami. ``With your help we can identify and dismantle barriers to Hispanic education,'' said Cavazos, the former president of Texas Tech University. ``We've been talking about this for years and years, but we've done nothing about it.'' During the 1980s, about 40 percent of Hispanics nationwide left school before high school graduation; in Texas the dropout rate was 45 percent, he said. Only 11 percent of Hispanics complete four or more years of college by the time they are in their early 30s, he said. Liz Cuevas, a 16-year-old student, testified that economics contribute to the Hispanic dropout problem. ``The students have to support their families, and I don't think that's right,'' Ms. Cuevas said. ``They say, `I'm getting money now. I don't know if I'm going to be alive tomorrow.''' More flexible school hours would help students who must work, she said. Ms. Cuevas also suggested improving communication between young people and their parents and teachers. ``What makes me different is that I care. A lot of students don't care,'' she said. ``I want to make something out of myself. I want to be a lawyer. I want to help people.'' Gloria Rodriguez, director of the Avance family support project in San Antonio, testified that one reason students drop out is that their parents don't expect them to finish high school. ``Parenting is not something that comes naturally. It is a skill that you learn,'' said Ms. Rodriguez, whose program helps parents learn about child care while furthering their education and job training. Louis J. Agnese Jr., president of Incarnate Word College in San Antonio, said lack of money, lack of preparation and perceptions of failure cause Hispanics to leave school. Agnese proposed a national marketing campaign showing achievement through Hispanic role models. He also said politicians must find equitable funding for all school districts.

DOC.HEAD: Launch Scrubbed; Flight Delay Possibly Week Or Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `NASA said ...,' to restore time element.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB3, LaserColor CSB103
DOC.TEXT: A runaway power plant on the space shuttle Discovery forced NASA to scrub its launch Tuesday with the Hubble Space Telescope, and officials said it will be a week or two before they try again. The countdown was down to the four-minutes-to-go mark when sensors detected that one of three auxiliary power units was running too fast. Computers halted the launch process. ``A valve which failed to respond let too much fuel go into the unit which caused an overspeed condition,'' said Bob Sieck, the Kennedy Space Center's launch director. The APUs pressurize the shuttle's hydraulic system, which is used to move wing and rudder surfaces and in the ship's braking and steering systems. Astronomers who had gathered for the big event were philosophical about the latest delay in getting the $1.5 billion telescope into orbit. ``The universe has been around for a long time, it will stay around for a couple more days,'' said John Holtzman, of the Lowell Observatory at Flagstaff, Ariz. The countdown had gone without a hitch until shuttle commander Loren Shriver flipped a switch to start the three APUs, and one ran erratically. NASA rules forbid a liftoff unless all three units operate perfectly. ``We call it quits here,'' Sieck told the astronauts and his flight controllers. The huge external fuel tank was drained of its half-million gallons of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen. Each scrub costs $377,000 in lost fuel and each day's delay means $247,000 in labor and materials, not including the other NASA centers supporting the mission. The power unit will have to be removed from Discovery while the shuttle is in upright launch position. In addition, technicians will either have to remove the telescope's batteries and recharge them elsewhere, or run equipment out to the pad to charge them aboard the ship. The batteries will hold their charge through Friday, but after that would have to undergo an eight-day recharge on the ground. In orbit, the Hubble's solar panels supply electricity to the batteries. Sieck said the auxiliary power unit weighs 100 pounds and will be difficult to remove. He said NASA officials will have a better idea in the next few days when they can reschedule the launch. Replacing the entire APU would mean a delay of at least several days, said Keith L. Hudkins, chief of NASA's shuttle orbiter division. Replacing a part, however, could be done in a day or so. Shriver and his crew of four had lain on their backs in the shuttle cabin for three hours when the launch attempt was called off. NASA said the crew would return to their training base, the Johnson Space Center in Houston, on Wednesday. Most astronomers who had come to see the launch took the delay well. Giovanni Fazio of the Smithsonian Astrophysics Observatory said ``we waited this long, and it's better not to rush this thing. Whatever they do, that's a $1.5 billion payload and there's no use taking any chances with it.'' Others were disappointed. ``We've been waiting seven years for this thing to go up, so it's very depressing in a sense,'' said Francesco Paresce of the European Space Agency, a scientist who will work with observations from the telescope's faint object camera. ``I was hoping that today would be the beginning of a new life,'' he said. ``In four minutes my life was going to be completely different with the thing up there, with operations, with the instrument pouring data out by the billions of bits.'' About 150 relatives of Edwin P. Hubble, the astronomer for whom the telescope is named, headed for a pool party after the scrub. ``These things have happened. It's part of the game,'' said Harvey Hubbell IV, a 60-year-old retired businessman who organized the family gathering. ``We would much rather you stop the count than do something foolish.'' Two other shuttle launches have been delayed because of auxiliary power unit problems. One, in 1981, caused an eight-day delay; another, in 1984, a five-day wait.

DOC.HEAD: Alaskans Say Soviets Leaving Polluted Mess Behind at Czech Bases
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet military is leaving behind polluted land, streams and underground water supplies as it abandons long-occupied bases in Czechoslovakia, an Alaska environmental services company said Tuesday. ``It's just a mess,'' said former Alaska Gov. Bill Sheffield, a director of Martech USA, an Anchorage-based company that has negotiated a tentative agreement with the Czech government to help it clean up bases and other sites. The Soviets ``just kind of covered up their tracks. In some places they just left it all exposed and running into the river,'' Sheffield said. Underground fuel tanks have been ripped up and the craters covered over with dirt and gravel, he said. Martech also said pipelines or storage tanks are leaching unidentified substances onto the ground or into streams. Sheffield and other company officials last week toured several areas including the Frenstat military base with Prime Minister Peter Pithart and other Czech officials. The officials were shown one off-limits site at Frenstat where they were told a Soviet germ warfare stockpile was still being stored, Sheffield said. Martech and the Czech government signed a letter of intent Friday to form a joint venture to clean up the sites, Martech President Bill Tisdale said in a telephone interview from New York. Company officials visited ``highly polluted'' sites at Frenstat where Soviet forces apparently had been dumping materials onto the ground for decades, Tisdale said. Observers found fuel and other unidentified pollutants in rivers and drinking water supplies, he said. Frenstat was the first base to be evacuated by Soviet soldiers, Tisdale said. Soldiers began leaving the base in northern Czechoslovakia on Feb. 26. Martech plans on April 25 to begin analyzing substances to be cleaned up. Tisdale would not say how much money the work involved. Two other bases, at Bruntal and Krnov, already have been turned over to the Czechs and both will require ``extensive'' cleanup work, the company said. Martech said it will act as managing partner in a joint venture with Geo Test, a state-run hydrology and engineering company. Martech will open an office in Prague and will provide professional expertise and equipment. Geo Test will provide some skilled and all unskilled workers, Tisdale said. No details have been worked out on how the Alaskan company will be paid for its work, Sheffield said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Suggests Germany Belong to Both NATO and Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union could accept a unified Germany that belonged to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact during a transition to a new European security system, a top Soviet adviser has told The New York Times. Soviet and American troops stationed in Germany should be reduced gradually during such a transition period, which would last for five to seven years, said Valentin M. Falin, chief of the international department of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee. The Times said in Wednesday editions that it was not clear exactly how the transitional period or the new security system would work. ``We need to arrive at an all-European security system in a few years, through some transitional steps,'' Falin told the newspaper in an interview Monday night in Moscow. ``The idea that for a certain time a unified Germany could remain with its Western part in NATO and its Eastern part in the Warsaw Pact, as a modus vivendi for a few years, would probably be acceptable to our side,'' Falin said. He added that ``the most important thing would be that Germany then becomes a motor to help to extract the best out of these two organizations and then meld them into an all-European security structure.'' Falin repeated the Soviet Union's position that it could not accept a united Germany belonging only to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Soviet Union dropped its previous insistence on a neutral Germany during last week's visit by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to Washington. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, asked about the Times report while traveling with President Bush in Toronto, said he knew nothing about it. Shevardnadze suggested during his Washington visit that a merged Germany could be part of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but gave no specifics. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said then that the idea was not ``attractive,'' and that the United States remained firm in its position that a unified Germany must remain in NATO. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday that the reunification of Germany should be synchronized with the formation of a new security structure for all of Europe, the Tass news agency reported from Moscow. Gorbachev told visiting British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd that a transitional stage is possible in the meantime, Tass reported.

DOC.HEAD: For Ann Richards, Politics and Humor Mix
With AM-Texas Governor, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in last graf
DOC.TEXT: For Ann Richards, who captured the Democratic gubernatorial nomination Tuesday, a sense of humor is a necessary ingredient in the political mix. Just ask her about the dog. Ms. Richards, who won celebrity status with a witty keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention in 1988, first won public office in 1976 when she was elected a Travis County commissioner. It was ``a truck-driving, front-end-loader'' kind of job, she recalls. So when she first met her county road crew, she tried to break the ice by asking the men about the one thing she felt certain they would discuss with a woman _ their dog. ``No one said a word. There was some shuffling of feet,'' she recalled in her 1989 autobiography, ``Straight from the Heart.'' Trying to make them comfortable, the new boss told the men she was accustomed to rough language and asked the dog's name. ``An old hand in the back row with a big wide belt and a big wide belt buckle sat up and said in a gravel bass, `Well, you're gonna find out sooner or later. ... Her name is Ann Richards.' I laughed. And when I laughed they roared,'' she said. ``From then on, those guys and I were good friends.'' Her humor was one of the main reasons then-Democratic Party boss Paul Kirk tapped Ms. Richards to keynote the Atlanta convention, where she immediately charmed the crowd by saying, ``After listening to George Bush all these years I figured you needed to know what a real Texas accent sounds like.'' She sealed her sharp-tongued reputation with this line about Bush: ``Poor George. He can't help it. He was born with a silver foot in his mouth.'' That speech capped an involvement in politics that began in the late 1950s. Ms. Richards, now 56, grew up near Waco, married civil rights lawyer David Richards, volunteered in campaigns and raised four children. ``I was by no means a full-time political activist. I was involved in whatever political opportunities I could find, with the constraints of raising a family,'' she said. In the 1960s, she helped form the North Dallas Democratic Women, ``basically to allow us to have something substantive to do; the regular Democratic Party and its organization was run by men who looked on women as little more than machine parts.'' Ms. Richards served on the Travis County Commission in Austin for six years before jumping to a bigger arena in 1982, winning the Texas treasurer's office to become the first woman elected statewide in 50 years. But politics took a toll. It helped break up her marriage. And public life has forced her to be remarkably candid about her 1980 treatment for alcoholism. ``I had seen the very bottom of life,'' she recalled. ``I was so afraid that I wouldn't be funny anymore. I just knew that I would lose my zaniness and my sense of humor. But I didn't. Recovery turned out to be a wonderful thing.'' Although the primary and runoff campaigns turned into a muddy brawl that included allegations of drug use against her, Ms. Richards entered the race hinting that she knew what lay ahead. ``You know, Sam Rayburn used to say that any jackass can kick down a barn, but it takes a carpenter to build one,'' she said last summer. ``I'm against negative campaigning. But I'm not a shy violet who'll take it across the head and not respond.''

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Pay Respect at Funeral Home
LaserPhoto NA3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of friends and strangers filed past the open casket holding Ryan White on Tuesday, and singer Elton John handed out tissues to tearful mourners of the AIDS sufferer. White was dressed in a red pullover shirt and a faded jean jacket, and his eyes were covered with reflective sunglasses. A photograph of a baby rested next to him in the knotty pine coffin, around which were numerous floral arrangements. There also was a painted portrait, magazine covers that featured his story and photographs of White with celebrities and others, including Lukas Haas, who portrayed him in a television movie, actress Loni Anderson and Indiana University basketball coach Bob Knight. White, who won a court battle to attend public school and later became an international spokesman for sufferers of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, died Sunday of lung congestion from an AIDS-related respiratory infection. He had been hospitalized after contracting the disease in 1984 from blood products used to treat his hemophilia. Between 1,000 and 1,500 people filed past White's casket at the Flanner & Buchanan Mortuary in Carmel, an Indianapolis suburb, between 2 p.m. and 8 p.m., when the funeral home closed, said a mortuary worker who refused to give her name. His mother, Jeanne White, spoke with callers at the funeral home Tuesday. Standing next to her was John, who had befriended White and comforted the family during the youth's final days in the hospital. He handed tissues to weeping mourners. White's younger sister, Andrea, also was among those in the viewing room. Brian Buchanan, vice president of the funeral home, said Mrs. White set up the viewing area with John's help. Callers were lined up when doors opened, Buchanan said. Pop star Michael Jackson was among family and close friends who paid last respects earlier before the home was opened to the general public, he said. Those who came included included White's physician, Dr. Martin Kleiman. To one woman who identified herself as a former employer of White, Mrs. White said, ``Thank you so much for giving him a job.'' Mrs. White also laughed and hugged several people who greeted her. No cameras or recorders were allowed in the funeral home. A public funeral is to be held Wednesday, with Jackson and first lady Barbara Bush among those expected to attend, hospital officials said. John will sing ``The Lord is My Shepherd'' and his own song, ``Skyline Pigeon.'' Also expected to attend are scores _ perhaps hundreds _ of White's classmates from Hamilton Heights High School in Arcadia. In Noblesville, Ind., about 300 cards, letters, telegraphs and donations from across the country arrived Tuesday at the Ameritrust National Bank, which manages a trust fund for the White family. More than 3,000 cards have arrived at the bank since White entered the Riley Hospital for Children on March 29, officials said.

A lawyer for Exxon said the nation's worst oil spill was a ``tragic accident'' after the corporation and a subsidiary pleaded innocent to a five-count federal criminal indictment. Attorneys for Exxon Corp. and Exxon Shipping Co. entered the pleas Monday in two separate arraignments before U.S. District Judge John D. Roberts. Each company has been charged with two felonies and three misdemeanors. The two Feb. 27 indictments stem from the March 24, 1989, spill of nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil from the tanker Exxon Valdez, which ran aground and ripped its bottom open on a charted reef outside shipping lanes in Prince William Sound. The oil coated hundreds of miles of coastline and killed countless fish, birds and other marine life.

The ice is breaking on northern Wisconsin lakes, signaling the start of another tense spring when protesters head to boat landings to confront Indians who use spears to catch spawning fish. The first boats of Chippewa Indian spearfishers are expected to venture onto off-reservation waters tonight to exercise a right guaranteed by 19th century federal treaties. Despite pleas for peace, this spring's spearfishing season is expected to renew confrontations between the Chippewa and sport anglers, who claim spearfishing is an unfair, outdated practice that thins game fish populations. Observers are unsure whether tensions will escalate from a year ago, when more than 200 protesters were arrested and the state and local sheriff's departments spent nearly $2 million to patrol the lakes.

Hundreds of Soviet Jews, the last group to pass through this gateway to America, celebrated a Passover dinner together in an atmosphere of joy and expectancy. ``It's the beginning of a new life,'' said Soviet-born Rabbi Hirsch Rabiski, who led Monday evening's traditional Seder. The approximately 7,800 Soviet Jews staying in the Ladispoli area near Rome are all to be resettled in the United States or other countries by late May. Their departure marks the end of an era in which nearly all Soviet Jews bound for the United States lived in this seaside area, their applications handled at the main U.S. processing center in Rome. Over time, Ladispoli became a symbol of the hope and despair of Soviet Jewish refugees.

The fact that no one has spent a day in jail in the Iran-Contra scandal will work heavily in John Poindexter's favor on sentencing day, legal observers say. ``I'm a great believer in the judge taking his cue from the jury and in this case, the jury brought in the most severe sentence'' by convicting Poindexter on all counts, said Paul Rothstein, a Georgetown University law professor. But the fact that Oliver North didn't get any prison time ``militates a little bit against prison time for Poindexter,'' said Rothstein, a past chairman of the American Bar Association's criminal procedure committee. Former national security adviser Robert McFarlane and North both were placed on two years' probation in the affair. McFarlane pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors in the scandal and a jury convicted North last year of three felonies.
