DOC.HEAD: Huffington Plans Sale of Energy, Land to Taiwanese
DOC.TEXT: Oilman Roy M. Huffington has agreed to sell his Houston real estate and extensive Indonesian natural gas interests to an affiliate of Chinese Petroleum Corp., Taiwan's national oil and gas company. The deal, announced Monday, is estimated to be worth at least $600 million and perhaps as much as $1 billion or more to the Houston-based Huffington Corp. The agreement includes the equivalent of 11 city blocks in downtown Houston, 419 acres of undeveloped land adjacent to Houston's Intercontinental Airport and Huffington's Indonesia petroleum interests that formed its financial backbone, officials said. Chinese Petroleum Corp., through its 10-year-old Houston-based affiliate Opicoil America Inc., signed a cash stock purchase agreement that includes Roy M. Huffington Inc. (Huffco) and The Abercrombie Co., Huffington's real estate operation, officials said. While neither Huffington nor Chinese Petroleum officials disclosed details of the deal, analysts have valued Huffco's 16.7 percent interest in the Indonesian joint venture alone as high as $1 billion. The 72-year-old oilman, who founded Huffington Corp. in 1958, announced in November he planned to sell out and step down because of his age and his desire to sell to a bigger energy firm that would offer career advancement for the company's employees, including 137 in Houston. Lorne D. Bain, president of Roy M. Huffington Inc., an affiliate of Huffington Corp., said the sale is subject to a definitive stock purchase agreement that he expects to be completed within 45 to 60 days. Mingson Juang, vice president and general manager of Opicoil America, said Huffco's Indonesian interests initially attracted the Taipei, Taiwan-based Chinese Petroleum. Formed to explore for oil and gas in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, the joint venture includes Huffco and affiliates of Union Texas Petroleum Holdings, Ultramar and Universe Tankships Inc. The joint venture has proven reserves of 5.9 trillion cubic feet of gas and 128 million barrels of oil and condensate in fields it operates in a production sharing contract with Indonesia, and expects annual revenue of $830 million.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed; Soybeans Turn Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Transmitting again for all needing.
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices turned slightly lower but grain futures remained narrowly mixed this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Weakness in the soybean complex was centered in soybean meal, which had recently provided support to the market. Strength in near-term wheat and corn futures was partly rooted in new sales of both grains to the Soviet Union. The Agriculture Department today announced it had accepted three bids from private exporters to sell 125,000 metric tons of government-subsidized wheat to the Soviets. The USDA on Monday announced Soviet acquisitions of more than 800,000 metric tons of U.S. corn. Corn futures were further supported by the USDA's weekly export-inspections report, which showed the agency examined more corn for export last week than the market had anticipated. DOC.HEAD: International Paper Posts Profit Decline for 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: International Paper Co. said Tuesday lower prices in some key product lines, disappointments in manufacturing operations and a higher effective tax rate led to a 19.3 percent decline in its first-quarter profit. The Purchase, N.Y.-based paper and forest products maker said it earned $180 million, or $1.65 a share, in the three months ended March 31, down from $223 million, or $1.96 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 23.1 percent to $3.2 billion from $2.6 billion. John A. Georges, chairman and chief executive, said the results were affected by lower prices in paper pulps and printed and writing papers. The deepest price cuts came in uncoated printing and writing papers, he said. ``Recent increases in industry capacity led to price reductions even though sales volume remained at healthy levels,'' he said. He said paper pulp price declines stemmed from inventory corrections by customers. Manufacturing costs rose at some mills due to higher wood prices and weather-related conditions, Georges said. Production interruptions associated with capital projects and process modifications also affected the performance of the mill systems, he said. ``These situations were temporary, and manufacturing conditions are returning to normal,'' he said. The company's effective tax rate for the quarter rose to 40 percent from 38 percent a year ago, he said. Georges said the company's other businesses posted improved performances, citing contributions to operating income from recent acquisitions, speciality products businesses and consumer packaging. ``While the uncertainty of future economic conditions makes it difficult to predict performance, we believe that our investments in new markets, development of additional higher value products and improved operating efficiencies should provide the basis for continuing good financial results,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar drifted fractionally lower against most key currencies in European trading Tuesday afternoon. Gold prices fell. Late in London's trading day, the dollar was quoted at 1.6900 West German marks, down from 1.6923 marks late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar climbed 1.70 yen to a closing 158.15 yen on Tuesday. Later, in London, it was quoted at 158.60 yen. The dollar held on to most of its overnight gains against the yen, a reflection of market expectations that the Japanese currency will remain under pressure without significant action on the interest rate front, or without clear signals that the Group of Seven nations are intent on supporting the yen. Finance officials from the seven countries met in Paris over the weekend. The G-7 includes Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, West Germany and the United States. The dollar gained against the British pound which was quoted late Tuesday at $1.6345, compared with $1.6397 late Monday. Other dollar rates late in Europe compared with late Monday's levels were: 1.4955 Swiss francs, down from 1.4960; 5.6750 French francs, down from 5.6805; 1.9030 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9043; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.00; and 1.1613 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1615. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $375.15 a troy ounce, down from $375.50 late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $375.25, down from $376.25 late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.16 an ounce to close at a bid of $376.97. Silver bullion traded in London at a late bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, down from late Monday's bid of $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says It Will Begin Seizing Some S&L Assets
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout with decision to freeze some S&L assets; no pickup. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department announced today that the government plans to freeze and seize assets in cases involving alleged savings and loan fraud. The announcement came a day after the Bush administration acknowledged that its $50 billion savings and loan bailout will not be enough. A congressional report has said costs could be as high as $500 billion. A major problem with S&L investigations, said Justice spokesman David Runkel, is that ``the assets are not there following the convictions.'' The new effort will try to ``prevent assets from being dissipated,'' he said. In Dallas, a federal bank fraud task force has brought charges against 62 people, of whom 49 have been convicted, the department said. The government has recovered about $12.5 million while the taxpayers have spent ``hundreds of millions of dollars'' to cover the costs of the illegal actions, Runkel said. The assets to be targeted could be either those of the S&Ls or of the individuals involved, and the actions would be ``pre-judgment attachments,'' he said. The authority to freeze and seize the assets was part of the S&L bailout package approved by Congress last year. ``It's a device to freeze assets that are derived from savings and loan wrongdoing,'' Runkel said. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh met today with Timothy Ryan, who was sworn in Monday to a five-year term as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. As a result of the meeting, Thornburgh directed his staff and U.S. attorneys to meet with Ryan's people to coordinate efforts. ``I want to send a message to the public: we will not tolerate the fraudulent practices and decisions in the industry that in the past have led to so many failures and put such a financial burden on the American taxpayer,'' Ryan told top officials at his agency. ``There's no question that the cost is increasing and we'll have to take that into account in deciding future actions,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday. Fitzwater was responding to a report by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, that the cost of the president's bailout program would be $325 billion instead of the $257 billion estimated only five months earlier. Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who directs the GAO, said the cost could easily surpass $400 billion and could hit $500 billion if the economy falters. The estimates include the government's borrowing expenses over 40 years. Previously, Treasury Department officials had said only that a shortfall was possible. Private analysts have said for months that the $50 billion program enacted last year was inadequate. ``We don't have an analysis either to endorse or reject the GAO numbers, except to say there clearly is going to be additional costs,'' Fitzwater said. ``Those numbers will have to be decided upon at some point. ``At this time, there is not enough information to make a reliable estimate of how much more may be required,'' he said. Ryan, 44, was confirmed last Wednesday by the Senate on a 62-37 vote. Democratic opponents complained that the former Labor Department solicitor had no direct experience in banking. Ryan succeeds Salvatore R. Martoche, an assistant treasury secretary who served one month as acting director of the thrift office after the resignation of M. Danny Wall. Wall quit under congressional criticism for his handling of the failure of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, based in Irvine, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Reached on Eastern Europe Development Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting for all needing.
DOC.TEXT: Forty-two nations have agreed on the terms of a development bank for Eastern Europe after reaching a compromise over the role of the Soviet Union. Under the compromise, the Soviet Union will become a full-fledged member of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development but has agreed to limit its borrowing for the first three years. The official signing of an accord to create the bank will take place May 30 in Paris, said Jacques Attali, advisor to French President Francois Mitterrand. The location of the bank headquarters and its first president will be disclosed then, he said. Attali's announcement followed meetings Sunday and Monday of representatives of the 42 countries planning to contribute to the bank's capital base. Plans call for the bank to have a capital base of 10 billion European Currency Units, the equivalent of about $12 billion. The United States would contribute 10 percent of the bank's capital, while the European Community would be responsible for 3 percent. France, the United Kingdom, West Germany, Italy and Japan each will contribute 8.5 percent, with the rest spread out among the other members. EC countries collectively will account for 51 percent of the capital contribution. The Soviet Union will contribute 6 percent of the bank's capital, he said. The representatives agreed on 58 articles of the bank's statutes, including the type of currency to be used in the bank and the amount and form of capital contributions of each member, Attali said. For the first three years, the Soviet Union will only be eligible for loans totalling the amount of paid-in capital it contributes each year, Attali said. After that period, the restrictions can be removed with the approval of 85 percent of the member countries, he said. The delegates agreed that the U.S. dollar, Japanese yen and European Currency Unit all can be used to contribute capital to the bank. At the first session to set terms for the bank, in January, the United States objected to full participation by the Soviet Union unless Moscow initiated major market reforms. In addition to the United States and virtually every European country, participants in the bank include Japan, Morocco, Israel, Egypt and South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Reader's Digest Association Plans French Family Budget Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said Tuesday that its French subsidiary plans to launch a monthly magazine in October that will be designed to help families manage their finances. It would be the first family finance magazine from the publisher of Reader's Digest and the first magazine startup for the company since its stock was made available to the public for the first time in mid-February. Reader's Digest Association said the new magazine will be called Budgets Famille, or Family Budgets, and will contain news, feature articles and tips on topics ranging from savings and borrowing strategies to the best ways families can budget for their children's education and vacations. The company, which is based in Pleasantville, N.Y., has been publishing a French language edition of Reader's Digest since 1947 and that magazine, called Selection, has a circulation of 1.1 million a month. ``We've designed our new magazine to be of service to readers _ in the same tradition as Reader's Digest,'' Henri Capdeville, managing director of Reader's Digest France, was quoted in a news release. He said while there are other magazines published in France that focus on personal finances and investments, none cover the combined topics of families and money. The magazine's target audience will be upper- and middle-income readers between 30 and 45 years old. Bruce Trachtenberg, a spokesman for Reader's Digest in Pleasantville, said the parent company intends to ``see how well it performs in France'' before deciding whether to publish versions of the new French magazine in other languages and other countries. But he noted that the company said when describing its business plans at the time that some institutional investors offered some of their non-voting stock for sale to the public on Feb. 15 that it was interested in global expansion of its specialty magazine publishing operations through startups and acquisitions. ``We are looking for opportunities to share concepts around the world,'' he said in a telephone interview. In addition to Reader's Digest, a monthly compendium of condensed stories that is published in 15 languages in 39 countries, Reader's Digest Association publishes The Family Handyman, Travel Holiday and New Choices for the Best Years. It recently agreed to buy American Health magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Stocks finished lower Tuesday in lackluster dealings, as Tokyo's overnight drop and some disturbing corporate news sent the market downhill. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 10.2 points, or 0.46 percent, at 2217.5. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index shed 9.8 points, or 0.57 percent, closing at 1732.5. The 500-stock index was down 6.51, or 0.54 percent, at 1196.87. Volume was a slight 367.6 million shares, a touch higher than turnover of 304.6 million a day earlier. Dealers said they expect the lean volume that has characterized the market ahead of Easter to continue through the rest of the week. BAT Industries PLC, the financial services and tobacco conglomerate, fell 15 pence (25 cents) to 740 pence ($12.06) a share, after insurance regulators in California dealt a blow to Sir James Goldsmith's bid for the diversified U.K. conglomerate. BAT owns Farmers Group Inc. Goldsmith, the Anglo-French takeover specialist, had proposed to sell Farmers to Axa-Midi Assurances of France upon acquiring BAT. On Monday, California regulators ruled that policyholders' interests would not be served by a takeover of BAT by Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd. or the sale of Los Angeles-based Farmers to the French company.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Metal, Mitsubishi Mining & Cement to Merge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS quotes and background. DELETES name Nakayama from 10th graf. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two members of the Mitsubishi Group created from the break-up of Mitsubishi Mining during the U.S. occupation after World War II announced Tuesday that they will merge. Mitsubishi Metal Corp. and Mitsubishi Mining & Cement Co., in announcing their merger, attempted to head off expected criticism that the move is a step toward re-establishment of the monopoly power held by Japan's pre-war ``zaibatsu'' financial combines. The Mitsubishi Group companies comprised one of the three most powerful zaibatsu before and during World War II. Under the merger plan, nine shares of Mitsubishi Metal will equal 10 shares of Mitsubishi Mining & Cement effective Dec. 1, the companies said. The merger will link one of Japan's largest smelters of nonferrous metals with one of its largest producers of cement. ``Every president of the two companies over the past 40 years sought out the possibility of a merger,'' said Mitsubishi Metal President Takeshi Nagano, who will become chairman of the new company. ``When this merger is complete, we will feel that the war is finally over for our companies,'' Nagano said at a news conference jointly sponsored by the two firms. The presidents of the two companies said the merger should not be seen as a ``monopolistic threat.'' By combining resources, the two firms will be able to grow into a comprehensive company, which is ``the best way to conduct a flexible and dynamic adjustment to various structural changes progressing worldwide,'' Nagano said. Masaya Fujimaru, president of Mitsubishi Mining & Cement, who will be president of the new company, said the merger is not aimed at strengthening the business affiliations of the Mitsubishi Group, which is still known for its strong ties among member companies. Nagano said the metal business is vulnerable to changes in foreign exchange rates and market prices, and the merger would help protect against such vulnerability. In addition, the companies said the combination of research in metals and ceramics is expected to create a wide range of new materials. The sales of the new company are expected to total the equivalent of about $5.7 billion during the first year and $6.4 billion within the first five years, the two companies said. The new company, which will have 9,000 employees, will have total assets of $5.1 billion, they said. The companies decided on the merger in early March, right before Mitsubishi Mining & Cement closed its last coal mine in Ohyubari, marking the end of the company's 120-year coal mining business.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Cites Failures Leading to Fatal Jumbo Jet Accident
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits thruout to include comment from United and Boeing, additional details; ADDS byline; No pickup. Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Federal safety officials today concluded that failures by the airline, the manufacturer and the government all contributed to the loss of a cargo door on United Flight 811 over the Pacific Ocean last year. Nine passengers were blown out of the aircraft to their deaths. The National Transportation Safety Board voted 3-0 to blame United Airlines, Boeing, and the Federal Aviation Administration in the Feb. 24, 1989, accident, which has already led to FAA action to ensure that Boeing 747 cargo doors are secure. The board said United failed to properly inspect the door of the airliner after its electrical system failed in December 1988 and mechanics had to operate it manually. It had been operating electrically since then, however. Boeing and the FAA were cited for failing to order timely corrective measures after another cargo door malfunctioned on a 1987 Pan American flight from London to New York. The board noted, however, that the FAA has since issued directives for improving the doors and plans additional action. United spokesman Robert Dowdy said the airline has complied with all FAA requirements except one that resulted from a clerical error. Six words mandating an inspection were left out of a regulation when it was copied from FAA documents into the company system, investigators said. Dowdy said the board conducted a good investigation with the evidence it had but said recovery of the cargo door itself is needed to make it more-thorough. Boeing had recommended that the board conclude that probable cause of the incident could not be determined. In Seattle, Boeing spokesman Jack Gamble said the company had no comment on the NTSB finding ``except to say we feel, No. 1, those cargo doors are safe.'' ``There were subsequent changes made as a result of the accident, changes and inspection processes. All of the necessary actions have been taken to ensure integrity of that door's operation in flight,'' Gamble said. The FAA is expected to issue a new order requiring an additional warning system in Boeing-747 cargo doors to indicate to the pilot and the ground crew that the doors are properly locked, investigators told the board. The board said there is evidence that the current system can indicate that the door is locked when it is not. The plane returned to Honolulu from a scheduled flight to New Zealand after the door popped off at about 22,000 feet, ripping off a 15-by-10-foot section of the fuselage and hurling a group of passengers and their seats out of the aircraft. Five other passengers were seriously hurt and 33 received minor injuries. The plane carried a crew of 18 and 337 passengers. Ron Schleed, investigator in charge for the accident, said efforts to locate and recover the cargo door from three miles below the ocean would continue despite the fact the board has completed its report. He said a Navy vessel and sophisticated probe device would be available in June to search for the door. Investigators hope to determine exactly what failure in the mechanism may have caused the door to fly off, although they believe it was caused by damage to devices either during manual opening and closing of the door or due to a electrical malfunction.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft's Popular Computer Operating System in Cyrillic
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft's industry-standard MS-DOS computer software can now say it in Cyrillic. Microsoft introduced a Russian-language version of its MS-DOS operating system Monday. MS-DOS is the standard base layer of software for IBM personal computers and compatible models and is installed on more than 40 million computers worldwide. The system now comes in 13 languages. ``The new Russian-language version further underscores our commitment to the international marketplace, which is now responsible for 53 percent of our revenues,'' said Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman. The Russian version uses Cyrillic characters on-screen and also runs printers with Cyrillic typefaces. The translation is the first in Russian by Microsoft. It was done with the help of Dialogue, a Soviet-American computer joint venture formed in 1988. An operating system is the base layer of software that controls such computer functions as operating the keyboard and opening files. It differs from applications programs, which provide such specific uses as word processing or spreadsheets. ``The standardization of Soviet computer science on the worldwide DOS standard opens the door for our users to the largest application base in the world,'' said Priotr Zvelov, the Soviet chairman of Dialogue. ``It also allows our developers to build applications for a worldwide market.''

DOC.HEAD: Review of Union Carbide Settlement Adjourned Until July
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court review of the government's $470 million settlement with Union Carbide Corp. for the 1984 Bohpal gas disaster was adjourned Tuesday until July, a news agency said. The current government and attorneys for victims' groups say the settlement, agreed to by a previous government, is inadequate. Danbury, Conn.-based Union Carbide says the deal is fair and binding. The Supreme Court ordered the settlement in February 1989 during arguments on interim relief for victims, pending a decision the outcome of a $3 billion lawsuit for damages against Union Carbide. The government of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi sued after passing a law making it the victims' sole representative. It said the leakage of toxic gas from a pesticide plant operated by Union Carbide was caused by negligence. Union Carbide maintains the leakage was caused by sabotage. At least 3,598 people in the central Indian city of Bhopal died after inhaling the gas and another 20,000 were injured. Arguments on whether to overturn the settlement, which was endorsed by the Gandhi government, began April 5. Press Trust of India reported that a five-judge panel hearing arguments in the case will reconvene July 17.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed; Corn Gains
DOC.TEXT: Corn futures prices closed moderately higher Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting increased export sales. Soybean futures retreated and wheat finished mixed. The gain in corn marked the eighth daily increase in the last nine trading sessions. Some of the buying was a reaction to Agriculture Department announcements of U.S. corn sales to the Soviet Union totaling more than 1.5 million metric tons since Friday. Tuesday's trading also featured the return of large-scale buying by commercial grain dealers, who have been absent from the market in recent days. ``This indicates the commercials are pricing these purchases and that there may be some more announcements coming out,'' said Susan Leighty, grains analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Strength in the wheat reflected spillover buying from corn, she said. Soybeans traded lower in line with weaker soybean meal. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.62 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 3 cents higher with May at $2.72{ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 3 cents lower with May at $5.90{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Goldsmith Group Says Takeover Bid to Continue Despite California Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The attempted hostile takeover of BAT Industries PLC by a Sir James Goldsmith-led investor group will continue despite a potentialy devastating setback from California insurance regulators, a spokesman for the group said Tuesday. ``We are reviewing the judgment but these insurance hearings are going on in nine states and we will continue our efforts in all the regulatory hearings,'' said David Beck, spokesman for Hoylake Investments Ltd. California state insurance regulators on Monday rejected a proposed acquisition of BAT's Farmers insurance companies by France's Axa-Midi Assurances. The sale of Farmers Group Inc. to Axa-Midi Assurances is a key element of Hoylake's strategy in its proposed $21 billion takeover of BAT, Britain's largest conglomerate. One objection by the California insurance regulators was Axa-Midi's financing of its $4.5 billion offer for Farmers entirely with borrowed funds. Axa-Midi has stated it would raise cash but has not yet indicated how. Beck said Hoylake was not surprised by the insurance commissioner's ruling. ``When BAT acquired Farmers they were rejected by California initially, and rejected several times in several different states,'' Beck said. ``It doesn't come wholly as a surprise.'' BAT acquired Farmers last year for $5.2 billion following a protracted takeover battle that also saw challenges to the deal by a number of state insurance regulators. BAT issued a statement Tuesday that it was not surprised by the ruling. ``California has long opposed highly leveraged acquisitions of its insurance companies and no doubt the other eight states will reach similar conclusions,'' the statement read. Illinois, Idaho, Oregon and Washington also have held hearings on the proposed takeover. They have yet to announce their decisions. Hearings began Monday in Texas. Insurance departments in Arizona, Kansas and Ohio have yet to set hearing dates. BAT has launched a defensive strategy against the hostile bid which includes selling its Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field stores. After restructuring, the company has said, BAT intends to focus on its remaining tobacco and financial services business. BAT Chairman Pat Sheehy issued a statement which said the company looked forward ``to being able to manage our business, of which Farmers is a key strategic element, without further distractions.'' The Hoylake takeover bid was announced in July by the powerful investor group led by Goldsmith, British investment banker Jacob Rothschild and Australian entrepreneur Kerry Packer. The acquisition would be the biggest British takeover and rival the record $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Co. in 1989 as the biggest anywhere. Hoylake has said it intends to break up the London-based BAT, which has interests in tobacco, financial services, retailing and paper, to better realize the value of the separate businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Footwear, Furniture Maker Reports $23.3 Million Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc., the maker of Converse footwear and Broyhill furniture, on Tuesday reported a $23.3 million fourth-quarter loss and a 50 percent drop in profits for the year. The poor financial results come as the company struggles to restructure and pay off large debt assumed to fend off a hostile takeover in 1988 by Steven and Richard Rales of Washington. Sales from continued operations for the quarter, which ended Feb. 24, were $380 million, down 21 percent from $483 million the same period a year ago. For its fiscal year, sales were $1.65 billion, down 17 percent from the previous year when sales were $2.01 billion. The $23.3 million quarterly loss compares with a $5.9 million loss for the same period a year earlier. The previous loss would have been much higher if not for the one-time, $33.9 million gain from the sale of some of the company's divisions. Since the takeover attempt, Interco has sold Ethan Allen Inc., Londontown Corp., Senack Shoes Inc., Central Hardware Co. and Big Yank Corp.-Cowden Manufacuring Co. to raise money to pay off $2.9 billion in debt. Interco now consists of the furniture and home furnishing manufacturers Broyhill and Lane, and the footwear makers Converse and Florsheim.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Board of Trade, CFTC Followed Rules in Soybean Liquidation
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade acted within ethics rules when it declared an emergency and ordered traders to reduce July 1989 soybean holdings, congressional investigators said Tuesday. The General Accounting Office was asked to probe last summer's order to liquidate large stakes in the July futures contract. The controversy centered on Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., one of the world's largest soybean processors. Ferruzzi had gained a huge stake in the soybean contract and traders believed the company's position could lead to price manipulation. The Board of Trade was widely criticized by farmers who saw the value of soybeans drop. They suggested that traders may have learned secretly about the emergency order before it was publicly announced July 11. But the GAO concluded that Board of Trade members who held contracts did not participate in meetings that led to the emergency order. The Board of Trade and the government's Commodity Futures Trading Commission ``followed their policies and procedures concerning emergency actions,'' the GAO said. ``Our review ... confirmed that the data supported CFTC's conclusion that the (Board of Trade) was in compliance with CFTC requirements,'' investigators said. Between May 25 and July 11, the CFTC asked Ferruzzi at least 10 times to voluntarily reduce its large position in July soybean futures. The Board of Trade made the same request at least six times. Ferruzzi refused to honor the requests, and on July 11 the Board of Trade told members with more than 3 million July bushels to reduce those holdings to less than 1 million. In November, the American Agriculture Movement filed a lawsuit against the Board of Trade, alleging that the emergency order illegally manipulated soybean prices. Board of Trade Chairman Karsten ``Cash'' Mahlmann called the lawsuit, which seeks more than $100 million in damages for farmers, frivolous.

DOC.HEAD: UAL, Unions Sign Definitive Buyout Pact
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. said Tuesday it had formalized its agreement to sell the company, the parent of United Airlines, to its employees for about $4.38 billion. The definitive merger agreement follows the signing Friday of an agreement in principle between Chicago-based UAL and its employee unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants. The formalization of the buyout pact sets into motion the process for leaders of the three unions to seek rank-and-file approval of wage cuts and other contract concessions designed to save $2 billion over five years as a contribution toward the buyout. The wage cuts range from 5 percent for flight attendants with less than five years of seniority to 11 percent for pilots with more than five years. Under the agreement, UAL's 71,000 employees will buy 100 percent of the company by exchanging for each share of UAL stock $155 in cash, $35 in UAL notes and one share in Covia Corp. valued at $11. Covia is a computerized reservations company in which UAL holds a 50 percent interest. The deal, valued at $201 a share, could take up to eight months to complete. The agreement gives the employees four months to secure financing and another four months to complete the deal. Hank Krakowski, a spokesman for the union group, said he envisioned ratification of the contracts within ``a month or two at the extreme.'' Leaders of the United chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association planned to hold an informational meeting Wednesday for Chicago-area pilots, then take the show on the road to United pilots in other cities, according to a recorded message on the union's information hotline. UAL's stock traded in a narrow range Tuesday, closing up 25 cents at $161.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Chairman McGowan Undergoes Chest Surgery
DOC.TEXT: William G. McGowan, chairman of MCI Communications Corp., was in fair condition Tuesday at Presbyterian-University Hospital after undergoing exploratory chest surgery, the company and hospital said. Doctors decided last week to operate after ``they discovered a condition'' during a routine checkup, said MCI spokeswoman Kathleen Keegan. She declined to describe the condition. Washington-based MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, earlier issued a brief statement that Dr. Bartley Griffith suggested the exploratory surgery following a periodic exam and performed the surgery. In the statement, Griffith said the surgery was ``completely unrelated'' to McGowan's 1987 heart transplant but did not elaborate. McGowan, 62, has had regular checkups since the April 1987 transplant, Ms. Keegan said. The transplant came four months after McGowan suffered a heart attack. McGowan was admitted to the hospital Monday and is expected to go home to Washington in five to seven days, Ms. Keegan said. McGowan rested in his room with his wife, Sue Ginn, following the operation at about 1:15 p.m., hospital spokesman Mark Kanny said. MCI, second in size to American Telephone & Telegraph Co., on Monday announced it had agreed to acquire Telecom USA Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long-distance company, for $1.25 billion.

Stock prices ended mixed in moderate, quiet trading Tuesday after overcoming earlier losses. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.01 to 2,731.08. Declining issues barely nudged out advancing ones in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 723 up, 740 down and 511 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 136.02 million shares, up from 114.97 million in Monday's session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 163.85 million shares. Volume was limited by the Passover holiday, which began Tuesday, and by the upcoming Good Friday holiday this week, traders said. Jack Baker, head of equity trading for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said there were few factors affecting trading other than the light volume. ``It's really tough to get a handle on it because there's nothing to talk about,'' he said. He added that the market was awaiting the outcome of an auction Tuesday of $3.5 billion in 40-year bonds by the government's Resolution Funding Corp., which funds the bailout of troubled savings and loans. The results were not announced until after the market closed, and they could be bad news for the market Wednesday. Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the results ``definitely came in weaker than expected.'' Wall Street had been looking for the bonds to sell at an average yield of 8.85 to 8.86 percent, Flanagan said. In fact, they sold at 8.89 percent, substantially higher, indicating investors offered less for the bonds than expected. Stock prices had opened slightly lower on the heels of losses overseas and due to continued concern that first-quarter corporate profit reports over the next few weeks will be lower. In Japan, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average was down 2.54 percent at the close. On Monday, the Nikkei index gained nearly 4 percent in its fourth-largest single-day advance. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 0.46 percent. Among most-active U.S. blue chips, American Express was up | to 27], Philip Morris was up ] to 42\, Exxon was unchanged at 46 and USX was down } to 34|. Ames Department Stores was the most-active NYSE issue, dropping ~ to 2]. The discount store operator announced it expects to report a loss of $288 million for its fiscal 1989 and that it was negotiating a new credit agreement with its banks. Telecom USA, the second-most-active NYSE issue, fell [ to 38. MCI Communications announced Monday it would buy the regional long-distance phone company for $1.25 billion. MCI was the second-most-active issue on the over-the-counter market, gaining } to 36{. Motorola, another active NYSE issue, shot up 4\ to 68{. The technology company reported first-quarter profit rose 3.2 percent, at the high end of analysts' expectations. It also said there are signs of renewed strength in the semiconductor industry. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market grew $4.912 billion, or 0.15 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.28 to 187.63. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.67 to 397.76, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 0.70 to 342.07. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.72 to 431.90. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dropped 0.16 to 359.52.

DOC.HEAD: Bell of Pa. To Pay $42 Million To Settle Marketing Charges
DOC.TEXT: Bell of Pennsylvania has agreed to pay $42 million to settle charges in two 1988 lawsuits that it used deceptive marketing techniques in selling optional services, state officials said Tuesday. The settlement could mean refunds of up to $63 each for more than 1 million customers, State Consumer Advocate David Barasch said. More than $35 million in refunds would go to 1.5 million residential customers who signed up for Bell's so-called ``custom calling'' services between Jan. 1, 1985, and March 31, 1988. Bell of Pennsylvania admitted to no wrongdoing in settling the suit, Bill Harral, Bell vice president of external affairs, said Tuesday. He said any allegedly deceptive sales techniques were eliminated when the suits were filed. The proposal would settle lawsuits before the state Public Utility Commission and in Commonwealth Court. The PUC must approve settlement of the consumer advocate's action. Customers who signed up for call waiting, call forwarding, three-way calling, speed calling and touch-tone service between 1985 and 1988 would receive a $12 credit on their bill for each service they ordered. People who no longer are Bell customers would get a check. The allegations were based on an investigation in which 32 test calls were made to Bell representatives by agents posing as customers.

DOC.HEAD: Victims Group Hails Ruling Making Insurers Liable for $960 Million
DOC.TEXT: A court ruling that insurance companies are liable for up to $960 million in damages for asbestos exposure could clear the way for settlement of thousands of claims, a victims' advocate said Tuesday. The five insurance companies reacted with caution to the ruling by a New Jersey superior court judge, which involved claims stemming from asbestos products made by Owens-Illinois Corp. from 1948 to 1958. Heather Maurer, executive director of the Asbestos Victims of America in Soquel, Calif., which represents more than 8,000 people, the decision is a key step to resolving lawsuits filed against asbestos manufacturers. ``This basically means that our asbestos victims now have recourse and the manufacturers no longer will be able to say, `We don't have any money to pay you because our insurance companies won't pay us,''' she said. Andrew Berry, an attorney for Owens-Illinois of Toledo, Ohio, said the ruling last Friday was the largest of its kind involving claims against an asbestos manufacturer. Owens-Illinois had sought a ruling to determine whether its five insurance companies would be liable to cover damage awards. The insurers claimed that asbestos-related lawsuits were excluded from policies written between 1977 and 1985. Asbestos is widely used in building materials and as a sound-proofing and fire-proofing agent. It has been linked to health problems and deaths caused by tiny particles that become trapped in the lungs. Allstate Insurance Co., one of the five companies involved in the decision, said in a statement Tuesday it was ``surprised and disappointed with the ruling.'' Allstate, based in Northbrook, Ill., said its exposure to claims would not exceed $25 million and thus would not threaten the health of the company. General Reinsurance Co., a Stamford, Conn.-based firm that assumed much of the insurance exposure of Owens Insurance Ltd., an Owen-Illinois subsidiary, said the asbestos claims would not impact its earnings or financial condition. Both companies said the decision would be reviewed to whether to appeal. Owens-Illinois claimed in the 5-year-old lawsuit insurers wrongfully refused to honor claims. The judge rejected insurers' arguments that the Owens-Illinois policies did not cover asbestos damage, Berry said. Most of the 75,000 suits against Owens-Illinois involved individuals and companies claiming injuries and damages stemming from the use of an insulation product manufactured by Owens-Illinois, he said. Included were claims of asbestosis and other forms of lung cancer linked to asbestos exposure. Asbestos exposure also has been linked to cancers of the esophagus and colon, and to mesothelioma, an always-fatal cancer of the lining of lungs or abdominal cavities. United Insurance Co. and CIGNA Reinsurance Co., the two other insurance companies involved in the case, did not have an immediate comment to the decision. Owens-Illinois spokesman Jeff Hoff also declined comment. New Jersey has been the focus of much of the court action over asbestos exposure, partly because it was the home of the Johns-Manville Corp., formerly of Manville, N.J. Now known as Manville Corp. of Denver, the asbestos maker filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982 after a number of injury and wrongful death claims. The company eventually settled the claims by contributing $600 million to several trust funds meant to compensate those made ill by Manville products.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity's Birthplace To Be Sold To Private Investors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT shipyard manager's first name to Hans sted Jan, SUBS 4th graf, `The manager...' Picks up 5th pvs, `The shares...' Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The state-owned shipyard where workers founded the Solidarity labor movement will be transferred to private ownership by selling shares to employees and the public, its manager announced Tuesday. The fate of the shipyard in the northern port of Gdansk had been uncertain since October 1988, when Poland's then-Communist government announced plans to close it. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa viewed the step as a political move, but authorities said the shipyard was unprofitable and must be closed as part of economic reforms. ``Poland should finally understand that we were fighting for everybody, but we got nothing out of it,'' Walesa told workers Tuesday at a Gdansk Shipyard rally where the ownership transfer was announced. ``The time of struggle is over. ... Now we are fighting for ourselves.'' The manager of the shipyard, Hans Szyt, read a telegram from Industry Minister Tadeusz Syryjczyk announcing the decision during the rally by 2,000 workers protesting the slow pace of government decisions on the shipyard's fate. The shares will be sold to the public for $1.05 each, with the founding capital to total about $11.4 million, said Andrzej Popczyk, director of the Industry Ministry's legal department. Shipyard workers will be able to purchase 20 percent of the shares at half the offering price before the end of 1990 and at half the market price after that, Popczyk said. The Solidarity-led government and parliament are working out complex reforms allowing the sale of state enterprises as part of a radical switch from a centrally planned socialist economy to a market-driven system. The state industries, although largely unprofitable and outmoded, make up much of Poland's national wealth, and there has been widespread concern about how and at what price they will be sold to private investors. Few other details of the plan for the Gdansk shipyard were offered immediately, including the number of shares to be issued and the timetable for the sale. When the Communists were ousted and the Solidarity-led government took over last fall, discussions began on how to save the highly symbolic shipyard. One much-publicized offer, from the Polish-born American heiress Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, seemed to fall through when terms could not be reached, apparently because the workers were unwilling to accept the pay and no-strike agreements she required. She has offered further negotiations. The Solidarity movement was born at the shipyard when Walesa, an electrician fired for union work, scaled a fence to lead a strike in 1980. As the movement swept Poland, Communist authorities were forced to recognize Solidarity as the first legal independent trade union in the Soviet bloc. On Dec. 13, 1981, martial law was imposed to repress Solidarity's surging power. But beset by a staggering economy and dispirited populace, the Communist regime was forced to turn to Solidarity for help and relegalized the group in late 1988. Within a year, the Communists were trounced in largely democratic elections, and the first non-Communist government in the East bloc was installed with a Solidarity veteran as prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: California PC Maker Invades Japan With New Machine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Safi Qureshey is cq.
DOC.TEXT: AST Research Inc., a small U.S. computer maker, is invading Japan with a clone of that country's most popular personal computer, a rare attack on a market dominated by domestic machines. The AST computer to be unveiled Wednesday in Tokyo runs programs designed for NEC Corp.'s PC-9801, but can be switched over to the different operating system used by IBM Corp. It will be the first PC in Japan to run both systems, and AST says it will be priced competitively with NEC computers. NEC has some 70 percent of the Japanese personal computer market, analysts estimate. AST, a decade-old Irvine-based company, had $457 million in sales last year and also aggressively has been courting business in the Soviet Union and Eastern European companies. Japan's market is already well-established, and is the second-biggest market for PCs in the world, behind the United States. The introduction of a U.S. product tailored specifically for Japanese buyers will provide a test trade case for the Japanese, who say they would buy U.S. products if only Americans would tailor them to Japanese buying habits. ``I think this will really test the Japanese willingness and see if they will follow through,'' AST President Safi Qureshey said in a telephone interview. ``This machine is Japanese (compatible) ... but it is also more than what they can buy today in Japan.'' He also said: ``The Japanese cannot say that the product is missing features. It counters the arguments that American companies are lazy, just comfortable with the U.S. market.'' But some U.S. observers believe AST's machine will be unable to make many inroads into NEC's dominion. Tim Bajarin of the Santa Clara-based Creative Strategies International computer consulting firm, noted that IBM already is selling PCs in Japan and Apple also is selling products there, particularly desktop publishing setups. ``The fact that this particular box is pretty innovative and priced competitively means it will get some attention,'' he said. ``But NEC is such a powerhouse I can't imagine they will do much damage there. If anything, they (AST) will take share away from IBM.'' But Qureshey said competition from Apple, Compaq, AST and the hosts of other manufacturers have chewed away pieces of IBM's business. ``NEC is so dominant that a small percentage of their share means a lot to a small entrant,'' he said. He suggested instead that another NEC imitation already introduced in Japan by Seiko Epson Corp. may be the loser in the battle. ``We're actually the third in the market,'' Qureshey said. ``But we're the only ones compatible with both Japanese and American machines.'' A basic NEC computer, with no hard disk and no monitor, costs about 390,000 yen, or the equivalent of $2,475, AST spokesman Joel Don said. Seiko Epson's PC costs 328,000 yen, or about $2,080, according to AST spokesman Joel Don. ``Our machine will be in between NEC and Epson in terms of competitive pricing,'' Don said. AST teamed with Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corp. and Tomcat Computer Corp. to develop its new computer, named the Dual SX-16. The machines will be sold under the brand names of Japanese distributors. AST is negotiating with several potential distributors, including Sharp Corp., Don said. The company plans to build the first machines at its Fountain Valley plant in Southern California but probably will shift production to Taiwan when distribution arrangements are completed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Clears Acquisition Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Tuesday removed the final obstacle to Norton Co.'s planned $550 million sale of Eastman Christenson Co. to Baker Hughes Inc. To allow the sale to move forward, officials required Baker Hughes, a Houston-based energy products and services company, to sell the diamond drill bit business of the Hughes Tool Co. Eastman Christenson also makes diamond drill bits, and the sale by Baker Hughes would eliminate possible antitrust problems surrounding the deal. Baker Hughes corporate vice president Ron Turner said the company sold $17 million in drill bits last year. He said several parties have expressed interest in buying the line but he declined to name the potential buyers. Eastman Christenson drills contributed $40 million to the company's 1989 sales, Turner said. The companies said they expected to close the deal within the next few days. The Justice Department's consent decree stipulates that if the drill business is not sold by Aug. 6, it must be placed under the oversight of a trustee to manage and sell the company for Baker Hughes. Norton Co., a leading maker of abrasives such as grinding tools and sandpaper, is a target of a $1.6 billion, $75 per share hostile takeover bid from the British conglomerate BTR PLC. The Norton board of directors has rejected the offer, but BTR has threatened to take control of the board via a proxy fight at the company's upcoming annual meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Huffington Brought Texas Spirit to Overseas Operations
DOC.TEXT: Roy Huffington, a Harvard-educated geologist who struck it rich in Indonesia, has agreed to sell his interests in natural gas and Houston real estate to Taiwan's national oil company. Terms weren't disclosed when the deal was announced Monday, but analysts have valued Huffington Corp.'s assets at anywhere from $600 million to $1 billion or more. The properties include the equivalent of 11 city blocks in downtown Houston, 419 acres of undeveloped land adjacent to Houston's Intercontinental Airport and Indonesian natural gas and oil interests that formed the backbone of Huffington's empire. Chinese Petroleum Corp.'s Houston-based affiliate, Opicoil America Inc., signed a cash stock purchase agreement that includes Roy M. Huffington Inc. (Huffco) and The Abercrombie Co., Huffington's real estate operation, officials said. Huffington, 72, became an international oilman because he thought there were too many restrictions on natural-gas production in the United States. He began searching in Indonesia because its deltas were similar to those of southern Louisiana, a proven gas-rich area. In 1968, Huffington and a partner signed a drilling contract with Indonesia's state oil and gas company. The venture began paying off in 1972, when Huffington's company found a major gas reserve. The field in East Kalimantan, Indonesia, has proven reserves of 5.9 trillion cubic feet of gas and 128 million barrels of oil and condensate. The field, which Huffington operates in a production-sharing contract with Indonesia, expects annual revenues of $830 million. In the late 1970s, Huffington began diversifying into real estate. Huffington graduated from Southern Methodist University with a geology degree in 1938, then earned master's and doctoral degrees at Harvard. He started as a field geologist for Humble Oil & Refining Company in 1946 and a decade later founded his own firm, Roy M. Huffington, Inc. Huffington's personal fortune has been valued at more than $350 million by Forbes magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Plunges To 14-Month Low On Supply Glut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 11th graf pvs, `Cocoa futures... to UPDATE with cocoa prices; PICKS UP 12th graf pvs, `What really...
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures tumbled to their lowest levels in more than a year Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid selling inspired by continuing signs of a worldwide glut. On other commodity markets, cocoa futures surged to their highest close in nearly a year; precious metals fell; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures rose. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 19 cents to 76 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $17.68 a barrel, the lowest settlement of a near-month crude oil contract since Feb. 14, 1989. Heating oil futures finished .10 cent to .88 cent lower with May at 52.40 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.35 cents to 2.46 cents lower with May at 58.43 cents a gallon. As in the five previous sessions, selling was largely motivated by perceptions of oversupply due to seasonal refinery shutdowns and OPEC overproduction of crude oil. ``There's a lot of bearish sentiment in the market,'' said William Hinton, an energy broker with Stotler & Co. Those views were supported Tuesday by a trade report on European crude oil stocks that showed supplies increasing there. After the close of trading in New York, the American Petroleum Institute released its weekly report on U.S. petroleum stocks, showing an 8.1-million barrel rise in U.S. crude supplies. The API report far surpassed the expectations of even the most bearish analysts, who had expected it to show, at most, a 3-million-barrel buildup. One reason for the unexpectedly large increase in crude supplies was an unforeseen 1.8 percent decrease in refinery activity. At this time of year, oil refineries usually increase activity after seasonal shutdowns to adjust for greater gasoline production. Cocoa futures soared on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, largely in reaction renewed fears of supply disruptions in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. Cocoa futures settled $66 to $76 higher with May at $1,329 a ton, the highest settlement of a near-month cocoa contract since last April 20. ``What really got the market roiled up was at midday you had talk of escalating problems there with possible closures of gasoline stations and a possible port strike,'' said Merrill Lynch analyst Judy Ganes. Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. said a dock strike may already have begun. Gold and silver futures slipped on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold futures settled $1 to $1.10 lower with April at $375 a troy ounce; silver fell 1.3 cents to 1.7 cents with May at $5.113 a troy ounce. Corn futures posted moderate gains on the Chicago Board of Trade for the eighth time in the last nine sessions, reflecting increased export sales. Soybean futures retreated and wheat finished mixed. After the close, the USDA released a supply-and-demand report indicating demand for corn and soybeans has picked up a bit, so year-end stockpiles may be smaller than forecast previously. The drop in projected Sept. 1 corn inventories to 1.33 billion bushels from last month&s~e 1\ cents higher across the board with May at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 2{ cents lower with May at $5.91 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures rose on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, helped by stronger cash markets. The April live cattle contract traded as high as 80.25 cents a pound, matching the all-time high posted in 1979. Live cattle futures settled .05 cent to .30 cent higher with April at 80.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .38 cent higher with April at 84.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .62 cent higher with April at 55.37 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .40 cent to 1.23 cents higher with May at 55.80 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Loses Try for Lockheed Directors, Wins on Shareholders' Rights
Repeating for all needing
DOC.TEXT: Investor Harold Simmons said Tuesday he failed in an attempt to oust Lockheed Corp.'s directors but won on several shareholder issues, including seeking to abolish the company's so-called poison pill. Citing preliminary tallies, Simmons said four shareholders' rights proposals each received 57 percent to 97 percent of the votes cast at last month's annual shareholders meeting. Incumbent Lockheed directors were re-elected with between 58 percent and 61 percent of the votes each, the billionaid. Lockheed, maker of the stealth fighter and other military hardware, said its directors won with 62 percent of the vote. The Calabasas, Calif., company also confirmed the outcome of the shareholders' rights provisions, but did not reveal specifiire investor sacs. Lockheed said its nominees won 78 percent of the vote of shareholders not controlled by Simmons. The results are preliminary, and will not be official until Monday, Lockheed spokesman Steve Shadet said. ``It appears we achieved a clean sweep on the issues of confidential voting, opting out of the Delaware anti-takeover law, abolition of the poison pill and anti-greenmail,'' said Simmons, who controls about 19 percent of Lockheed stock. ``The shareholdeother tumble Tuesday, sending crude oil prices to their lowest level in more than a year. Analysts blamed the recent price decline on sizeable supplies and production while demand has been weaker than expected. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, lost 76 cents to settle at $17.68 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract fell 71 cents on Monday. Later contracts posted smaller losses Tuesday. The May settlement price was the lowest for a near-month contract for West Texas Intermediate since it finished below $17 a barrel in February 1989, according to Elders Futures Inc. Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders, said West Texas Intermediate has fallen 27 percent in the past 11 weeks. Analysts cited recent reports that indicate the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been producing 24 million barrels of oil a day with no signs of a letup. In addition, they said the normal maintenance periods for many oil refineries are ending and the refineries should soon resume production. At the same time, they said demand for oil has been weak with big customers either placing smaller orders because of weak business conditions or postponing purchases in anticipation of further price declines. ``With heavy imports coming in, weaker than expected demand and good stocks already, this market has no other way but to go down under the weight of in excess of 2 million barrels a day of crude,'' said James Steel, energy analyst for the brokerage Refco Inc. in New York. Bob Baker, oil analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said he estimates OPEC is producing 1.5 million barrels a day more than the market can sustain and said ``they have shown no indications of moving down.'' Gasoline futures also dropped sharply on Tuesday on the New York Merc. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline settled 2.46 cents lower at 58.43 cents a gallon, after Monday's drop of 1.22 cents. Later contract months had smaller losses. The decline in home heating oil prices was not as sharp. May home heating oil fell 0.67 cent to 52.40 cents a gallon, after falling 0.64 cent on Monday. Later contracts posted bigger declines. Prudential Bache's Baker said the steep decline in gasoline futures may have reflected an earlier overestimation of how strong demand would be. ``We have been seeing 1 and 2 percent less consumption here than we had last year,'' he said. He said the more subdued decline in home heating oil may reflect some lingering demand because of unexpectedly cold weather in some parts of the country. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.620 per million British thermal units, down from $1.637 on Monday. Contracts for delivery further in the future were also lower.

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Reports Record First Quarter Results
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. said sales rose 16.5 percent in the first quarter, reflecting strong growth in its cellular telephone businesses, but profits grew by only 3.3 percent. Motorola, based in this Chicago suburb, said net income rose to $127 million or 98 cents a share in the first three months of 1990 compared with $123 million or 95 cents a share a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.53 billion from $2.175 billion. Sales climbed 53 percent in the company's general systems sector, which includes its cellular telephone and computer operations, spokesman George Grimsdrud said. ``In the communications arena, the cellular telephone business continues to expand rapidly,'' said George Fisher, chairman and chief executive officer, in a statement. ``Higher orders for two-way radios and paging products indicate that our investments in these technologies also should result in sizeable growth.'' Semiconductor sales rose 13 percent in the latest period and orders rose 14 percent, but operating profits declined, Motorola said. ``There are some promising early indications of renewed strength in the semiconductor industry,'' Fisher said. ``We are confident that our focus on quality, efficient short-cycle production, and customer satisfaction should enable us to gain greater shares of growth electronics markets.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT first set of franc figures to Swiss sted French; picks up 11th graf pvs bg'ng, Late dollar ...
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined sharply Tuesday against most major currencies in thin, see-saw trading as concerns about continued central-bank intervention dampened market sentiment. Gold prices also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $375 a troy ounce, $1 lower than late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $375.50 an ounce, off 15 cents. Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York, said traders were reluctant to buy dollars for fear major central banks would intervene to drive the dollar down again. Several central banks, including the Federal Reserve, sold dollars in Europe and Asia to help stem the yen's decline on Monday. That action followed a weekend meeting in Paris in which the major industrialized nations, known as the Group of Seven, agreed to closely monitor developments in the yen. The Japanese currency has been under pressure lately amid growing signs of a weakening Japanese economy and a sharp decline on the Tokyo stock market. Also helping to weaken the dollar Tuesday were reported comments from West German Finance Minister Helmut Haussmann that he expects the mark to firm as a result of a planned economic and monetary unification of East and West Germany, currency dealers said. Trading was described as thin Tuesday because of the Passover holiday and in advance of the upcoming Easter holiday. In Tokyo, where global trading begins, the dollar climbed 1.70 yen to a closing 158.15 yen on Tuesday. It was quoted at 158.60 yen in London, and at 157.60 yen in New York, down from 158.335 Monday. The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling sold in London for $1.6345, down from $1.6397; and for $1.64515 in New York, up from $1.63445 Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.6750 West German marks, down from 1.6935; 1.4830 Swiss francs, down from 1.4982; 5.6285 French francs, down from 5.6845; 1,230.16 Italian lire, down from 1,243.00; and 1.16925 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6900 West German marks, down from 1.6923 marks; 1.4955 Swiss francs, down from 1.4960; 5.6750 French francs, down from 5.6805; 1.9030 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9043; 1,240.00 Italian lire, down from 1,242.00; and 1.1613 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1615. Gold traded in London at a late bid price of $375.15 an ounce, down from $375.50 late Monday. Gold also fell in Zurich to $375.25 an ounce from $376.25. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed down $2.16 at $376.97 an ounce. Silver prices also weakened. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.091 a troy ounce, down from $5.104 late Monday. Silver fell in London to $5.13 an ounce from $5.14.

DOC.HEAD: Securities Dealers Agree To Work Toward International Trading Standards
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of securities dealers in the United States and four other nations have agreed to work toward common international standards for settling trades. However, officials who wrapped up a two-day meeting of the International Councils of Securities Dealers and Self-Regulatory Organizations on Tuesday said it may be some years before that can be achieved. ``We start from a position of enormous differences among the major markets,'' said Stanislas M. Yassukovich of The Securities Association, a self-regulating organization of brokers in Great Britain. For instance, stock trades are settled in five days in the United States, three days in Japan and after a much longer period in European countries. The representatives also agreed to regularly share confidential information needed to regulate international securities trading. The international group was founded in 1988 to promote effective regulation of cross-border securities trading. Its members include groups from the United States, Britain, Japan, France and Canada. According to Joseph R. Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, cross-border stock trading has increased 16-fold since 1979 to $1.5 trillion a year. Such trading is expected to near $5 trillion by the end of the decade, he said. This week's gathering was the group's third meeting. The next is scheduled in 1991 in London.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting
Westinghouse Says Net Income Up 11 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Tuesday its first-quarter profit increased 11 percent in part because of the sales of two radio stations and a minority interest in a nuclear power project. For the three months ending March 30, Westinghouse posted net income of $210 million, or $1.43 per share, up from $189 million, or $1.30 per share, in 1989's first quarter. Net income in the year-ago period included a gain from the sale of a minority cable-television interest. Revenue dropped 0.9 percent to $2.86 billion from $2.89 billion a year ago. However, after adjusting for the 1989 first-quarter sale of transmission and distribution businesses, revenue rose 10 percent, the company said. Westinghouse Chairman John C. Marous said the company received more orders for its electric systems and power generation divisions. Westinghouse said revenue and operating profit in its financial services division went up because it had more outstanding loans and marketable securities. In broadcasting, operating profit dropped because of ``the softness of the Northeast market,'' while revenue held steady, the company said. In energy and utilities, operating profit rose on higher sales by the power generation division. In industries, revenue and operating profit rose slightly, and recent acquisitions raised revenue and operating profit in the furniture unit. Revenue and operating profit also rose in the electronic systems unit, Westinghouse said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Missouri Men Arrested in Greyhound Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf: ``Both men,'' with two grafs to note proceedings before magistrate in St. Louis. Also moved on general wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two striking Greyhound drivers in Missouri were arrested Tuesday in connection with the shooting at passenger-occupied buses near St. Louis last month, federal agents said. Those arrested were Roy B. Simes, 35, and Harry T. Lewis, 42, both of suburban St. Louis, said Stephen Higgins, director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. There were no injuries in either of the March 22 incidents. One involved a bus traveling on Interstate 55 about 12 miles south of St. Louis and the other was just across the state line in Collinsville, Ill. The federal agency announced last week it was investigating the more than two dozen Greyhound shootings that have occurred since 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other workers walked off the job March 2 over wages and job security. Both men were charged before a federal magistrate in St. Louis with three federal crimes _ endangering people on board a vehicle used in interstate or foreign commerce; commission of a felony with a firearm that has been transported in interstate commerce and use of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, the agency said. Spokesman Tom Hill said U.S. Magistrate Richard Buckles ordered the men held without bond pending another hearing at 2 p.m. Wednesday. If convicted, the men could face up to 10 years in jail and a $10,000 fine. Using a firearm during the commission of a felony carries a mandatory five-year jail term. The two St. Louis arrests were the agency's first since getting involved; an arrest in a Hartford, Conn., shooting incident has been the only other arrest. That also involved a striking driver. There were no new bargaining developments. Talks between Greyhound Lines Inc. and the union have been stalled since March 18, and the company said it will not resume negotiations until a week goes by without any acts of violence. Along with the nearly 30 shootings at buses and more than 100 bomb threats, the union contends there have been more than 60 incidents of violence against striking workers. One striker was crushed to death by a bus in Redding, Calif., on March 3. Greyhound, the only nationwide bus system, has been operating on a reduced schedule with replacement drivers they hired and union members who crossed the picket line.

DOC.HEAD: Pepperell Sells U.K. Unit To Dutch
DOC.TEXT: West Point-Pepperell Inc. said it had sold its British division, Arthur Sanderson and Sons Ltd., to the Dutch textile group Gamma Holding N.V. for $96.5 million. The sale announced Tuesday was seen as another move by Chicago industrialist William Farley to raise the necessary cash to complete his acquisition of Pepperell, the big Georgia-based textile company. Farley owns 95 percent of Pepperell's stock. Calls to Farley's company, Farley Inc., were not returned Tuesday. The collapse of the junk bond market has dealt a severe blow to Farley's expansion plans. Last week, the Farley subsidiary formed to acquire Pepperell announced it had defaulted on $1.5 billion worth of loan and bond payments. Farley is trying to restructure a $796 million loan obtained from a consortium of banks for the Pepperell buyout. Unless the loan is restructured, analysts say, Farley may be forced to sell more assets to raise enough money to complete the Pepperell acquisition. Farley's other properties include Fruit of the Loom Inc. and Acme Boots. Pepperell manufactures apparel and bedding sold under such brands as Ralph Lauren, Martex, Lady Pepperell, Esprit and Utica.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T-Memorex-Telex Announce Deal on Mainframe Controllers
DOC.TEXT: Memorex-Telex N.V. has agreed to purchase most of AT&T's synchronous terminal products business, which includes mainframe-compatible terminal displays, printers and software, the companies said. Under the agreement announced Tuesday, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. will receive royalties from Memorex-Telex for five years from the sale of equipment designed to connect with IBM's 3270 system and the sale of personal computers. AT&T also will acquire an equity stake in Memorex-Telex. Although the companies didn't disclose the size of the stake, AT&T last week said it would acquire between 5 percent and 10 percent of the Dutch company. AT&T will continue to manufacture the mainframe computer equipment for at least two years and provide Memorex-Telex access to technology and software developed at AT&T's Bell Laboratories, the statement said. ``Both AT&T and Memorex-Telex currently offer strong complementary product lines,'' Charles E. Yates, president of AT&T's synchronous terminal products unit, said in a statement. He said customers would benefit by a wider selection of choices to serve their data communication needs. Giorgio Ronchi, chief executive officer of Memorex-Telex, said the move would enhance the company's financial position by providing new revenue. ``With our access to worldwide markets and AT&T's strength in research and development, we have a winning combination that can compete anywhere for function and performance,'' Ronchi said. Memorex-Telex, based in Amsterdam, resulted from the 1987 purchase of Tulsa, Okla.-based Telex Corp., a computer systems maker, by the former Memorex International NV. The company makes a variety of computers and computer products and operates in 27 countries. Its American subsidiary is based in Morristown. Memorex-Telex had 1989 sales of $2.24 billion, said Julia C. Gentz, a company spokeswoman in Tulsa. It has about 10,000 employees, including 6,500 in the United States, she said.
